entry.title: A quick Comment on Sewell's Logics
entry.content:
I think that Sewell’s comments about the teleological methods of Tilly and Wallerstien offer a very fine definition of the term teleological. It appears to me that he argues that a concept or logic  (as opposed to process) is the locus of teleology. It also points to what is to me the most dangerous type of history: the assumption of an eternal humanity across temporality. This is dangerous because it is both very attractive–it promises to add gravitas to even the most particular of studies– and because it obfuscates what history can do. It accomplishes the latter either by the former or by its inverse: it begins with an assumption about the nature of humans and/or their interactions and uses this to extrapolate meanings either toward or away from the actual event.

I also appreciate– though my deficiency in this area limits the worth of such appreciation– the manner in which he demands a statistically viable amount of phenomena and that, often, phenomena have to be considered in relation to one another, limiting the “scientific” context that can be given to particular events. Overall, a fantastic book!

entry.title: 11/28 Logics of History
entry.content:
In his book, Sewell argues for more dialogue between history and the social sciences, asserting that each has something to teach the other. He notes that historians often appropriate social scientific theory, but that sociologists, perhaps from a desire to appear as scientific as possible, generally do not adopt the temporal theories inherent to historical study. His autobiographical discussion of the turn from social to cultural history in the 1980s was very well done, and the personal lens gave the chapter an interesting angle. His discussion of structure was a little hard to follow, but given the very clear style of the rest of the book, I suspect that my difficulty with that chapter was due more to my lack of background in the field, rather than to Sewell’s explanations of the concept.

The chapters on the taking of the Bastille and the Marseilles dockworkers were the ones I found most interesting and helpful. I appreciated the application of theory to a concrete historical event (another term Sewell describes well); it allowed me to better understand how the theories discussed could be applied, rather than just leaving them in the abstract. I also appreciated his argument for using quantitative data, when applicable, as an additional means of mining sources for information. As a medievalist, my source material is somewhat scarce, and being able to extract every pertinent thing from it is crucial. I rather wish we had read this book earlier in the semester, as it clearly defined some terms that I had struggled with in other readings and for which I had been unable to find clear explanations.

I have a couple of friends doing graduate work in sociology, and reading Sewell’s book makes me want to initiate a dialogue with them to learn more about how they undertake studies in their discipline. They both study modern ecological sociology, so I’m not sure how much theory/methodology we could exchange, given our different foci and time periods, but I think it would be interesting to compare notes.

entry.title: The Logics of History
entry.content:
Sewell, Logics of History

William Sewell ultimately argues for an increased between history and the social sciences.  He picks certain foundational tools of historians, sociologists, anthropologists and other social scientists to provide a more articulated and nuanced approach to explaining the interrelation of the many disciplines.  Historians’ greatest advantage, Sewell asserts, is their understanding of the “temporalities of social life.”  In essence, historians understand contingency.  The social sciences’ greatest strength is “their penchant for structural thinking.”  Sociology’s foundations in theory help social scientists to understand the past and the present according to set of unchanging systems or structures of social organization and power. 

Sewell argues that history and the social sciences must bend and subject themselves to modification in order to create a unified social theory for all the disciplines.  He calls for a mixture of historians’ understanding of temporalities, sociologists’ commitment to structural explanations, and anthropologists’ recognition of the dialectics of power and culture within societies.   The categories of culture and structure, he asserts, are useful, but they must be modified to accept the idea of temporality.  Everything is contingent, and cultural and structural interpretations must be responsive to that understanding of reality. 

At the surface, it is clearly evident that history can benefit from the single causation of sociologists to help winnow our multifaceted strands of causality.  But here again, I think we come back to the issue of objectivity.  If a historian’s research is driven by a belief in the existence of a fundamental structure of power or society is he not likely to find exactly that because he reads the sources to fit his conclusions?  But it can also easily be argued that because everything is contingent, that the structures are constantly evolving and historical investigations will not find the structures we seek, but their historical counterparts which, while similar, are intrinsically different.  

My own cautionary reticence notwithstanding, Sewell’s volume had many engaging discussions—some of which I am sure I failed to comprehend as they were intended.   In particular I enjoyed the discussion of temporality and causality and the shift within the historical profession from the “new social history” to a history driven by culture were quite interesting and well written.

entry.title: Logics of History
entry.content:
William H. Sewell Jr. argues in Logics of History, that historians, sociologists, and anthropologists all have unique insights into the study of the human condition and unique limitations, based on the assumptions and practices of their respective disciplines. Sewell therefore argues that the most complete and incisive study of social history would be done with due consideration shown to each of the disciplines. He argues that this is in scholars best interest, not only to improve the work done and the quality of the understanding the work would engender, but also because each discipline shares interest in many of the same things, and thus have much to benefit from such academic exchanges. He explained his motives in encouraging such interdisciplinary study due to his personal experience working with scholars of other fields.

Of particular interest to me was Sewell’s examination of Geertz. Since we have read some of Geertz’s work on “thick description” in this class a few weeks ago, I was intrigued to read Sewell’s take on it within this study. Sewell notes first that Geertz is the preeminent ambassador of anthropology to other scholastic traditions, though he is often criticized within his own field. Sewell agrees with the materialist critique of William Roseberry that Geertz lacks sufficient attention to temporality and power relations, looking at cultural practices simply as given and detached from their historical tradition(177). Sewell had previously given this to be the major failing of anthropological study, and the area in which historians could contribute the most to the other two disciplines. Still, Geertz remains very important to historians, which Sewell attributes to the similar interest historians and anthropologists have in studying different cultures. He says, “History, like anthropology, specializes in the discovery and display of human variety, but in time rather than in space,”(179-80) or, as we have been apt to say all semester, “the past is a foreign country.” Answers pertaining to understanding people who operate from a different set of assumptions is naturally intriguing to historians, whether the subjects of the study are past or present. We are both most comfortable evaluating cultures from some type of distance, looking in from the outside. Finally, I found his case studies at the end of the book to be interesting, though personally I would have been more interested to see one at the beginning of the book and one at the end.

entry.title: hist510-- Logical?
entry.content:
When I first completed Logics of History by William Sewell, I was not sure exactly how I felt about the book as a whole. Although I finally came down on the favorable side of the book, this was not one of my favorite assignments for this course; I believe the word that most accurately how Logics of History struck me is “unexpected.” From the title, I suppose I was anticipating a book directed more toward developing historical methodology instead of one that aimed to promote interdisciplinary theoretical constructions. This preconceive mindset was a surprising inconvenience proved to be a surprising inconvenience while reading the book, for I constantly had to readjust my expectations and remember to judge the book based on its own merits. I must admit that I enjoyed the setup of Logics of History quite a lot; having each chapter as a self-contained argument helped divide the book into manageable segments and allowed Sewell to develop the individual points most important to his overall theme.

On a basic level, I agree with Sewell that social theory needs some reworking in order to be useful to contemporary academics. Beyond this fundamental observation, I most strongly agree with his critique on the problems of social theory and how he proposes to address these issues. One of the biggest problems he identifies is the static nature of social theory in the social sciences, which precludes the possibility of historical change. I believe that incorporating historical concepts of temporality would benefit social theory precisely because, as Sewell says, it would make such structures flexible enough to accommodate the inevitable changes society and culture go through over time. I thought Sewell did an admirable job of arguing for greater incorporation of basic historical assumptions into a working social theory, although my favoritism toward the discipline of history predisposed me to accept claims on the value of historical methodology.

I also appreciated Sewell’s ideas on “social network of scholarship” that exists amongst the intellectual community of scholars. By this, Sewell simply means that no scholarly work is created entirely independent of “outside” works, outside in this case referring to extra-disciplinary. This idea ties directly into one of Sewell’s basic premises: the need for greater interdisciplinary cooperation between history and the social sciences, namely sociology, anthropology and even economics/political science.  It is his belief in the interconnectivity of these disciplines that drives Sewell’s search for a more universally comprehensive social theory. Although I agree with Sewell’s conception of an “intellectual community” that transcends disciplinary bounds, I hesitate to extend this argument to the length Sewell does. I accept the assertion that each discipline experiences an overlap of goals and methodology, but these basic similarities should not override more pronounced differences. Historians, sociologists and anthropologists are all trained to look for different things and each pursues its goal in the manner most appropriate.

Because of my conviction that each discipline is inherently unique, I also found myself wary of Sewell’s attempt to create a social theory applicable to each discipline. I am certainly not saying that such a thing could not be done, or would not be useful if accomplished. I am simply not sure that a universal social theory is necessarily desirable in contemporary scholarship. To make such a theory acceptable to all disciplines, the emergent structure would necessarily be characterized, if not entirely composed, of compromises. I cannot help but wonder if each discipline is better off adhering to the form of social theory most suitable to it.

entry.title: Logics of History
entry.content:
Our reading this week was Logics of History: Social Theory and Social Transformation, by William H. Sewell Jr.  In it, Sewell relates history to a vocabulary of social theory, making historical study more relevant to social sciences and cultural studies, and vice versa.  He places Historical events into a theory of social structures in an attempt to answer the question, what can history and social science teach one another?  That is a wonderful point of view.  Historians should not shy away from utilizing other disciplines to create an accurate picture of whatever their topic may be.  Sewell believes that Historians can learn a lot about theories of social structures from social scientists.  On the other hand, he believes social scientists can learn something of ‘the temporalities of social life’ from historians.

Sewell’s idea seems like common sense to me, and it was refreshing to have it set down so eloquently with examples that show the effectiveness of combining the benefits of the disciplines of history, sociology, political science, economics and anthropology.  This is a fitting way to close out the semester, as we began the year talking about trends of social sciences mixing with historical practice in search the best ways of ‘doing history.’  In short, this is the way I would like to approach history in my own studies.

entry.title: Fascinating
entry.content:
I think that is how Mr. Spock would describe The Logics of History by William Sewell.  At least, I doubt he would use his other famous line, “illogical” to describe it.  I myself will have to read it again…and again before some of the ideas will sink in, maybe.  He caught me right out of the gate with the notion of how historians think about time and social interactions, or social temporality as he termed it. It’s fateful, contingent upon the sequence of events that are complex and historically contextual; they are a mix of continuity and change that happens chronologically.  I believe that’s the gist of it.   He then talks about a shift from social history to cultural history, which sounds like a good base for ethnohistory.  I will agree that culture is learned by the individual through the agency of the society, community, or group they are in, and through repeated exposure to a distinct set of symbols – uniforms in the military or wooden shoes in Holland.  Could we not say that academia has a culture all its own as well by employing this definition?
In chapter 8, he used the French Revolution and the storming of the Bastille as his base for defining historical events.  To me, it read as what makes an event historical.  Think back to 9/11 as an historical event.  Political and social structures, at least between Al Qaeda and the U.S. were dislocated.  There was a cultural transformation with symbolic interpretation; lots of songs, movies, and books. It was shaped by particular conditions.  There were definitely heightened emotions, and acts of collective action by emergency personnel and people on the street.  It was marked by the displaying of U.S. flags everywhere, and even the current military actions being taken are its legacy.  It changed the way we think of travel and how airports, amusement parks, and stadiums like Neyland, treat security.  The attacks may have been contained to a few places, but the action left a mark on the nation and spurred action just like the attack on Pearl Harbor, but I’m pretty sure a nuclear bomb is not in the Middle East’s future.  However, this section of the book offers us a good way to look at historical events.
Like I said, I’m going to have to re-read most of this, or as the old folks used to say; let it percolate for a while, before I can articulate better the ideas therein contained.  For now, this is will have to suffice.

entry.title: Historian's Theories and Social Scientific Dialogue
entry.content:
This is it. The last blog post for the class. Weird feeling, actually. Anyway, onto the book: William H. Sewell’s Logics of History.

I thought this was an excellent book to end the semester with. Sewell’s interdisciplinary work in the social sciences, and his premise of creating a two-way dialogue between historians, who spend more time incorporating outside theories than in propounding their own, and social sciences, who are theory-rich and involved but do not incorporate useful lessons from history. His initial explanation of the general theory that drives most historians was especially useful, because I, at least, do not think about theory as much as I evidently need to, and had not recognized that simply by thinking like a historian I was very much attached to a particular theoretical bent. It’s funny how that happens, isn’t it?

This theory of social temporality, as he puts it, is very interesting, and he spends considerable time explaining what he means by it in depth. In addition to the fatefulness/sequence of time, he adds the heterogeneity of time and cause as major aspects of the theory—time happens, and can never be recovered (a non-repeatable experiment, if you will), but just because time passes does not mean that it passes the same way in every place, that there are grand systems of human development that are universal, or that there are singular causes that drive all human societies at all times and places. What this leads to is the need to contextualize all things, because they are only meaningful within their own time, place, and culture.
This is very different from the kinds of universalist rules sought after by some of the social sciences. Do I even need to mention economics, and how they seem hell-bent on proving themselves wrong-headed? (Thanks for the recession, by the way). Sewell mostly advocates interacting with those disciplines in the social sciences that are already on a historical-cultural bent anyway, like anthropology. Actually, he really only mentions anthropology in his first section as a whole, though he mentions that dissident scholars within sociology and other social sciences, though clearly within the minority of their fields, would also be welcome in the dialogue. He points out the two major things that the social sciences can contribute: a use of structure that gets discarded by historians, and a willingness to tackle major issues, time spans, etc.

His second chapter, remarking on his own historical journey and the shift from social to cultural history, was interesting. Fairly useful, too. I tend not to use quantitative assessment in my own work, but I think it would be a good think to start looking into—social history’s use of data in that sense, to help build a more complete picture of the marginalized through numbers, would help in medieval history, where charters, legal documents, tax records, etc. still exist and can make up for the dearth of narrative sources, especially in the County of Tripoli, where I’m working. Shipping records, etc.? Might be very useful. Note to self.

My favorite sentence, dealing with the change from social to cultural history, and why I would like to know more about both, is on page 51: “If social history tended to privilege quantifiable data as uniquely objective, cultural history, at least in its post-structuralist modality, seemed to deny the possibility of access to any realities beyond the discursive structures present in the text.”

Now, I will admit that the first two chapters were the ones I found most useful and thought-provoking (I especially liked the areas commenting on French historiographic trends, if only because I am French). Chapters three and four I had a harder time with, not because of any inherent flaws on their part, really, but because I have no experience with sociology, at all. I understood the difference between eventful temporality and the other two he mentioned, and I understand the need for a good definition of structure (I’ve been that naïve student), but I had a hard time following past that, because I was really out of my element. I did not feel like this was a beginner’s guide to understanding sociology—sadly for me. His theory of structure may or may not have been excellent, I just don’t know enough to make the judgment.

When he turned to anthropology, I felt much more comfortable. Really, it mostly made me want to read Geertz and Sahlins in their original forms, which I never did (in my anthro. classes they were mentioned repeatedly, but I was a sophomore, so we didn’t really get in to the major texts). Having read Ethnohistory recently, I felt like a lot of what he was saying we’d discussed recently.

What I really got out of the book as a whole was the need for more interdisciplinary work, not just as a pillaging of theory from other disciplines, but actual work within in, dialogue with their practitioners, integration and assimilation when appropriate but also editing and criticism for the benefit of all groups. We’ve discussed interdisciplinarity in this class, and how it is useful for us but not yet within the cards job-wise; that needs to change. Sewell’s personal journey, teaching in a variety of departments and joint positions, shows it can be done where there is a will and funding, and I think it would benefit students and scholars in all fields to have that expand in the future.

entry.title: Reflections on Logics of History
entry.content:
History. Anthropology. Sociology. Can’t we all just get along?

William H. Sewell – in his 2005 work, subtitled Social Theory and Social Transformation – argues that social scientists and historians can and should not only respect one another’s work; they all have something to gain from an ongoing dialogue.

Historians get “social temporalities”; anthropologists get “the power and complexity of culture”; sociologists get “commitment to explanatory rigor” (p. ix). And while history has borrowed ideas from the social sciences, the reverse has not occurred with much regularity. Historians, Sewell says, “have lacked the confidence to become active participants in theoretical debates” (p. 6).

The author, based on the breadth of his self-described experience, certainly is qualified to diagnose and comment upon these dynamics. And for what it’s worth, based upon my exceedingly limited experience, his observations ring true.

For example, this semester we have spent considerable time discussing major theories of causation. Yet I have loosely inferred that theory (whether social or otherwise) is something several of my classmates have not previously dealt with extensively (whether as a matter of choice or curriculum). I certainly fit into that category. And to give a more specific example, as Sewell examines the notion of culture in Chapter 5, he invokes Saussure’s concept of semiotics – an idea I have studied, with limited results. It’s fascinating stuff, but difficult for me to wrap my mind around.

Sewell evidently has no such deficiencies. Because of his rich and varied background, he seems to know whereof he speaks. And so it is that the case he makes is not only compelling, but credible. As he presents various events and works as backdrops for possible theories of history, his is seen to be a truly well-reasoned stance.

(As a side note, I was especially intrigued by Sewell’s treatment of “history’s little accidents,” vis-a-vis Sahlins’ account of Captain Cook, in Chapter 7. There’s a great example of right place, right time becoming wrong place, wrong time. Similarly fascinating is Chapter 9’s look at the role contingency – as opposed to necessity – played in helping Marseille’s dockworker corporation attain and retain a position unusual among France’s 19th-century working class.)

Throughout this work, Sewell drops in countless salient points that serve to further fortify his standing. All in all, he lays out an impeccable case for “forms of structural thinking that are compatible with historical conceptions of temporality” (p. 15).

entry.title: Logics of History
entry.content:
This was a great book. It clarified and explained several terms I’ve run across elsewhere (discursive, cultural turn, etc) and gave an excellent grounding in some recent-ish theories and trends in history and the social sciences. It would have been nice to have read this earlier in the semester, actually.

William Sewell is an interdisciplinary scholar who works in history as well as several of the social sciences. As a die-hard generalist, I appreciated the breadth of his perspective and the way he connected disparate threads. I also noted a strong tendency toward favoring Both/And over Either/Or, which I also enjoyed. Sewell consistently provides several apparently contradictory conceptions, and then shows how they actually act together to reinforce each other. He does this, obviously, with history and the social sciences, but also with events and theories, symbols and materiality, synchronic and diachronic analyses, language metaphors and construction metaphors, and more. Accepting and integrating both is a great way to side-step conflict, and it gives you more tools in your toolbox as well.

This book was written over many years as individual essays that he gathered and revised for this publication. It’s easy to see his include-it-all position through the various angles and treatments in these individual works, but it would have been nice to have a bit more of a…hmm, “story arc”, I guess. I wish that chapter 10 had been more of a summary, consolidation, conclusion sort of end, instead of yet another discussion of contradictions that are actually complements. The book just stopped, instead of concluding with a distilled statement of the whole picture.

Until the abrupt and unsatisfying end, though, this book was full of great insights and ideas to think about. I liked the several places where Sewell suggested that one of the reasons we study history (or the social sciences) is to show why things happened then and thereby illuminate why things are happening now, to some extent or another. I liked the contingency and agency that kept recurring, especially in light of our depressing conversations about capitalism. He does a very good job of showing why it’s not as grimly inevitable as that Latin America/Africa book made it seem.

In fact, this book had so much great stuff in it, I had a harder than usual time finding the forest beyond all the interesting trees. I guess that’s part of my problem with the lack of conclusion. Here, then, is my stab at summarizing his ten essays:

Chapter one was an introduction of sorts, laying out his intention to combine the strengths of history and the strengths of social science. History is good at particulars, narrative, sequential chronology, and showing the lumpiness of change over time. The social sciences are better at big-picture generalities, theories and laws, regularities, continuities, and big scope. They each have something to offer the other that would improve both fields.

Chapter two was cast as an autobiography, to show what social history was, how it rapidly evolved to cultural history, and what was lost in the wholesale (well, “most-sale”, actually) transition. This resembled in many ways his chapter on the differences between social science and history just before. Again, he says we need to incorporate skills and interests from both in order to give thorough descriptions of our subjects.

Chapter three considers three temporalities—teleological (long-term, progressing toward a goal), experimental (slices of time to compare equivalent and independent events), and eventful (how events are able to transform social structures). He also discusses that time moves at three different rates—structural (centuries), conjunctual (decades), and eventful (“froth on the waves”)—so any good description needs to tease out different contexts and explain how they’re each contributing to the situation under consideration. He ended by sharing three examples of how the concept of enduring structures can be integrated with a history of events to show how events transform structures.

Chapter four looked more closely at these structures that social scientists are so fond of. They include both schemas and resources, and we live in many different structures, which overlap and interact in many ways. This multitude of structures is what allows human agency and creativity. Chapter five continued this look at our context for living, although here he called it culture. Culture is a collection of overlapping systems of symbols and meanings that people use and act within to live their lives. As they live those lives, their actions may alter the symbols and meanings that enabled the actions. Each culture encompasses many differences and has ways of organizing this variety to produce coherence.

Chapter six compared the strengths of history and anthropology, as well as how very similar they really are. Anthropology looks at humans across space, studying the differences possible within a still-human context in order to distill what it means to be human, and historians do somewhat the same thing only across time. Both of these fields show that a lot of what we take for granted is actually quite contingent. He also discussed how culture and large brains developed together, because brains give us more options and culture helps us choose between them in the absence of instinct. And he showed the slippage available between elements of culture that allow for change.

Chapter seven looked at Sahlins’ description of Cook’s arrival in Hawaii to show how events can change social structures. Events grow from and act within many kinds and scopes of structures, but slippage, change in resources, and human intentions can rearrange the symbols and their meanings and thereby transform the basic structures of interpretation.

Chapter eight did about the same thing for the original Bastille Day. After an extended description of the events, he analyzed them to show how an act of violence was absorbed and interpreted to become the novel concept of an initiation of political revolution. From this, he laid out an elaborate theory of events that incorporates structures, culture, conditions, emotions, creativity, ritual, event cascades, authoritative sanction, spatial elements, and arbitrary boundaries.

Chapter nine began with a very long description of the dockworkers in Marseilles in order to show how some structures can persist even when surrounded by changing circumstances. In the analysis that followed his long description, he showed how there were several temporalities and different sized structures operating, and then he explained how each one contributed to the persistence of their position, and their evolution from conservative to liberal politics. This was an example of the combination of historical narrative and social science analysis that he’s calling for throughout this book.

Chapter ten tried to define “social”. After an interesting etymology, he shared the language metaphor, some detractors, and how it can be stretched to answer their challenges. Then he showed the advantages of a mechanistic/quantitative analysis for when your data are obscure, sparse, or unwieldy in narrative form, and how these strategies can show the contingency behind what had previously seemed to be “blind forces”. Then he explored the social construction metaphor to show that we have more agency than we believe, and that materiality is as significant as symbology. He finished this chapter by saying that we need to incorporate both the language metaphor and the construction one in order to adequately perceive the society and culture we’re studying.

And then it was done.

As is this blog, so Philip—whoever you are—you can unfollow me now so I no longer feel like I’m being stalked.

entry.title: Thoughts on Archives and Digital History
entry.content:
• Dan Cohen and Roy Rosenzweig, Digital History: A Guide to Gathering, Preserving, and Presenting the Past on the Web.
  • Antoinette Burton, Archive Stories. Durham: Duke Univ. Press, 2005.

This week’s readings were of eternal practicality to my future.  Digital history was an interesting introduction into online historical writing. Though it presented itself as a how to manual it also openly states the limitations of digital history.  The cost and time that goes into creating and maintaining a website can often shadow the actual boundaries of a department or historian.  Also the manipulability and sometimes inaccessibility, side affects of the internet, are two major factors of skepticism which I retain for digital history.  One of the positive aspects to digital history, which I admittedly use everyday, are the online databases, run often by libraries from various campuses, which facilitate the ability to do research.

Concerning archive stories, this quote really spoke to me,

“We would not like to end on yet another trumphalist note, because we recognize that the telling of stories, like the production of history itself, has no intrinsically redemptive power, whether revolutionary or conformist.  Stories—in whatever narrative form—embed as many secretes and distortions as archives themselves; their telling encodes selective disclosures, half-truths and partial pasts no more or less than do histories ‘proper.’” Pg 20

Archive Stories caused me to rethink the infallibility of an Archive.  I, of course, understood that approaching the materials within an archive a historian should never take said documents at face value, but I failed to realize that the archives themselves are subject as well. The information they collect reflect what ever status quo their geopolitical locations deem.

This work also brought to my attention  the importance, uses and limitations of oral history, such as consistency and reliability, which I then realized are the same issues historians face with written history.  Now I do not mean to understate the fact that oral history has a large grain of salt to swallow… however it is one of those final frontier, as far I can tell, when Textual evidence leaves you in a bind.

entry.title: hist510-- digital and archives
entry.content:
I must admit that I was slightly nervous upon hearing of the subject of our readings this week; I did not necessarily expect bad things from these two titles, I was simply leery of the technological focus. As most people have figured out, technology is not one of my strong points and I worried my unfamiliarity with computers and whatnot might hamper my understanding of the author’s arguments. I was quite relieved, therefore, to discover that I had no problem following the readings. In fact, I had a much easier time with these books than several others we have read throughout the course and found myself even enjoying them at times, something I expected from Archival Stories but certainly not from A Digital History. Personally, I can say that these two books have been the most practically useful texts assigned. Numerous professors and colleagues have attempted to persuade me of the advantages to be gained by a more extensive use of technology, but none have done so with as much success as A Digital History. I also appreciated how Archive Stories illustrated the constructed nature of historical archives, dispelling the illusion of immutable truth-holding that surrounds popular conceptions archival collections.

Somewhat unexpectedly, A Digital History was my favorite of the two books assigned. I thought Cohen and Rosenaweig put admirable effort into persuading academics to partake more actively in the transition of historical document from paper to digital storage devices. The authors abstained from promoting an absolute opinion on either the usefulness of technology or its potential dangers, instead opting for a middle track that focused on how to maximize the advantages posed by technological developments while avoiding, or at least minimizing, some of the more detrimental effects. Some of the benefits the book advanced I had not previously considered, such as the manipulability of textual evidence – an idea that could entail something as simple as the ability to simultaneously compare, contrast and arrange evidence from a single location. The dangers of historical expansion onto the web are problems I am more familiar with, a result, I am sure, of the ultra-conservative beliefs espoused by my advisor as an undergraduate. 

To be clear, I acknowledge and appreciate how much easier online access to thousands of historical documents has made historical research. I certainly have benefitted from this development and I am sure my dependence will only grow with time. But I also agree with one of the primary dangers Cohen and Rosenzweig point out: the internet’s capacity to blur the boundary between professional and amateur work. I find the idea of amateur work functioning as historical truth inherently distasteful; although some claim historical credibility, the vast majority either regurgitate traditional interpretations or present ungrounded arguments. Because this material can be found on websites that somehow incorporate the word “history” or “historical,” words that apparently entail legitimacy in the eyes of the general public, “true” history remains in the background. On the other hand, I must admit that I am happy the general public is gaining at least some exposure to history. Since the expansion of history onto the web, public interest in the past had increased substantially and I simply cannot perceive this as a bad thing, despite the occasionally questionable nature of their information.

I am not sure what I expected from archive stories, but what I read was certainly not it. I suppose that I imagined a book focused the stories created in archives, a view the authors directly sought to challenge by addressing instead the way in which archives themselves are created. This collection of archival stories did an excellent job at this goal, collectively illustrating the numerous ways in which personal experience and the history of archives affects the narratives that emerge. Although the idea that archives are constructed seems logical once one thinks about it deliberately, it is not a consideration that would have remained at the forefront of my thoughts when doing archival research.  After reading this text however, similar to my mindset following our readings on objectivity, I will be much more conscious of archival flexibility. After all the complications we listed when discussion the quest for objectivity, Archival Stories seemed to add yet one more layer between “the truth” and historical interpretation. I also agreed with the argument for the influence of current pressures upon interpretations of the past, another factor that must be considered when constructing historical narratives. The idea that individuals exist under political and social pressure is nothing new, but I had not really considered the impact of such circumstances of institutions and documentary preservation, two elements crucial in the construction and maintenance of historical archives. This book, too, is a useful guide to policing my future endeavors to accurately and successfully pursue historical research.

entry.title: 11/21 Archives and Digital History
entry.content:
“Archive Stories” presented a number of different takes on the archive, beginning with personal experiences with using archives to the creation of them to their role in politics. Overall, I found the essays very interesting and thought-provoking; however, some of the ones in the middle section, such as the essays about the “suffragette spirit” and Kohler, WI, had the definite feel of having originally been written for another purpose and only superficially adapted, with an introduction and conclusion, to fit this collection. I was also struck by the interconnectedness of the essays. Almost all of them made multiple references to others in the collection, and I wondered how much a particular entry had been revised in relation to the others. I’ve had this thought before when reading essay/article collections, in which a brief mention will be made to another entry, but I had never encountered such interconnectedness before.

The different takes on the archive were quite interesting, and it was also nice to have oral archives included. Previously, I hadn’t given much thought to the archive as a thing, to its biography, as one of the authors stated. The archive was just the place where lovely, useful books and documents were stored. Instead, though, our work as historians is dependent upon years of archival selection: what is kept and made available based on interest, national goals, and from reading Robertson’s (somewhat whiny at times) essay, the whims of the archivists themselves. I had, of course, realized that archives did not contain entire documentary histories, but I hadn’t grasped the degree to which they were filtered, for lack of a better term.

I appreciated Digital History’s practical nature; it’s the type of thing that I’ve bookmarked to return to as a guide, for if I need/want to create a stronger digital presence in the future. While the author’s are aware of limits regarding the internet and digitizing materials, they make a strong argument for its benefits. Their discussion of copyright and fair use policy was equally helpful. As someone who has strong feelings about the glories of the printed page, I must admit to having reservations about going too far toward the internet. So many websites are not reputable (although, of course, with training, they can be spotted and avoiding, just as printed popular histories can be), and then there’s the question of the ephemeral nature of individual sites, discussed by Sentilles in her Archives Stories submission (I realize that one could also argue that paper is ephemeral, what with fire and the ease of shredding documents and throwing them away). Ultimately, I see the digital world as having distinct uses, and certainly some advantages in terms of easy communication and access to documents without travel expenses, but I don’t think it replaces print culture. At least, not yet.

entry.title: On Archive Stories and Digital History
entry.content:
Our readings for this week were Archive Stories: Facts, Fictions, and the Writing of History, and Digital History, A Guide to Gathering, Preserving and Presenting the Past on the Web.  The common thread I found in the collection of essays that make up Archive Stories, and the web publication of Digital History  are the common issues of legitimacy that crop up when historians use archives to perform their research.  Whether these archives are found via the internet, which holds millions of archives, created by individuals and professional organizations, or whether the archives are found in some dusty government repository in India or South Africa, problems exist as to how, by whom and why these archives were formed, what purpose they served then, and what purpose they serve now. 

As John Randolph points out in his chapter in Archive Stories, “The Bakunin Family Archive,” (209-232), the essential problem is one of control.  There is very little positive control over most of the content published on the internet.  There is also a lack of permanency to it as Renee Sentilles points out in the “Archives of Cyberspace.”  These are particular issues discussed in Digital History as well. According to the authors, one is left having to rely on the general concensus among historians on what is considered legitimate sourcing on the internet, like Early English Books Online, and what is considered ‘tertiary,’ like Wikipedia.  However, as Archive Stories points out, there are problems of legitimacy with the traditional archive as well. 

In contrast to the internet, many archives have issues with too much control over their content.  Barriers to archival research exist between historians and those who have political and cultural control over archives, such as the Bakunin Family Archive, or the Uzbekistan archives.  these archives serve as “contact points” (pg28) between archivists and historians that often spark debate over what versions of history may be viewed negatively by individuals with vested interests in maintaining, even moulding, the ideas the archives have come to represent.  According to our authors, many archives (especially national archives) represent ethereal monuments, and to tamper with them is to invite opposition from those who do not wish to see these monuments disassembled and rebuilt into unfamiliar and/or unwanted forms.

entry.title: Archives
entry.content:
The readings for this week discuss the historians experience working with archives, both the materials and the institution. Archive Stories is a collection of essays that each relate one historian’s experience when researching in an archive. It discusses discrimination and restricted access from archivists or government officials, gender discrimination, nationalism and national narratives, changing political regimes, the benefit of oral histories, the changing role of archives throughout history, etc. It is clear that archives are not neutral repositories of fact, but rather are organized, accessed, and preserved in necessarily limited ways. Thus our own work as historians needs to acknowledge not only the debt we owe to archival collections, but also the lens through which we work due to an archival filter before our own interpretation of the documents even begins(other than the fact that we have decided to look for them, thus bestowing some value onto them as potential sources.) The decision to keep particular documents through generations, and possibly changes in archival leadership, represents particular choices about the value of the document each time it is preserved( even if, in some cases, the author wrote “to be burned” in the margin.)

The keepers to these collections also make choices about individual scholars and projects, as certain projects may received more support and others may be left to flounder. Some information about sources is clouded even before it comes to the archive. We like to think there is certainty about all the sources we find, but even this cannot be assured, as some documents and artifacts come to archives in mysterious ways. During my internship at the Baseball Hall of Fame, I spoke with various curators who lamented the fact that some very interesting 3D artifacts were left at the front door with no further explanation. It takes highly trained people to narrow down the historical context of a unique item, but the story of the particular artifact itself can still not be known for sure.

Digital History: A Guide to Gathering, Preserving, and Presenting the Past on the Web, was an interesting supplement, as it continues the discussion of the role of archives and how they are formatted into the twentieth first century. Living in the information age, the possibility of (close to) a full record of events is closer than ever, and the capacity for storage of digital material is greater than would have been imagined even decades ago. However, digital records are not permanent, nor are they as unrestricted as some believe. In fact, sometimes I wonder if our quick ability to access such a broad swath of information makes us ultimately less curious about information not available on the web. Do we assume the world is really at our fingertips? I think there is some weight to both sides of the argument that the internet may be the new beginning and the end of investigative inquiry. The authors take a middle position and offer the pragmatic consideration that the internet is a tool and not the only one, which can be further sharpened and refined.

In addition, we are living in a time when anyone can post on the internet(and anyone does, including this student), so the credibility of sources comes under new scrutiny. We also may now be burdened with too much information, as “mastery” of relevant literature may now be impossible by older standards. Still, technology continues to develop, so some drawbacks of internet searching and publishing may yet be remedied. It also provides some exciting opportunities for historical records and scholarship, as evidenced by the September 11 case study. In the wake of that tragic event, hundreds of thousands of people posted their stories on the few sites mentioned in this book alone. Millions more have recorded and shared their perceptions and remembrances of the days event online. Thus, the historians of the future will have unprecedented depth from which to draw in writing their attempts at informed description and analysis of that generation-defining event. This is just one example; there are many others related the ability to share information around the world.

entry.title: Archives and Digital History
entry.content:
Burton, Archive Stories | Cohen & Rosenzweig, Digital History

This week’s selection of essays in Burton’s work really hammers home a very large point: that archives are not infallible. The archive is man-made entity and, as such, it is capable of as many faults as man. Because archives are created by imperfect men and states or other organizations, they are not perfect and the mechanisms for determining what documents are catalogued and preserved is highly political. For those with a background in public history, this is really nothing new. In the course of learning archival methodologies the door is opened for a brief glimpse into the very political world of accessioning and de-accessioning items or collections. From the historian’s perspective, however, it is always helpful to remember that the archive only holds those records which were purposefully placed within—it is not the complete record.

The first group of essays deals with the experiences of historians in various archives throughout the world from a first person point of view. Presented here are the many obstacles (both bureaucratic and procedural) that hampered and assisted as historians struggled to complete their researches. From this first handful of essays, it is clear that the archive is more than a repository of information: it is a living, breathing organism that is responsive to its own circumstances. The second set of essays tells the stories of the formation of various archives—from national repositories to archives in Kohler, Wisconsin that document architectural plans of sites that were never constructed. From this it is obvious that archives exist for more than one reason, as such they can provide us with more than one answer to those questions we seek to answer.

The final section presents the archive as current political force. The inclusion of particular items and the conscious exclusion of others represent a deliberate attempt to control the narratives of history. To be sure, none of the authors in this section are against highly critical and selective practices of accessioning items to archival collections; rather they assert that politics have too frequently been involved in the process to the detriment of certain historical traditions—particularly those of indigenous peoples and the lower classes. Oral histories are virtually nonexistent many western archives unless they are part of a specific research program.

As they presently exist, I think Burton would argue that archives are wholly inaccessible to most non-archivists and non-historians. Because the general public does not understand the fundamental contingency of the accessioning process, there is this belief that the archive is objective and presents the full record. Without question the archive does not present the full narrative of any line of research. Our sources are never innocent—they are products of their time and of their writer; so too are our archives. As historians we must be cognizant of these innate flaws in the archive and adjust our researches accordingly.

Without question, technology has greatly enhanced the research capabilities of modern historians; the internet connects us to various institutions and organizations to investigate their archival holdings; computers have decreased the time necessary to search a collection catalogue for particular items that may be of use; digital archives have made it unnecessary to physically visit an archive to perform research. The presence of digital and online archival resources such as the Valley of the Shadow Project (an online archive of documents pertaining to the Shenandoah Valley during the American Civil War) have made it possible for scholars and amateurs alike to gain first-hand knowledge of the sources that inform our interpretations.

To the extent that the authors want to make Digital History a guide book for preparing and organizing digital archives, they have succeeded. Their work is very practical and still quite applicable today. One area that I particularly liked was their discussion of copyright and fair use practices. Their very strict construction of copyright laws belies academia’s adherence to the published word. The biggest problem with fair use today is the fact that it so little understood by copyright holders, users of copyrighted material, and the general public.

The authors make a compelling case for the use of the internet as a research tool. Technology has democratized access to information and the ability to publish opinions and interpretations. To traditionalists, I think this is the biggest problem. The internet makes it much easier to spread junk history. The fair approach the authors take, however, makes it much easier to consider their argument. The internet holds great possibilities for historians, particularly as archives are digitized and made accessible via the internet.

entry.title: Reflections on 'Digital History' and 'Archive Stories'
entry.content:
Rather than wax philosophical, I’ll just say up front that I enjoyed these two books a great deal.

Daniel J. Cohen and Roy Rosenzweig’s “Digital History: A Guide to Gathering, Preserving, and Presenting the Past on the Web” is intended as a “practical handbook rather than a theoretical manifesto” (p. 13). To the extent that they focus on the general ins and out, the pros and cons, of the Web as a history tool, they succeed quite well.

The authors’ evenhanded tone does seem a bit odd as they discuss the phenomenon of “grassroots historians’” online handiwork. They seem rather indecisive regarding the level of trust that should be given Web sources. But their views on copyright law approach outright stridence.

Nevertheless, I rate this as a useful, and still timely, guide, as per the authors’ goals.

“Archive Stories,” meanwhile, is a treasure trove of diverse, but still widely relatable, tales pertaining to historians’ archiving efforts.

Standouts include:
• Ramirez’s “A Living Archive of Desire,” which highlighted the poignancy of a life that, at least at face value, is far removed from my own.
• Sentilles’ “Toiling in the Archives of Cyberspace,” which in several ways dovetails nicely with the Cohen and Rosenzweig book.
• Fritzsche’s “The Archive and the German Nation,” a fascinating look at one nation’s “absence of a common past and the enormous violence entailed in the attempts to produce it” (p. 204).
• Pohlandt-McCormick’s “Soweto in the Archives of South Africa,” a terrific recounting of the writer’s attempt to undo some of the damage done by a regime whose officials “erased the histories of their victims and contrived to create histories that denied their culpability” (p. 301).

“Documents are never innocent,” Pohlandt-McCormick writes (p. 316). And the same is no doubt true of the aforementioned accounts. But irrespective of their authors’ agendas, those works have great value, representing as they do once-lost threads now woven into history’s rich tapestry.

Who knew so many traditional archives began creating online digital versions almost from the inception of Al Gore’s internet. (Yes, I’m laughing) I remember when I first got a computer with a modem and internet connection.  My phone wouldn’t work while I was “online” and it took five minutes to get a single page, but it was from somewhere else in the world!  The job to get email and all that was on my windows desktop – the operating system had a massive 400 megabyte hard drive and weighed about 10 pounds not counting the monitor – was called Gopher, which I think was because it was developed at the home of the Golden Gophers of Minnesota.  Now, a scant fifteen years (has it been that long?) later, we surf the internet from our phones and wonder why it takes those interminable seconds for the webpage to load.  I am happy to see that there were archivists with the foresight to commence digitizing – I think it was called scanning back then – for future generations.  If you think about it, that was quite a smart move on their part to not only make it available but to preserve the manuscripts.  Instead of countless oily, salty, acidic fingers destroying the pages, unless gloves were used, then there is still the wear and tear on the old and brittle pages.  Untold numbers can now turn the pages with a simple mouse click.  Few need to actually examine the pages for their research, so this has greatly increased the ability of scholars to be more thorough in their work, which means more is expected of modern graduate students.  I can state from experience how much I prefer going over digitized and scanned records on my laptop as opposed to hours in front of the microfilm machine looking a government records – and I can’t wait for them to digitize those rolls of microfilm to make searching the records easier.

On virtual museums – yes, they are nice.  However, one can look at the pieces from the world trade center in an online museum, but when you are standing in a physical museum, staring at one of the girders that have been twisted like a plastic straw; it has the power to move you on such a deeper level.  Also, I’ve seen pictures of the Alamo, but when you are there, inside in the still quiet looking at the bullet pits in the walls, it brings you face-to-face with the sacrifices that were made.

I’ve created websites since about 1998 both for myself and for church youth groups, so I’ve been through much of what this book recommends.  I’ve also scanned into .pdf format several journals and books that I use in writing papers.  I did this for ease of access back in 2001 for a research paper.  Yes, I would prefer digitized, searchable format but all I had to work with then was my personal flatbed scanner and Adobe acrobat, which would group the scanned images into pages.  We have a better version of this now in Hodges library.

I believe though that no matter how advanced digitalization gets there is still something magical about words on dusty pages that inspires historians the world over to brave all troubles and obstacles to turn those pages.

entry.title: Access and Repositories...
entry.content:
Archive Stories, edited by Antoinette Burton promised to give us an inside look at not only the creation of archives, but their maintenance, protection, and access.  Just the name, archives, conjures up for me images of rows of books on shelves with those rolling ladders to access them; the hidden finds that await the turn of a musty page inside a dusty book.  Thrilling just to think about it isn’t it?  However, these were not those stories. Von Ranke is not hunched over a giant book in these.  Rather, it is the real archives that we as historians may face regardless of our specialty.  I found the information contained in this book enlightening.  It introduced ideas about how to deal with archivists we may encounter at the various repositories.  Who would have thought that simple items like melons (57) that we think little of would be the key to getting more information and access from the gatekeepers of the archives?  I can see how others would want to protect certain information from becoming public as it would force questions they did not want to ask and answers which they did not want to seek.  Many people like their version of history as it is; boiled down to a working definition of what their people believe.  Ghosh exposed the ways archivist protect their warehouse of knowledge.  It also hinted that the archivists knew the information she was after was in their charge and were very unwilling to give it up.  I am glad that, instead of destroying information they did not like, as did the Spanish with the Mayan codices, they acknowledge their historical value and tried to protect them with cajoling and condescension until they had to give up the information.  This was also what the archivists did in the Praslin case; refusing to turn over historic documents knowing they were to be destroyed. 
I love to see that oral histories are beginning to see acceptance, as in the court case in British Columbia.  With legal precedent set, I wonder how this will affect the view many now hold on such archives.  And what about the living archive in the Terasita la Campesina story?  I would hope that the author recorded some of the information she seemed to freely give as it would provide different perspectives on gender and sexuality that ones like Butler, Scott, and Bennett may find useful in their arguments.
Turning now to the U.S. of A.; it is amazing how many hoops you have to jump through to get at information.  I understand the problems with personal information and ID theft, the need for redaction of information provided, and the need to keep that information secure.  However, I wonder if the director decided to write his own history of the passport after he heard the author’s desire to do the same.  And having the power to prevent access to the information until his was complete, the foot-dragging began.  It makes you wonder if, in having to spell out what, when, where, and why you want/need information from the US government only leaves you open to having your ideas co-opted by the very officials in charge of helping you.  I know, conspiracy theorist love this stuff but it’s still interesting.

I want to close with this thought about the importance of archivists. Most have probably seen the Lord of the Rings Trilogy.  Remember when Gandalf told Frodo to keep the ring safe and secure, then left to consult some information?  Did anyone catch that while he was reading all those dusty books there was an archivists bringing them to him.  How about that?  A middle earth archive with a reading room and an archivist – nice touch of realism since some would have simply had him grabbing books off the shelf and thumbing through them.

entry.title: Archive Stories and Digital History
entry.content:
Ahhhh… familiar ground!

This book, Archive Stories, presents fifteen essays around the theme of archives. Part 1 is primarily about users’ experiences, Part 2 is primarily about the development of some particular archives, and Part 3 is primarily about the political ramifications of popular perceptions of archives and their objectivity. I say primarily because most of the essays in each Part touch on the other two emphases as well.

The overall point that comes through all of these stories is that archives are not repositories of objective facts that can be used to establish a single, irrefutable truth. In their selection, organization, accessibility, and limits, archives themselves are subjective, even before users begin to interpret their artifacts. This inherent subjectivity needs to be explained more clearly because the evidence in archives—primarily of the written variety—is being put on a pedestal and given authority that can then be used to perpetuate unfair power relationships.

I loved the stories in this book, even when I wanted to argue with their interpretations. The authors gave little snippets of their own research as context for the points they were making, so I got to visit India, Uzbekistan, New Zealand, San Francisco, the Civil War, France, Germany, Russia, Edwardian England, Wisconsin, Egypt, Soweto, British Columbia, and Australia, each with a chatty and thoughtful guide and an archive perspective.

There were, however, several times I wished that the archivists could have contributed their sides of the stories. Schadeo interpreted inadequate finding aids as deliberate attempts to exclude researchers. Robertson was downright whiny about being denied access to people’s private information. And Milligan seemed almost to ridicule the requirements for specificity in document requests. Each of these situations has a legitimate reason behind it—archivists (as a rule) don’t hoard their collections to thwart researchers; they do the best they can within the limitations of time, space, and budget. They also have excellent stories about the quirks of their patrons, which professional ethics require them to never share, unfortunately.

The concept of archive was interpreted quite fluidly throughout. Robertson said it was a procedure, not an institution, and gave a great etymology of the word. Ramirez used it for the single collection of one person’s oral history. Sentilles said the internet both is an archive and contains archives. Milligan sees them as a synecdoche of the state/citizen relationship. Fritzsche says, “Every soul possesses an archive…” (184) Mayhall shows a human body being used as an archive. Booth presents novels as archives of an alternate view of history. She also uses the term in ways that I couldn’t figure out, as does Perry.

I had dozens of thoughts as I read these essays (and kept track of the times they mentioned “power”, “foregrounding”, and “Foucault”) but my biggest question is about how these collections of essays get put together into a book. Every single essay very self-consciously refers to others in the collection, so apparently they all had each other’s as they were writing. But in responding to those others’, they changed their own, so the other authors then had old versions. This process is a lot more interactive than I’d previously realized, and I wonder if that’s a new thing because of the capabilities of the internet.

Which brings me to the other book:

I was initially proud of myself for remembering the second, electronic reading for the week, but this smugness dissipated quickly when I realized it was an entire book instead of an article. I don’t like having to read from a screen, so I was regretting not having paid for a paper version. As I got into it, though, dismay made way for growing appreciation for the advantages of an electronic format (that disturbance in the force you feel is my husband’s glee at this statement—he’s been dragging me, shrieking and spitting—into the 21st century for years). I liked the footnotes that you can click on, and the expanding table of contents. I liked that I could scroll through each section without having to wait for new pages to load, but that each section was on its own so the blue button wasn’t excessively sensitive. The lack of page numbers was a little disconcerting, though—how do you cite a quote from this? And, for my second-ever attempt to type my reading notes, it proved to be much more wieldy than the paper book that refused to stay open.

Format aside, the content and writing style were fantastic. The authors include information that I’ve wondered about for a long time, in a non-threatening and succinct way. They note the downsides of electronic publishing as well as the benefits (like Sentilles in the other book). They organized the information clearly and they explain it gently, as though they realize that humanities people are less likely to jump into technology than their geeky spouses. If I ever want to go digital, this book will absolutely be my primary resource for doing so.

I particularly liked the section of Fair Use, which has always seemed vague and intimidating. They did a good job of showing why it seems vague, and then provided a nice little pep talk for why we should be more courageous in using and sharing other people’s work. I’d never thought about the interpretation of a law evolving in response to people’s assumptions, but I can see how this is real.

The Final Thoughts seemed to be written just for me, with comments about being deliberative and tentative and perfectionist. By respecting my reality, they make it easier for me to consider theirs. I never expected to enjoy a computer book, but this one—even read from a screen—was wonderful. I’m even thinking of parting with cash in order to have it in paper. And yes, I do see the irony in that instinct. It just seems more real (and less ephemeral, by the way) if I can hold it and scribble in the margins. Just because I’m coming to appreciate the advantages of computers doesn’t mean I don’t still see the advantages of paper.

entry.title: Pondering the Archives
entry.content:
The collection Archive Stories: Facts, Fictions and the Writing of History, edited by Antoinette Burton, is a gem of a text certain to enthrall students and historians alike, ignite the flames of interest in the lay person, and, one hopes, provoke a new generation to delve into the archives. The fifteen essays contained within take the reading on a whirlwind geographical tour, dealing with archives from Paris to Uzbekistan, British Columbia to South Africa, and cross the modern period, from archival foundations in 19th century Europe to modern court cases in late 20th century British Columbia, and everywhere in between. The wide, friendly scope of this work gives it an accessibility and sweep that do not detract from its central argument: archives are constructs and historical documents in their own write, and as such have to be treated as an object of history no less than as a historical resource.

Archive Stories is divided into three larger units, introduced by a short essay from Burton. Burton’s introduction brings to the forefront the need for archive stories, “narratives about how archives are created, drawn upon, and experienced by those who use them to write history,” as part of a greater program to change the perception of the archive as a static bastion of objective fact. As she points out, this is not a new concept; Jorge Canizares-Esguerra, whose work How to Write the History of the New World is repeatedly mentioned throughout the essays in the book, does a superb job demonstrating the multifaceted process that goes into constructing an archive, both in the political sphere and the historical one. After briefly describing the coming essays, Burton ends her introduction with a reminder of the need for a “de-bunking” of the notion that the archive encapsulates the means to determine Truth; a problem made clear as “the fetish of the archive as a surveillance apparatus has been matched in recent years by the fantasy that history is or can be a delivery system for absolute truth.”

The first section, entitled “Close Encounters: The Archive as Contact Zone,” could just have easily been named “Stories in Archives,” as the section deals with the personal experience of six historians in various archives across the world. This is by far the most fun section of the book, as professional historians give details of their interactions with archives themselves, the archivists, foreign cultures and bureaucracies, idiosyncrasies in protocol, and myriad other obstacles, aids, and adventures in their endeavors. The overarching narrative of these six works is that archives are clearly not storehouses for objective fact, but living entities that change and mutate due to sociopolitical circumstances of the nation around them.

The first essay in the text, Durba Ghosh’s “National Narratives and the Politics of Miscegenation: Britain and India,” does an exemplary job of pointing out the politics of archival work. Ghosh experienced two extremely different responses to her work on miscegenation between British colonial men and Indian women, and the responses form a backdrop to a larger challenge of archive work. In Britain, her project was well-received, with librarians, archivists, and scholars leaping to tell her their own connections to the project; they used their personal experiences of family members marrying Indian women as a marker of a greater cosmopolitan identity. This willingness on the part of the people was met, however, with silence from the archives, which had deliberately left out records of the native women. In India, the position was even worse, with “many archivists and librarians den[ying] that native women became sexually involved with European men,” and further absences in the archives. Ghosh ended up having to work from tangential evidence, and even novels, in order to garner evidence of something that was known and acknowledged to have happened. Archives, through their absences as much as their collections, shape history in ways that are defined by social, cultural and political motivations.

The other five essays reinforce this point. Jeff Sahadeo’s essay “Without the Past there is no Future: Archives, History, and Authority in Uzbekistan,” looks at the archives from a political context, where repressive regimes in Uzbekistan have used the archival materials, and denial to them, as a means of political control and creation of legitimacy. In the process, he also takes a look at the very different living and working conditions faced by non-Western archivists and scholars in countries where history is a weapon used by the state, and where the economy cannot support historians in the manner customary in the West. Craig Robertson’s and Tony Ballantine’s essays continue on this trend, looking at exclusion from the archives, personal politics, and disused sources. These essays give useful tips for how to deal with archival work on a political level, but also on the neglect of certain sources from an academic standpoint, and how this can affect their future use.

The last two essays in the first section, while still dealing with the research of individual scholars, look beyond the traditional vision of the archive to delve into oral history and cyberspace. Horacio N. Roque Ramirez’s essay “A Living Archive of Desire: Teresita la Campesina and the Embodiment of Queer Latino Community Histories,” is not as effective of a work as many of the others, dealing with oral history archives in the form of one woman’s life story, memories, and personal narrative. The main idea, of oral history being like an archive, and one that can and should be read as such, is perfectly valid, but by only using a single person as an archive, it is not as powerful as marker of the use of oral archives as Adele Perry’s “The Colonial Archive on Trial: Possession, Dispossession, and History in Delgamuukw v. British Columbia,” in the third section of the book. Perry’s text also looks at oral history archives, but looks at a much larger scale, and in more depth the system of organization, remembrance, and use in a cultural context. Ramirez’s essay is still an interesting look into Latino queer culture, and this particular personage’s narrative, but as an exploration into oral archives, it falls a little flat.

The final essay, Renee Sentilles’s “Toiling in the Archives of Cyberspace,” is an especially useful piece, looking at the internet as an archive and how that reshapes traditional notions of scholarship. Perhaps the most useful question she raises is the idea of permanence when it comes to Internet sources; in her own research, talking about some four hundred websites which disappeared in a single year, she writes “I cannot find them; it is as if they never existed, yet I documented them in an earlier essay. Given traditional reasons for why we note source material (the reader must always be able to go back and review the information source), was my previous Internet research valid?” This essay is one of the most useful and thought-provoking in the book, pointing out both the need to use the Internet, its potential applications, and its incredible expansion of scholarship (both good and bad), as well as the ways in which it will transform current modes of citation and archival thought.

The second section of the book, titled “States of the Art: ‘Official’ Archives and Counter-Histories,” is easily thought of as “Stories of Archives.” The six essays in this section look at archives and their history/construction, rather than taking the view of an individual researcher and their archival experience. The first two, Jennifer Milligan’s “‘What is an Archive?’ in the History of Modern France” and Peter Fritzsche’s “The Archive and the Case of the German Nation,” look at the construction of national archives in France and Germany and the political implications of both their construction and usage. These are fairly standard pieces, useful and informative, but hardly groundbreaking—national archives exist for specific reasons, and tell specific narratives about the nation and their creators. The third essay, John Randolph’s “On the Biography of the Bakunin Family Archive,” follows a similar vein, though it is innovative enough in its idea of taking the genre of biography to the archive as a means of constructing identity.

The second part of this section steps outside of these more traditional ways of examining archives to look at archives outside the usual spectrum. Laura Mayhall’s essay “Creating the ‘Suffragette Spirit’: British Feminism and the Historical Imagination” examines how archives can create a fiction where one particular facet of society, a movement, a life, whatever is emphasized to the point of being the sole reality available in the archive, a cautionary tale to researchers not to assume archives represent the full truth. Kathryn Oberdeck’s essay, “Archives of the Unbuilt Environment: Documents and Discourses of Imagined Space in Twentieth-Century Kohler, Wisconsin,” goes even further to examine the archives of a city that only partially exists, looking at architectural designs and urban plans that never came into fruition. This essay was, in my mind, possibly the most useful in the entire book—the archives of Kohler are filled with documents concerning places that never existed off paper; documents do not necessarily correlate with material reality, and the objectivist notions attached to archives in the popular mind are therefore even more dangerous than sometimes imagined. Marilyn Booth’s essay, the final one in this section, examines the archive of fiction writing and how it can relate to history. On the heels of Oberdeck’s work, it helps to show the point that material reality is not the sole judge of the use of an archive—the never-realized plans, the fiction novels of a Lebanese feminist, both tell a great deal about the world they were constructed in.

The final section of the book, “Archive Matters: The Past in the Present,” is really a series of “Stories by Archives.” The three essays at the end examine the effect archives have upon the present, mostly in the political arena. Helena Pohlandt-McCormick focuses on South African archives of the Soweto Uprising, Adele Perry on the Delgamuukw v. British Columbia legal case, and Ann Curthoys on the eradication of the Tasmanian Aborigines, but all three are merely looking at facets of the greater problem of what archives say to the present day. Pohlandt-McCormick shows the systematic obfuscation of the truth in apartheid South African archives, the selective inclusion of sources in order to render a particular verdict to future generations, as well as the deliberate destruction of files deemed incriminating.
