Perry looks at how Western scholars privilege the written archive, ignoring the oral archives of the First Nations to the detriment of those of non-European descent, something explored thoroughly in Canizares-Esguerra’s book which she references. Curthoys look at the historiographical debate over the fate of the Tasmanians, and how various readings of the archives from particular political agendas can give widely different views.

The importance of this final section ties the entire book together. The first two sections raise important questions about the nature of archives, their use, their origins, etc., but it is only in the third section, where the flaws of common understandings of archives are displayed in a very real, very political sphere, that the scope of this book becomes clear. Burton has created a collection that urges a redefining of the archive, not only on the level of what constitutes an archive, but in the thought-process behind archival work. Archives can no longer be considered repositories of facts, but need to be seen for the constructs they are, historical artifacts in their own right to be interpreted by historians. Only when this has occurred can they be properly used, not just by historians, but by politicians and the public.

entry.title: Thoughts on Feminism II
entry.content:
thoughts on The Sexual Contract

I found it enlightening to be informed on contract theory, as a whole.  The victory that social contract theory had over Patriarchy was only due to a rigid, literalist interpretation of Patriarchy, that which views all of the arrangements in a civil society around the Father, however they failed to view what Pateman calls the Sexual contract, the contract between a man and a woman within a society, that still guarantees the man dominance over the woman, another Patriarchy.

According to Pateman the Social contract excludes women and creates a men only society. When she examined the economic opportunities for women, the glass ceiling is keeping women out of the capitalist system, even when women attain entrance into the capitalist system, they never achieve the status of capitalist, only as wage laborers or wage slaves in positions deemed “feminine”.

She compared the slave contract and sexual contract and argued for their horrendous similarity in their one-sidedness, and here is where I take issue with her.  The slave contract has a violence factor that the sexual contract does not have.  I feel like her comparison is deeply exaggerated.  She argued for their similarities in law… but the truth is that a slave had a vastly different experience than that of a wife.  The slave was subject to oppression in ways that the wife could not claim.

thoughts on Gender Trouble

“The task of this inquiry is to center on—and decenter—such defining institutions: phallogocentrism and compulsory heterosexuality.”  (Pg xxix)  What Butler is referring to here is not only questioning the centralization of feminist study on the woman, but more specifically the sexual orientation and its assumption of heterosexuality within the school of Feminism.  Butler is bringing into light queer theory.  I found this more enlightening than something to argue against, it brings to light the failure of assumption.

entry.title: Pateman's The Sexual Contract
entry.content:
Carol Pateman, in The Sexual Contract, tries to argue that women are largely ignored in the idea of  the social contract, noting that despite its inherent emphasis on free will, it still has served to uphold a patriarchal society. Here, to me, is an example of a book that is far more interesting than it’s own thesis. Her reviews and discussion of the interaction between Patriarchy, paternalism, and the nature of the social contract are really well done and engaging; however,she manages–and perhaps this is simply a function of her writing style, because logically she makes the connection– to muddle these together almost at random, interjecting contract theory into discussions of other phenomena causing it to seem like she has to strain to make the connections between the various thoughts and her thesis. She also is forced to say some rediculus things: arguing, for example, that if someone looks for patriarchy they will find it (the last paragraph of the second chapter). However, her thesis is clear and i think generally proven here. She also handles a lot of thinkers from different eras deftly and is able to glean out what she finds useful and more often than not argue away what isn’t.

The hardest part of reading this book was context;  I was not sure how revolutionary many of her arguments are simply because I don’t know, for example, to what extent the marriage function of the term “patriarchy” had been lost prior to her writing it. I have a hunch my impression of some of the terms she attempts to define are impression formed after her period; many of her writings, then, loose their initial implication and now seem to be arguments against phantoms.

I do hope that  my reviews of this book are not seemed too negative; I did enjoy it and though it was an interesting and well developed take. I am just not sure either where it fits in to feminist theory or just how connected all of these critical approaches are to one another and weather or not contract theory is ocean to which all the rivers flow. The negative, than, is precisely that: a reflection of my ignorance.

entry.title: Gender Troubles...
entry.content:
As I began the preface, I realized this would probably be a confusing book for me.  Philosophical works are barely on the main deck, let alone in my wheelhouse.  With that said, here goes.  Upon reading the 1990 preface, I came to only one conclusion; she may have been using English, but it wasn’t any English I understood. “As a strategy to denaturalize and resignify bodily categories, I describe and propose a set of parodic practices based in a performative theory of gender acts that disrupt the categories of the body, sex, gender, and sexuality and occasion their subversive resignification and proliferation beyond the binary frame.” I have no idea what this means.  Maybe if I read it a few more times it will start to make sense.
Her 1999 preface made more sense; at least I understood it better.  Maybe that is why she wrote it.  She said the book was rooted in “French Theory” with some feminist theory thrown in for good measure, so I was prepared for another round of the man-haters club.  However, she was on a separate course.  She wants her lifestyle choices to be accepted by all. (xix) This sounds a little hedonistic to me, but it would seem she had a rough go of it early and that made her a little mad at the world and this was her venting session.  I can understand that.
As she begins, we learn that “woman” and “gender” are political constructs that limit what a person actually is.  She says the definition of ‘women’ has been harder to redefine that ‘patriarchy’. (7)  She asserts that “gender is culturally constructed: hence, gender is neither the causal result of sex nor as seemingly fixed as sex.” (9-10) She speaks about Monique Wittig and the desire to use “person” to remove gender and the baggage that comes with it.  This would seem a good idea.  Think about it, does the phrase, “That is one happy kid,” seem more open to interpretation than, “That is one happy boy?”  By using a tag, boy/girl, the connotation of the statement is altered. 
As Butler is talking about Douglas’ ideas about how bodies are inscribed by our culture to designate them male and female, it got me to thinking about how they are inscribed. I was expecting thoughts on tattoos, piercings, head shavings, and the like.  I found none of that.  However, I would have thought she would have pulled tattoos into the mix.  Wasn’t this a common male custom, especially sailors?  Now, I’ve seen women with tattoos on their chest at Belk in Knoxville – it’s a little weird.  It would seem this would fall under gender questioning wouldn’t it?  To address the elephant… it’s weird because I’m a little old fashioned.  Discreet tattoos on females may be okay.  Unless you’re a sailor or a member of a tribe, that really cool tattoo is going to look funny when you’re 75.  A few piercings may be cool, but if refrigerator magnets stick to your face, or anywhere else, that may be a bit too much.
In the words of Chief Ten Bears, “That is all I have to say.”

entry.title: Reflections on 'The Sexual Contract' and 'Gender Trouble'
entry.content:
Were male-female relations still in a comparatively primitive state 22 years ago? Was Carole Pateman then entirely too inclined to see everywhere the legacy of an unenlightened past? Or am I now too naïve to see pervasiveness thereof?

In “The Sexual Contract” (1988), Pateman does an excellent job critiquing contract theory – in particular many of its inherent inequities and contradictions. Particularly fascinating are her citations of the tortured logic that was used to justify slavery and women’s exclusion from society’s functionings.

In short, from a social standpoint, her position is eminently sensible. It’s a well-reasoned explanation for what I understand or have seen firsthand of gender relations among those of pre-baby boom generations.

And yet …

At the risk sounding like an apologist and/or a simpleton who feels we’ve attained the best of all possible worlds (no need to elaborate on the myriad well-known ways we still fall short), I – a 40-year-old male – don’t believe present-day situation is quite as bleak as the one Pateman outlines.

The dynamics between men and women at large probably are in some ways apt to bear vestiges of the old, exclusively male-authored contract. But among married couples my own age, for example, I see very little that resembles the unilateral subordination that Pateman depicts; nor do I see even an expectation thereof. (I should add, I’m not qualified to comment on any evolution of attitudes toward prostitution.) So there’s that, for whatever it’s worth.

As for Judith Butler’s “Gender Trouble” (1989), I found particularly intriguing her assertion that “only the feminine gender is marked … the universal person and the masculine gender are conflated, thereby defining women in terms of their sex and extolling men as the bearers of a body-transcendent universal personhood.” (pp. 13-14)

Such a sentiment is cause to ponder the English language’s annoying (but supposedly innocuous) lack of gender-neutral pronouns – an absence that traditionally has rendered male pronouns the default setting.

And then, specific to our university, there’s the practice of referring to our women’s athletic teams as the Lady Vols (as distinct from the male just-plain Vols). How might that be explained, and is it a sign of progress that such nomenclature is now rather quaint?

entry.title: Sexual Contract
entry.content:
The Sexual Contract by Carole Pateman examines the historical subjugation of women as a necessary part of social contract history. She argues that patriarchy was not overthrown by the shift to representative government, but rather that it has taken on a new modern form. Pateman argues that despite some problems inherent in the term “patriarchy,” it still best describes the multifaceted social control that males have over females. She evaluates many contract theorists and argues that their perceptions of women are crucial for fully understanding their contract theories. Women are conspicuously absent in many historical accounts of social contract theory, but Pateman makes clear that they are not ignored by the traditional theorists, nor are they treated neutrally. With the exception of Hobbes, all traditional theorists believe women to be innately inferior to men, and as such are not fit for citizenship. Women cannot be “individuals” in the same way as men. Pateman cleverly points out the contradiction in this argument, however, as women are expected to engage in marriage contracts and contracts can only be legitimized between two consenting individuals. She also makes a few interesting comparisons to slave contracts(also inherently contradictory) and marriage, in that both result in civil death and the loss of one’s autonomy over one’s own body.

Where the book seems to falter, in my mind, is the periodic victimization of the women discussed within the book. While Pateman argues at the beginning that women should not be viewed as passive victims of a corrupt system, her language obscures this fact at later points in the book. In her articulation of male sex-right over his wife, a fully legitimate example of male dominance, she seems to deny that females also have a desire to engage with their partner sexually. The marriage is not complete until it is consummated, she interprets as male sex-right, though it could just as easily be interpreted as a mutual sexual act, releasing both spouses from social restraints against premarital sex. She also omits the religious significance of the act as two bodies becoming one, a belief she seems to deride as a facade for male lust in other parts of the book, in favor of a Freudian interpretation. She does seem to forestall some of this criticism by insisting that while many couples are not oppressive, the institution itself cannot be separated from its inherent subjugation of women. Still, she seems to imply that the sexual appetite of the wife will never be satisfied to the extent of the husband, a statement that would need more evidentiary support.

Elsewhere, she makes the case for despotic authority more persuasively. Women are forced into marriage by societal expectations and economic restrictions and then surrender their labor power, personhood, and sexual capacities- this part of the argument is well supported. Though sometimes couched in dismal language, she remains convincing that this grim portrayal is warranted by the experience of many married women, and more importantly, by the capability of all married men to become tyrants(whether or not they would, personally).

entry.title: hist510 Gender Again
entry.content:
This week, I was not pleasantly surprised upon completion of The Sexual Contract. Fortunately, I was not disappointed either and the book managed to satisfy my somewhat higher expectations following the discussion last Monday. Although I enjoyed many of the ideas put forth in this book as well as Pateman’s use of gender theory, I found some parts rather difficult to get through.  Pateman’s deep familiarity with contract theory, a knowledge I do not particularly share, also hindered my attempts to fully understand her arguments.

From the start, The Sexual Contract grasped my attention.  Although I have had some exposure to the original contract, I must admit that prior to reading this book I was guilty of many of the misconceptions Pateman critiqued.  According to Pateman, the story of the original contract has not been fully explained because a critical component of this contract, the sexual part, has been ignored. The original contract’s social role has been well examined, but its role as a modern form of patriarchy remains something of a mystery.  I greatly appreciated Pateman’s constriction of her patriarchal examination to a specific form of patriarchy as it emerged in the modern world. In addition, Pateman acknowledged that women’s positions have varied greatly across time and geographical distances. Our discussion of Bennett’s book last week left me leery of attempts to generalize gendered structures too broadly. I also enjoyed Pateman’s argument that political right originates as patriarchal right. I have never considered the original contract as the means by which pre-modern patriarchal right was transmuted to political right and new form of patriarchy, but this argument was quite persuasive for me. I was, however, slightly hesitant of Pateman’s suggestion that the original contract was established only as a way to subjugate the female sex. I would not deny that this motivation factored into the decision to contract, but I disagree with the extent to which she pushes this argument.

For me, the most interesting part of The Sexual Contract was the discussion of patriarchy. It was interesting to see Pateman’s argument for the incorporation of patriarchy into historical study following Bennett’s last week.  Pateman disagrees with the idea that patriarchy declines as a viable form of political power in the last couple of centuries. Instead, patriarchy is still a dominant influence that affects not only the household but politics and the economy as well. I must admit I was not completely enthralled by her long discussion of the theoretical confusions surrounding patriarchy, but I admit the usefulness of such a survey.  Perhaps my favorite part of the patriarchy argument is her assertion that patriarchy is a social invention. Pateman delves briefly into biology and theories on man in the state of nature, particularly Hobbes, to establish a father’s disassociation from his child. According to Pateman men have no natural right over women or children; in fact, maternal right ruled in the state of nature because it was the mother who bore the child. After inception, the father no longer played a role and had no direct link to the child. Barring a natural foundation then, the idea of patriarchy must be a human invention. The patriarchal powers of fatherhood have an entirely different social meaning than those of motherhood. Although Pateman refers frequently to the invention of patriarchy, I was disappointed not to see a discussion of how such a power construction emerged. Of course, such a task is likely too large for this book but I would enjoy a study explaining this phenomenon. 

Overall, the sexual contract was one of my favorite books this semester. I thoroughly enjoyed reading a more concrete application of theoretical ideas rather than a pure study of theory. I have also been surprised at the level of appreciation for women’s studies the last two week’s readings have instilled in me. Women’s studies have never figured largely into my historical perspective, but that has already started to change as these reading have diverted my attention to the pervasiveness of such factors. Although gender studies are valuable in their own right, I find even more useful the application of such theories as a means of shedding additional light on other areas of history traditionally devoid of such considerations.

entry.title: 11/15 Pateman and Butler
entry.content:
Pateman’s “Sexual Contract” argues that there is an implicit, often overlooked and hidden, sexual component to the Enlightenment social contract theory. She argues that “patriarchy” is often understood to involve a parental relationship; its strict male/female meaning generally neglected As such, she seems to predate Bennett’s argument from last week that “patriarchy” should make a comeback in discussions of gender and feminism. In the modern era, Pateman presents a rather bleak picture of male oppression of women, arguing that although women in the Anglo countries she studies have reached a level of judicial equality, they are still secondary to men in marital relationships and in the question of prostitution. I did notice that the studies she cites to support her arguments about the views of wage-earning married women were published in the early 1980s, with data likely gathered from the late 1970s; I questioned how dependent she should be on their findings nearly ten years later. Her use of Freud was surprising; she acknowledges that he is not normally used in discussions of social contract theory, and I was often unclear as to whether she was applying his views about fraternity and sons displacing the fathers to the late twentieth century or not (her love of the historical present and her often sloppy use of the word “contemporary” didn’t help). Many psychologists now dismiss the details of Freud’s theories, and so I questioned how relevant they were to Pateman’s argument.

Butler analyzes the idea of compulsory heterosexuality in her attempts to re-examine the construction of gender and its interplay with sex. Throughout, she points out flaws in and deconstructs previous theorists’ work. I was surprised not to find a discussion of Scott’s article (unless I overlooked it). In the process of taking apart so many other theories, I somewhat lost track of what Butler was proposing. I think she is advocating for defining gender as a performance. Wittig’s view, discussed in the last chapter, that not only gender, but also sex, is constructed was interesting; I hadn’t previously run across that viewpoint. Butler’s discussion of grammar and language was sometimes murky, but I was struck by the statement in the last chapter, regarding the French use of masculine “ils” as the normative, universal “they.” Throughout her book, whenever she wrote about masculine as universal and feminine as particular, I kept thinking about “ils” and its Spanish corollary “ellos.” Thus, it was good to have her give that example to confirm my reading of that portion her text. (Interestingly, German just has one, non-gendered word for “they,” “sie,” which happens to also be the singular feminine subject pronoun.)

entry.title: Gender and Sexuality II
entry.content:
Our readings this week were Gender Trouble: Feminism and Subversion of identity, by Judith Butler, and The Sexual Contract, by Carole Pateman.  I found these two works to be interesting; even if I didn’t entirely agree with their arguments.  Gender Trouble discusses what amounts, in relation to my own interests, to be a fringe topic of how different sexualities are not given equal weight in gender discussions.  Instead, they are often dismissed as abnormal, and therfore excluded from ‘normative’ constructs of gender studies and sexuality.  The Sexual Contract, on the other hand, takes a universalist look at gender relations in which male dominated society has created a civil construct that has enslaved women through a sexual contract gives new form and funtion in our modern society to the old pre-enlightenment patriarchical system.

Pateman’s work is a call for true gender neutrality in both the public and private sphere.  “The appropriate feminist response then seems to be to work for the elimination of all reference to the difference between men and women in political life,” (pg 16), and “if contract is extended into the private sphere, inequalitites of status between men and women in marriage must disappear,” (pg 167).  Given the bleak picture of the relationship between the sexes that Pateman paints throughout the book, this hardly seems achievable.  To me, the male seems demonized in The Sexual Contract, and women are portrayed as martyrs to the system.  Even though, in a Marxist sense, women own the means of production, and males want to own this process, so one might think women would have more influence on the system.  I’m being facetious, but this raises an issue we discussed last week of the level of female complicity in the system.  Pateman portrays women as subjugated and exploited vigorously by the male.  I don’t know; it all seems very general to me.  Pateman fails to interpret the nuances of familial cooperation that exist between man and wife in the ‘sexual contract.’  Even as I fully realize the legal constructs of our society have been male dominated hsitorically, there are obviously redeeming qualities to this relationship that allowed it to survive as long as it has.  So, although I didn’t completely disagree with her arguments, I must say some of them definitely raised an eyebrow.

In Gender Trouble, Judith Butler explains that “I opposed what I took to be heterosexualism at the core of sexual difference fundamentalism,” (1999 preface, pg viii).  Butler argues that a focus on normative sexuality as opposed to lesbianism and homosexuality leads to skewed analyses of gender.  I agree that the male female dichotomy alone in a heterosexual milieu narrows the focus of gender studies, I’m not sure the inclusion of all sexual preferences would add clarity to the major arguments of gender studies such as the issues with which Pateman wrestles.  However, I do think Butler is wise to point to the need to exercise caution in gender related analyses by understanding that the general context in which one is conducting one’s studies may not be entirely representative.

entry.title: Performance, Gender, and Contract Theory
entry.content:
Butler, Gender Trouble: Feminism and the Subversion of Identity | Pateman, The Sexual Contract

Butler’s argument was somewhat convoluted (possibly made more so by the fact that I did not have the text in my hands) and I am sure that there are many important nuances that I did not pick up on as she explained her thesis.  Such caveats notwithstanding, the main objective of her work is arguing that the manner in which feminists identify (or are forced to identify by a patriarchal system), and connect that identity to politics, is constraining because it assumes “women” are a single unified body based solely on sex.  In Butler’s opinion, accepting such a definition of gender is a logical fallacy for feminism as a political movement.  Through a deconstructionist theory, she is able to mock the idea of a unified concept of “women” behind feminism.  For Butler, the concepts of sex and gender are indeterminate.  Furthermore, concepts such as male-female and masculine-feminine are political constructs and should have no bearing on how feminists, or anyone else, identify. 

Gender, in Butler’s mind is little more than performance, and people in general, and feminists in particular should be aware of how they perform  their socially constructed roles in order to effect change.  Advancing an argument for a more fluid definition of gender rooted in self-identification and sexuality makes it easier to subvert the male-dominated culture.  Marginalized segments of society can also use fluid definitions of gender rooted in sexuality to work against the established culture.  Essentially, because women, lesbians, and gays are less engaged in the traditional male-dominated culture, they have more freedom to subvert or denaturalize the established categories of gender.

Butler’s argument is based on a definition of gender that is a political construct.  Pateman offers an exploration of just how that came to be through a reexamination of social contract theory.  Behind the rhetoric of liberty and equality espoused by proponents of the social contract, Pateman argues there is a larger unifying force of fraternity that, while eliminated inequality among men, has increased inequality between the sexes.   ”Sex” she argues “is central to the original contract,” and “civil freedom includes right of sexual access to women and, more broadly, the enjoyment of mastery as a sex—not a gender” (225).  Through extrapolations of the social contract via the marriage contract and the prostitution contract women are “tainted with the odour [sic] of slavery” (230) and subjugation by men. 

Pateman concedes that movement for equality between the sexes has made some great advances in the last century, that women now enjoy judicial equality and the a certain equality of opportunity with men.  However, sexual harassment has been “discovered in the workplace and the patriarchal division of labour [sic] has not been greatly upset … and that women’s economic circumstances still place them at a disadvantage in terminating the marriage contract” and the act of sex has been encapsulated by a growing sex industry “which provides men with new forms of access to women’s bodies” (228).   In essence, she argues that advances have been made and they have been easily worked around because the social contract was always predicated on the subjugation of women by men.

entry.title: Sexual Contract & Gender Matters
entry.content:
Due to my apparent habit (once is an accident, twice is a habit) of forgetting the accompanying article until alerted by my colleagues’ blogs, I decided to begin with the Butler excerpts. Also, after that enticing disclaimer in class, I hoped that Pateman would be like dessert in comparison.

Butler’s language didn’t turn out to be as bad as I’d expected, despite having to read from a screen, but her content was disappointing. Well, uneven, I guess. There were parts that I found interesting, and even a few things I enjoyed, but overall, I just wanted to shriek, So WHAT!!! I’m not sure if I’m fed up with theory in general or the persecution complex and contentious perspective of the last few readings, but I know I’ve had it with reading page after page of verbose, self-aggrandizing vocabulary manipulations that just over-inflate small ideas to make them seem more significant. Seriously, if you can’t say it succinctly, you don’t understand it well enough.

So, rant aside, here’s what I took away, beginning with my favorite quote of the whole book: “…trouble is inevitable and the task, how best to make it, what best way to be in it.” With a start like that, I figured this would be great. Sigh.

She presented several ideas, over and over, among them:
1) Gender is a performance—something we do, not something we are—and so doesn’t need to be limited to two choices. She mentioned her uncle as being institutionalized just because he didn’t fit into one of those slots.
2) Language supports the naturalizing of gender and sex. The word “women” is inadequate both because it’s only one aspect of a person and because it’s expected to refer to such a variety of people that is ceases to have meaning (sort of like our complaint of “lesbian-like” last week). I also liked her crack that pronouns become a problem here, on…some page that I can’t find now!
3) Since gender is a construct, it is a cause of our perception of sexual differentiation instead of being a result of any inherent differences. Here she pulled in Foucault’s idea around how prohibiting delinquency in effect created the category of delinquency. This has some merit, I suppose, in an ivory-tower theoretical sort of way, but I’ve changed enough diapers to say that you don’t need a pink ribbon glued to a bald head to see what you’re dealing with once the tape comes off. Maybe this is more effort to make Middlesex people ordinary instead of exceptional. I did like her explanation of Foucault in the 1990 preface, though I didn’t understand why he called this a genealogy. “…genealogy investigates the political stakes in designating as an origin and cause those identity categories that are in fact the effects of institutions, practice, discourses with multiple and diffuse points of origin…” (xxix)
4) Finally! The drag section didn’t come until the last part of the last chapter. It provided a glimmer of concreteness to what she’d been talking around through all those previous pages. Drag shows that surface indications aren’t true, which extends the thought to body elements. Just as “female” clothes cover a “male” body, so does a “male” body cover a “female” self. Drag is simultaneously anatomy, identity, and performance, each out of expected alignment, which thereby shows all three to be contingent. The parody of drag provides freedom from the hegemony of the binary cultural expectations.

Then, to Pateman, supposedly my dessert. She was easier to read, but she’s still contentious and verbose, using too many words and too many disparate sources to supposedly prove her point. She claims that contract theory obscures reality because it ignores the sexual contract that undergirds and predates it. She sees contracts as creating domination instead of limiting it.

I wonder if she’s finding what she’s looking for, even though it’s no longer (if ever) true. She wrote 22 years ago, but even then, women weren’t relegated to the private sphere because they were considered less rational than men. If anything, women were considered inadequate by other women when they chose the private sphere. The women’s movement, in demanding equal access to one style of life, has inadvertently (I hope) suggested that other styles are a betrayal. In any case, society has come a long way from the vision she argues against. I wonder—given my abhorrence for confrontation—how much of the progress has come from radical exaggerations and theoretical flights, and how much has resulted from a more incremental, persistent “add women and stir” approach.

Reading these two books suggested to me where our leeriness about feminist theory may be coming from. Both of these were very political, abstract, and strident. They include a lot of extreme ideas ungrounded in specific, concrete examples. They deal with society on a mega-level, calling for massive changes to all of reality, instead of focusing on a manageable sphere of influence where something might actually happen. Fundamentally, despite Pateman’s lead sentence on page one, there aren’t enough stories. I want a pictures from which to hang all her big ideas.

I realize this is a theory class, but I’m beginning to feel like the cartoon guy crawling across the desert: Must…Find…Narrative…

entry.title: On the Sexual Contract...
entry.content:
I am going to hit a few high points in the book that stood out to me…
Carol Pateman sets out in her book, The Sexual Contract to draw attention to the notion that the famous “social contract,” which even the framers of the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution, and the Bill of Rights had in mind as they created the American trinity of liberty (my words not hers), had a little-acknowledged rider to it; the sexual contract.  She states it better as the male sex-right, and that even though the “social contract is a story of freedom; the sexual contract is a story of subjection.” (2) The social contract masks the fact that it was instituted by men, between men, and for men. This is achieved by dividing society into two spheres – civil and private.  By pushing the women completely into the private sphere, men can dominate the civil sphere, and thus dominate society.  It is further hidden by paternalism, which subsumes the female under the protection of the male, who takes the role as the head of household.  This hides the argument further by using the father to exemplify the state, with the family as its citizens dutifully following – including mom. 
In chapter 3 she lays out the basic contract theory: we are individuals born free and equal. (39)  We then choose to be under the authority of the state.  I seem to recall when a group of ‘states’ didn’t want to be under the authority of the “State” there was a little war.  In 1865, after this little war, the “State” acted like a punishing father spanking his children for disobeying his orders.  Though she didn’t use that analogy to disrupt the theory it does sound good to me.  However, onward we go.  Conjugal power would seem a different way of saying sexual power, but Locke uses conjugal as a natural power men have over women from nature. (51)  Pufendorf follows up with the idea that men have this power to get women to consent to subjection, and this is due to male physical strength being greater than a female’s.  I guess he was closer to the days when clubbing meant whacking a female with a stick and dragging her back to the cave.  Yes, I’m laughing right now at that. I know.  I’m a dork, but that is pretty close to the idea
I want to finish this blog with one final thought.  Pateman wrote this stuff in 1988 – 22 years ago.  In her last two chapters she covers ideas about prostitution, sado-masochism, fetishes, and wonders what’s next.  I wonder if she has any new views about the state of female subjection and patriarchy.  I would like to think we’ve made strides toward evening the divide.  There can be no doubt there will always be a difference between men and women, but sometimes those differences complement each other.  I remember a wedding service I heard once.  The preacher made the statement that when God made Eve he used one of Adams ribs.  He didn’t use a bone from his feet so that she was under him or one from his head so she was over him, but from his side as she was to be beside him and work with him.  And what he couldn’t do, she could and vice versa.

entry.title: Sex by Contract
entry.content:
Carole Pateman’s The Sexual Contract operates on the premise that current social-contract theory misses a vital point, that the contract is not simply a political one but a sexual one. The political right invoked in the social contract is, in her opinion, also a patriarchal right or sex-right, giving men power over women. She argues that the creation of social contract-based civil society is also a new patriarchal society. This is innovative, in her argument, because traditionally patriarchy has been defined as the power of the father, not the power of the husband over the wife or man over woman; writing at the end of the 80’s, I will buy this theory, at least thus far—it’s still early enough that, perhaps, feminist arguments about the patriarchy have not breached into the mainstream, or at least not into contract theory.

The connection between the marriage contract and the social contract, which she lays out at the beginning (it’s nice of her to clearly state the purpose of her book and its framework right off the bat, at least), is an interesting one, and, to be frank, the part of this book that I found both most intellectually stimulating and most relevant to her topic. The idea of the marriage contract both being perpetuating the dominance of the woman by the man in the modern era, and its connection to civil society via the social contract, was not something I’d ever considered, even though I had thought long and hard about the implications of marriage in my younger, commitment-phobic days. I certainly don’t believe that the link between the marriage contract and the slave contract, or even the patriarchal dominance of women, is necessarily true in the West today (and she’s only interested in the Anglophone West, so I feel qualified to make such judgments), but as a historical topic it was… illuminating.

Now, I have to say I’ve never met anyone who claimed that the advent of “civil society” and the modern era led to an end of the patriarchy or the domination of women by men, if these were topics they discussed at all. I am not necessarily familiar with the debates over the term patriarchy, or feminist theory or history, but… and her insistence on the negative aspects of the marriage contract, that it is in essence a tool of oppression solely, regardless of how men and women attempt to break out of it… well, let’s just say I entered the second chapter of the book a bit leery of what I would find. Intrigued, and at least attempting to maintain a positive attitude, but leery.

The second chapter was a very useful overview of the term “patriarchy” and its use for her purposes. I also noticed that the sensation of being screamed at, or at least severely berated, ceased in this chapter. I was familiar with a paternalism version of patriarchy and its relationship to the state, but again, patriarchy in a feminist context is one I am familiar with in only the most general terms. Linking the two forms of patriarchy, and how they interact with society, was a helpful refresher.

Chapter three returns to marriage, and I have to admit, personal bias gets in my way of appreciating her point, because I find her arguments about marriage narrow-minded. In theory, marriage in the modern day is between equals—arguments about rings denoting ownership are nonsense, the marriage contract in the modern era in an equal undertaking, and in the Anglophone world nowadays you don’t even need cause for divorce, so it’s surprisingly easy for both men and women to get out of it. Alimony, child support, etc. in general mean that men (overwhelmingly the higher earners still, though that’s another discussion) continue to help women out after a divorce. Even historically, most marriage contracts have provided women with some rights, however limited, and even sexually women were supposed to have the right to their husbands body during the middle ages. Of course, I’m not arguing that marriage is not historically a mostly repressive regime of men dominating women physically, sexually, emotionally, politically, economically, etc., because it was and in some parts of the world still is. But in the Anglophone world, which is her specific focus, she continues to discuss marriage as if it were still this way, and it’s not.

So there’s my little rant, and I won’t mention it again.

Once she gets back to the nature of contract theory, I perked back up. The link between slavery as a contract and social contracts in general was interesting, and I think fits in very well with our discussions of the capitalist “world” system and the wage slave (as she mentions), but I was left somewhat confused as to how the slave contract and the sexual contract really interrelate.

The fourth chapter, and the parts dealing with the fraternity aspect of the patriarchy, and the father-right, and the religious aspects thereof were all interesting. The links between Locke’s vision of the father-ruler and the patriarchal basis of rulership were pretty clear, as well as the way his vision of the social contract could lead to a directly patriarchal civil society. This section, discussing solely the original social contract theorists and their vision of a patriarchal society, makes perfect sense, even the inclusion of marriage into the debate. I can very clearly see her point, that this vision of civil society completely excludes women from the social contract and therefore from the civil society.

I am not going to mention my thoughts on how she ended the chapter, or the last paragraph of chapter four. At all.

At the beginning of chapter five she does finally mention that the world of the classic contract is essentially different in many ways from our modern social world. I wish she had presented that understanding all along, and at least mentioned at the beginning that her concepts of some things were based on more classical notions.

She kept discussing how wives are like servants—does she not mention women in the workforce at all? Right, end of the 80s. Man, I would love to read an updated version of this for 2010.

The model of economic coercion and essentially work-whoring is not a crazy one—actually, it made a lot of sense. The economic aspects of marriage are pretty clear, supportive of her argument, etc. I think we’ve talked sufficiently about wage slaves for one semester though. Or at least I have.

Her discussion about marriage as being akin to the contract between a prostitute and her client was applicable. I guess. I mean, it’s not like I’ve never thought about it in those terms, I’ve just never thought about it as being the exact parallel for the marriage contract, or built into civil society. I think prostitution should be legalized, personally, for the purpose of improving standards for something that will happen anyway—I was fascinated reading this chapter.
In the end, I find her original argument, that social contract is both a political and sexual contract, that led, at least in its original form, to a patriarchal civil society, to be pretty persuasive. I do not think the book was particularly well-organized or written, and I thought there were a number of digressions and side-arguments that were deeply unnecessary, but after reading the book I’m at least convinced that her reinterpretation of social contract is both innovative and useful.

Judith Butler’s text is more familiar to me, as both my thesis advisor and my faculty supervisor at my old school were heavily involved in queer theory and taught classes on it annually, so I’ve read excerpts before and some articles by Butler. I liked her preface, both because of the humility it displays and in that she makes her point pretty clear—feminist theory was, and in some ways still is, pervasively heterosexual, and focuses on traditional gender identities and how they affect the world. The discussion of gender and what it means is productive ground for study—I’m taking “Gender and Sexuality in Early Christianity” this semester, and it’s fantastic.

I’m slightly interested in this basis in “French Theory.”

Now, as of this point, all I can read on Google Books in the Preface. I’ll happily read the other chapters when a course link is provided—Butler is a great writer, and while gender theory is not my area, it is interesting ground to tread.

entry.title: A quick comment about feminism…
entry.content: When First reading History Matters by Judith Bennett, I was struck with the natural thought that what she initially called for was anything but history. What she was calling for, it might seem, would lead to bad or incomplete history, and I was not sure exactly how to argue its inevitability since, like other interdisciplinary schools, it is in many ways self-policing. However, when she started talking about “patriarchy” as the unifying feature of all feminist history, their stance became clear: that  women looked to the past and realize their identity was determined by anything except their own qualities, it struck me that this was merely their argument. By watching the present for signs of past wrong, Bennett is merely calling for an internal call not for the heads of men but the dignity of the self.

entry.title: Thoughts on Feminism and its place in History
entry.content:
Bennett, Judith M.  History Matter: Patriarchy and the Challenge of Feminism.  Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2006.

Joan Scott, “Gender: A Useful Category of Analysis,” American Historical Review 19.5 (1986): 1053-1075.

Concerning Bennet, I found it curious how the feminist struggle took shape in different countries “especially influenced by socialism in Britain, shaped by Marxism in China, interested in women’s culture in the United States, allied with sociology in Brazil, and fractured by ‘woman’ versus ‘gender’ in Japan.”(pg 4)

Her pluralism to other socio-histories is convincing, race, class and Gender(many other factors of course) history are not at competition to see which has more sway in the plight of societies in history, rather they all play their respective roles in combination.

I enjoy the medievalist within her and how she rightly pointed out that in American culture there is an odd understanding that “old” is inherently bad, and “new” is inherently good.  She explains that this is due to the United States being a young country with no interest in harkening back to before its creation as it would remind them of a “tradition-bound, elitist, European past, as past that has been properly replaced by the dynamism of U.S. democracy and multiculturalism.”(pg 34)

Though I enjoyed her defense of pre-modern and early modern history, her eventual purposes I found conflict with.  Her ultimate goal of rejoining feminist history and feminist activism is an incorrect goal.  That in my view, is abusing history, like a Nationalist would claim a link to the people that just so happened to be in his geographic area 500 years before, and gather that the exploits of those people applied to him in the present.

Concerning Scott, I had very little issue the use of the word Gender as she proposed it, so I tended to agree with what she was saying.

entry.title: 11/08 Bennett and Scott
entry.content:
I really enjoyed Bennett’s book, though I have a few small points of disagreement about it. She argues that feminist activism and history should be more closely aligned, and she presents reasons for why they have diverged since second wave feminism took hold in the 1970s: the need for women’s history to be accepted, presentism, and the move away from history by feminist scholars in literature and other fields. The discussion of presentism, and Bennett’s negative view of it, form a strong secondary thesis to the book, one that I, as a medievalist, appreciated.

As a TA this semester who’s seeing a western civilization textbook for the first time (my undergrad survey professor hated them and assigned us several primary sources instead), I certainly see Bennett’s point about women being added on as an afterthought in the master narrative. At the same time, I think she, at times, goes a little too far: women certainly should be included in narratives of the medieval period, but Christine de Pisan, for example, while interesting, doesn’t merit the same weight as Gregory of Tours. At the same time, women such as Eleanor d’Aquitaine and Emma of Normandy certainly deserve more attention than they receive. They are the “women worthies,” but as Bennett says, it’s not hard to include “…and nuns” when discussing monasteries.

As said, I appreciated Bennett’s defense of the medieval period throughout in her assertion that feminist scholars need to look beyond 1800 in order to examine continuities and changes. Events in the 1800s, whether concerning women or men, sometimes have roots in earlier time periods, and those should be considered. I disagree, however, in her attempts to make the past relevant to students today. I agree that the “past is a foreign country,” and while we can find parallels to today’s society, the idea that Value X is important today just as it was in 1300 is uncritical. Past events can inform what we do today, but finding those links isn’t the goal of history.

I was already familiar with the ideas in Scott’s article, that “gender” should have more theoretical meaning, and that the construct of gender is different from biologically-determined “sex.” However, it was nice to read the argument in her words.

entry.title: On Gender and Sexuality
entry.content:
This weeks assigned readings were Joan Scott’s 1986 article “Gender: A Useful Category of Analysis,”  and Judith Bennett’s, History Matters.  I found these two works to be quite instructional on a subject about which I have very little knowledge.  I was unaware there was such a heated debate among feminist historians about how to best define and do feminist history.  Judith Bennett actually quotes Joan Scott directly in her conclusion as someone whose philosophy of “simply comparing data about women didn’t get us very far,” places her firmly in the category of the ‘third wave’ of feminism she seems to feel is more a Sex in the City style feminism in comparison to her hard-core ‘second wave’ of feminism in the 1970s. 

Although I agree with Bennett’s basic points, I disagree in some ways with how she might put them into practice.  For example, I agree that feminism should be confrontational to inequalities against women today, and, where possible, history should be used to clarify/bolster this position.  At the same time, I don’t think the idea of creating a category identifying ‘lesbian-like’ behavior in order to create more historical precedents, sources, or foundations for research is necessarily a good idea.  Another conclusion Bennett makes is that the patriarchal system has come to be ignored due to its unpopularity among postfeminists and general crticism of talk of women’s oppression being amateurish and overly emotional.  However, as Bennett clearly points out, the gender movement has branched out into many finer forms of argument, and universal history has gone by the wayside.  Perhaps patriarchy is the universal system of feminism, and maybe the system is being refined, and, over time, will be redefined. 

It seems Bennett feels jaded by the transition in focus from feminism to gender study, but she does admit the new outlook shows an overall maturation of the field.  In that respect, you can’t have your cake and eat it too.  On the other hand Joan Scott’s article is a look at the use of “gender as a way of referring to the social organization of the relationship between the sexes,” (pg 1053).  In my opinion, this more inclusive approach seems more enlightened than Bennett’s, and may actually serve better to solve her problems with fodder for medieval research and beyond.  In Scott’s view, no understanding of the feminine can be achieved without attempts at understanding the male in the same ways.  While this makes perfect sense to me, this is likely to be just the theory that Bennett considers a further homogenization of her beloved field.

entry.title: Reflections on Bennett and Scott
entry.content:
It is a paradox endemic to the American character: We feel that a better tomorrow is our birthright, even as are quick to disregard the lessons of yesterday.

Yes, I know that’s basically a variation on what Santayana said. But it’s a notion that is compellingly laid out in Judith M. Bennett’s “History Matters: Patriarchy and the Challenges of Feminism.”

For all the ways that women’s lot has improved, Bennett says, there remains a glass ceiling, and its name is patriarchy. This system is so pervasive as to be, like glass, practically invisible. And even when gender diversity comes to formerly male-dominated institutions, patriarchy lingers as a largely unquestioned norm.

I am male. I also have a wife and a young daughter. And I am not aware that I have actively engaged in any oppression or subordination of the female population, nor do I have any desire to do so. But does that mean I’ve never benefited from gender inequity? I don’t know. Certainly, I’ve not been oblivious to the constraints that some of my female relatives and friends have faced, but I suppose I’ve been of the mindset that it’s only a matter of time before such dynamics go the way of colonialism. Or slavery. Or Soviet communism. So I guess that brings us back to my original point.

I am old enough to remember the pejorative (a la Gloria Steinem) or at least quirky (a la Alan Alda) connotations that were assigned to feminism in its ERA heyday. Bennett’s work makes clear why such was the take-home message for our mainstream culture.

Meanwhile, Joan W. Scott’s “Gender: A Useful Category of Historical Analysis” continues the cultural history theme by focusing on a very specific language issue.

I have long been aware that “gender” is not, technically speaking, a true synonym for sex, and yet I’ve understood why the terms have come to be treated as interchangeable. And though I consider myself something of a stickler when it comes to linguistic matters, I’ve not really been bothered by that particular practice.

That said, Scott’s article left my head spinning. As she delves deeper, I can sort of understand her points on a case-by-case basis, but taken together, it’s a lot to absorb.

“Gender is a synonym for women.” OK.

“Gender is … a social category imposed on a sexed body.” Gotcha.

“Gender is a constitutive element of social relationships based on perceived differences between the sexes, and gender is a primary way of signifying relationships of power.” Ummmm … yeah.

I’ll be interested to see what light our discussion can shed on these ideas.

entry.title: hist510 Gender
entry.content:
I was initially leery of the readings for this week simply because I tend to shy away in general from feminism and women’s history. To my mind, feminist history conjures images of resentful women creating female-only histories that do the exact same thing as their male-centered counterparts do, only switching the subjects’ sex. With this mindset, therefore, I was quite relieved to discover that both the article and the book shunned this approach in favor of a more mutually balanced history of women that focused primarily on integration. I thought both texts provided well-reasoned arguments for the broader incorporation of women’s history into more mainstream history and why such a development would prove useful to the overall profession.

Joan Scott’s article focused mainly on the term “gender” and the position this idea currently holds in the historical profession. According to Scott, gender has traditionally entailed two different aspects: descriptive power and theoretical power. For much of its existence, gender has primarily been employed in its descriptive form rather than its analytical one. Scott, however, argues that gender would serve a more useful purpose as an analytical category used to better understand human relations. Gender as a theoretical tool rejects any biological implications of the term and is instead regarded as a means of examining culturally constructed social identities. What I found most interesting about this interpretation of gender is the universality it implies for both historical applications and sex in a biological sense. Gender is not only appropriate for the study of women doing traditionally female activities, but it can now be expanded to include studies of male politics. Scott argues, convincingly I believe, that the subtle effects of gender extend into all areas of human relationships. Things such as the cult of manliness and traditional ideas of male protection all fall within the category of “gender”, thus justifying the incorporation of gender studies into traditionally male-dominated spheres. I also found the somewhat ambiguous nature of Scott’s conception of gender to be intriguing; her argument that gender identity, although operating under an illusion of coherence, is actually a constantly shifting phenomenon. 

As much as I enjoyed Scott’s article, I was surprised to find that I liked History Matters by Judith Bennett even more. The overall style of the book was well done, from the clear organization to the relaxed yet professional prose. In addition, as a medievalist I appreciated her use of medieval examples, which I believe made the book even more interesting. When I first read the book’s title, I expected another generalized argument for the overall usefulness of history, not an argument for the greater incorporation of history into women’s studies. Needless to say, I appreciate her chosen course much more. Although I am not a strong proponent of women’s history, this book forced me to ponder if perhaps that might not be because of the forward-minded approach taken by many feminists that Bennett argues against. According to Bennett, the study of women’s history is in great need of historical help to strengthen the discipline in terms of accuracy and potential efficacy. I strongly agree with her assertion that feminists need to look back to the past to truly understand and work to address women’s subservient position in society. One of my favorite parts of this book was Bennett’s argument for a theory of continuity in women’s history rather than periods of foundational change that currently dominates. Personally, I imagined from Bennett’s argument a dual existence of women’s history where the foundational layer, the system of patriarchy, remained constant while the upper layer reflected societal change. Even though shifts may occur on this upper level, such as the status rise of a previously female-dominated trade, counter changes will arise to insure the foundation of patriarchy remains. 

For me, the most interesting part of Bennett’s book was her analysis of patriarchy. As she points out, many historians shy away from such charged terms as “patriarchy”, particularly historians of women seeking to maintain academic legitimacy. Bennett, however, argues that this dismissal of patriarchy is not only inaccurate but ultimately detrimental to women’s history. I found myself agreeing with her use of patriarchy as a concept around which historians of women can focus their study and not, thankfully, as a meta-narrative. Patriarchy is such a useful starting point for study because of its constant pervasiveness in society; although it has existed in different forms over the centuries, patriarchy has remained constantly present to insure the inferior status of women. The overall effect of the patriarchal system has been to keep women socially, economically and politically disadvantaged, but this does not mean that patriarchy was universally bad. In fact, Bennett suggests that patriarchy has survived so long because women have found ways to exist in and take advantage of the system, ultimately contributing to its endurance. This aspect of Bennett’s argument was particularly interesting to me and her fair-mindedness greatly improved the substantial respect I already held for her as a scholar. Bennett’s brief study of brewsters in England to illustrate her points was particularly enjoyable, and I fully recommend her complete study Ale Beer and Brewsters. 

The readings for this week once again pleasantly surprised me, and I found them to be particularly useful because they countered so many unfounded misgivings I held toward women’s history. Both pieces presented convincing arguments for the applicability of gender studies to the broader historical profession as well as providing useful theoretical tools for doing so. I am still not as interested in women’s history as much as other areas such as religion, but I certainly hold greater appreciation now. More importantly, Scott and Bennett have convinced me that gender and patriarchy play a role worthy note in non-traditional areas of study, and I hope I will keep such considerations in mind in future studies.

entry.title: The Failure of Feminism
entry.content:
Judith Bennett, History Matters: Patriarch and the Challenge of Feminism | Joan Scott, “Gender: A Useful Category of Analysis

After reading Bennett’s History Matters, I am utterly lost as to what she perceived the impact of her book to be.  She rants against the male-dominated hierarchy of professional history, demands a greater focus on pre-modern women’s history, and an increased attention to the oppression of women in all periods of historical investigation.  The entirety of her book came to little more than a lament for the separation of professional history and feminist activism.  Taking such an approach, her argument seems confusing at best and incomprehensible at worst. 

Because she is a professional historian, perhaps the greatest insult to her and the tripe she calls a book is to say she suffers from nostalgia.  While Bennett asserts her lack of nostalgia (153), she frequently reminds the reader that she wants to restore the feminism that has been lost.  She writes: “This book seeks to recover … [the] ideal of a seamless union of history and feminism” (1); “Feminist activists and scholars, once so steeped in history have lost interest in the past” (29); “it is time for historians of women and gender to regain our feminist indignation” (154). 

The entirety of Bennett’s argument is that “women’s history seems to be losing its feminist edge; deferring unnecessarily to male authority, dwelling overmuch on biographies of unusual women, taking a sharp cultural turn away from social and material considerations, attending more to diversity than to power differentials, and allying with a history of masculinity that is developing in surprisingly problematic ways” (22-3).

Despite her constant rant about what is wrong with women’s history today, she never comes to any sufficient conclusion as to why the loss of militant feminism is such a terrible thing for women and gender historians.  Because the historiography of women and gender has become so widespread and culturally inclusive, Bennett suggests that it has lost its feminist edge.  Perhaps she adequately describes the expansion of women’s history and its pluralistic development over the last four decades, but she fails to explain why the evolution of an inclusive, globalized point of view is such a terrible thing for the women’s movement or for the genre or women’s history.  It seems that history only matters for Bennett when it is explicitly political and specifically affirms her feminist point of view.

Joan Scott, on the other hand, presents a more logical and understandable perspective of the women and gender field of history.  She suggests that the term gender fits nicely into the social construct of expectations pertaining to men and women.  Like Bennett, Scott suggests that there is a trend within professional history to be more inclusive in historical investigations which naturally brings differences of class, race, and gender to the fore (1054).  Scott goes on, however, to examine the strengths and weaknesses of the theories and viewpoints which dominate the current historiography of women and gender. 

Scott succeeds because she is able to form a coherent argument for the inclusion of gender-based examinations.  She argues that because gender is a “constitutive element of social relationships based on perceived differences between the sexes” as “a primary way of signifying relationships of power” (1067), that it may open new perspectives in examining historical actors.  Owing to its creation as a social construct, gender-based analyses are applicable to nearly all realms of historical inquiry, from class, to race, to politics.  Scott argues that “historically specific, normative definitions of gender” are “reproduced and embedded” in the culture of people, time, or place (1073).  Because “gender is one of the recurrent references by which political power has been conceived legitimated and criticized” (1073) it may provide a better understanding of the motivation and ideals of the period and people under investigation.

entry.title: History Matters, Judith Bennett
entry.content:
The subtitle of this book is Patriarchy and the Challenge of Feminism, and Bennett certainly featured both of those topics, but the main point I got from the book is that History Matters. She almost always couched this claim in terms of it mattering for feminist strategy, but I saw this book primarily as a manifesto for the importance of studying pre-1800 history, even beyond its usefulness to just feminism.

It was reassuring to have her insist so often that we study the events in history because they’re useful for our need in the present. I seem to recall a previous discussion in class that historians are not supposed to read history in order to find insights for today. I felt then, and still think now, that that is nonsense. If you don’t find patterns and causalities and implications for the events in your historical studies, then you only have a list of facts, like an antiquarian. If you do find these, they will inform your perceptions of other events and trends, including the ones around you. So, in answer to her claim that “this is a book…intended to help us think more generally about history, patriarchy, and feminism,” (3), I would say she did a better job with the first than the second and third goals.

It was interesting to keep a tally of every time she reiterated her claim that studying history could inform current strategy (pages 1,4,5,33 [repeated almost verbatim 42-43], 50, 60, 106, 129, 138, and 154, in case you’re interested). Hers is a more focused and political perspective, but by removing just a few descriptors, she makes an excellent case for studying history, period. “history provides…long-term perspectives essential to building a better long-term future” (4), “I believe that modern history is impoverished by inattention to the premodern past…” (133) “The power of [fill in your current problem] in our lives today partly rests, in other words, on our failure to understand how it has worked in past times” (60) “If they would look further down the ‘long cool corridors of the past,’ [they] would see their short-term data in a different light.” (106)

The past is particularly suited to examining emotionally fraught issues of today, like the patriarchy and feminism that Bennett is interested in, because the distance lends objectivity and dispassion that enable clearer thinking and sharper insights. That’s one of the reasons morality tales have so often been set long ago or “peopled” with animals—it’s easier to talk about selfishness over there in them than to recognize it inside yourself. She returns to this benefit of history less often than the strategy angle, but on pages 52, 146, and 149 she does so quite eloquently.

What she did less eloquently, but no less often, was to defend her terminology. Endlessly. Women on page 9, objectivity (positivism) on page 14, patriarchy on page 55, and her pet phrase, “lesbian-like” all through chapter six. I wish she could have explained herself briefly and then moved on to her point, leaving the agonizing defense of her vocabulary choices for the footnotes. In the case of lesbian-like especially, I lost sight of her point, unless the only point of chapter six was to campaign for her new word.

Other than that (and the fact that footnote 16 on age 133 didn’t answer my question) this was an excellent book. I appreciated its defense of premodern history, I enjoyed the description and analysis of the brewsters’ situation, and I picked up many shiny thoughts to squirrel away for future consideration. She made a good case for the usefulness of grand narratives and overarching structures even as she pointed out their limits. On page 131 she hit the nail on the head with the benefit of conventional textbooks—they should only be expected to provide the foundation, thereby freeing the teacher space to incorporate the magic. And she gave a great testimony to the power of incrementalism and moderation in her story on pages 135-137, about editing that textbook.

entry.title: Gender
entry.content:
Joan Scott notes the creation of the term “gender” to apply to the socially constructed expectations that surround the biological division of male and female. Instead of using the term “sex,” which conjures up both sexual activity and a certain biological determinism, “gender” denotes a distinction from a study of physical difference to a study of male-female dynamics. Women’s or gender history is an expanding field, though as Judith Bennett points out, it is not without its detractors. There is a larger disciplinary trend within History to expand the topics of historical study. This includes increases awareness of class, race, religion, and now gender, as well(Scott, 1054; Bennett, 142). Like these other fields, there is tension within gender history over inclusiveness, as some studies stop short of full integration into the analysis of the period and instead just add a few interesting case studies of particular individuals. In addition to call historians to do more than create biographies for a few “women worthies,” Scott also looks at the strengths and weaknesses of current theories to explain patriarchy, or male dominance.

While her points are well-taken that women taking the primary responsibility for childcare is not biologically determined (in fact, there are some cultures where the man had primary childcare responsibility), I do think she underplays the period of nursing after the child is born, which certainly marks the woman as necessary to the child’s care. Her attention to the pattern that seems to emerge of female suppression when new regime takes over, despite a lack of economic incentive to disadvantage that group, is strong evidence for the issue of patriarchy. It seems one of the popular and effective strategies for cementing a new rule is to first “put women in their place,” which is, to me, powerful evidence to the political implications of patriarchy and a lens through which the traditionally male-dominated field of political history, could be opened to included gender(Scott, 1072).

Finally, one part of Bennett’s book that was particularly intriguing to me was her analysis of the Virgin Mary. As both the ideal woman and the intercessor, female virtue is embodied in this central religious figure; that much has always been clear. However, the more nuanced interpretations of Mary as both mother and bride, virgin and mother, new mother and bereaved parent, create an impossible standard that women cannot achieve as well as connecting female worth and authority entirely to their connection to men(Bennet, 146). Both of these have real implications for women’s place within society, then and now.

entry.title: Gender
entry.content: In her article, “Gender: A Useful Category of Historical Analysis,” Joan Scott argues that the term ‘gender’ should be employed more in historical studies than it currently is, and that by not using such a functional term that many historians are selling themselves short.  Gender to Scott should be a new topic defined as a “constitutive element of social relationships based on perceived differences between the sexes” and “a primary way of signifying relationships of power.” (1067) She says it is useful to historians because it is practically an uncharted terrain, and it can be politicized.  By applying the concepts of marital relations to political context, “gender is one of the recurrent references by which political power has been conceived, legitimated, and criticized.” (1073) When you look at her argument it is rather convincing how an examination of political, class, and race of a subject through a gender lens may provide better insight into motivations and ideas of the characters being studied.

entry.title: Patriarchy Matters, or How I Stop Being Small-Minded About Feminist History
entry.content:
Let me start with the article for a change, because usually by the time I get done with blogging about our weekly book I don’t really have anything left to say, and it gets neglected.

The opening discussion on gendered language reminds me of why my French grammar is terrible, despite being a native speaker. My grandparents will never let me live down my rants as a kid about how trees were neither male nor female, and my general disdain for having to learn whether a word was masculine or feminine. Of course, I can now see the phallic symbolism in a tree, and I understand language much better than I did then, but I still hate the way words are gendered in ways that make no sense to me.

Gender is a useful category for historical analysis—it isn’t the one I’m most comfortable with, but that is slowly but surely changing. The discussions of gender identity in Gender and Sexuality in Early Christianity, the class I’m taking with Dr. Shepardson, have been lively and enlightening, and I’m starting to see how it can be a good direction for me to look at.

Gender theory, and its use in history, are areas fairly murky to me, but between the article and the book I have a much better sense of why women’s history requires such a theoretical approach if it is going to really be women’s history, as opposed to the kind of panacea described in parts of both texts. The barest mention of women in textbooks without altering the grand narrative of history, the inclusion of “notable women” without mentioning the lives of the commoners, and the idea of history as progress are all counterproductive to creating a truly synthetic history—one that takes into account both men and women equally, and uses both of their experiences to create a new narrative structure, rather than grafting on a thin outer layer of equality without really changing anything.

I enjoyed this book much more than I thought I would. Honestly, the title kind of scared me: History Matter: Patriarchy and the Challenge of Feminism. The word “patriarchy” has all kinds of really negative, man-hating connotations in my mind, and I appreciate that Bennett toke the time to forthrightly address these kinds of concerns. I don’t disagree with her definition of patriarchy, a social system that is inherently man-centric, or the use of feminist theory and critique in history being to show that, within a social group under the same circumstances, women are disadvantaged in comparison to men. It was a really nonthreatening way of going about it.

I think what I found most useful about this book was not the actual feminist theory; I’ve been exposed to it before, and while this text managed to reverse the vision of it I had had before, that wasn’t really what did it for me (though the historical examples were really neat). What I liked best about this book was the way in which it dealt with the historical profession and genre in general. The emphasis on a political use of history, without necessarily returning to the nationalistic genre of history writing or skewing facts, is important to me—mostly because she uses this as a springboard for how to make history, and especially premodern history, relevant. That the kind of thing I wish there was more honest debate about, and I found her discussion, with all the pitfalls waiting for feminist women’s history in academia and the broader world, refreshing and engaging. The problem of conforming to the academy’s expectations in order not to be judged amateurish is one that worries me, with my own, personal goals, so it was nice to hear not only her personal experience, but an entire discipline’s struggle in this way.

entry.title: Feminism and Patriarchy
entry.content:
Judith Bennett makes no bones about where she stands; as a lesbian or as a feminist.  Her book, History Matters: Patriarchy and the Challenge of Feminism, seems like a venting of frustration at first.  She starts strong, stating that feminism is not the ‘she-woman man-haters club’ that many think of it as.  Feminism can be very useful to men as well, mainly in the area of the history of masculinity.  Her main point is that by looking at the past from a feminist perspective, a whole new approach opens up.  New angles on old questions, new insights into why and how something could have happened.  She takes issue with the so-called feminist magazines that used to run sections devoted to the exploration of strong female characters of the past.  Now they rarely devote much space to history articles, and then only those that focus on more modern history.  She finds three troubling problems: loss of a golden age for female history, the present mindedness of most feminist scholars today, and the current focus on women of the West.  Patriarchy has three meanings to her: ecclesiastical power of men, legal power of husband/father over the family, and the main one for her; the one that draws on the “feminist critiques of male power.” (55)  When she said that “by analyzing the nature and causes of women’s oppression in the past, we can directly contribute to feminist strategies for the present,” (81) it sounds a lot like using the past to define the present.  Wasn’t that a no-no for historians? 
Her comparison of wage differences is compelling, but I never like wage comparisons between past and present for a couple reasons.  First, what is the information pool of the past? Second, is this comparable to today’s pool of workers?  I know that in every wage job I’ve had in my life the females in that job have made the same as I did.  This is what throws me off.  I’m sure to make the arguments of discrimination you have to look at non-hourly wage workers since people in the past were not under law to pay equally and everything was negotiated.  But wouldn’t the very fact of there being a law of equal pay signify a change in society?  This was never addressed in her work, at least not that I found.
Her idea of “lesbian-like” (109) does add a new dimension to the study of women in the past.  It would make for interesting discussions about the motivations of some, and the behaviors and aims of others.  However, she concedes that the term will not answer any real questions, but it does open many possibilities.  In the end, she did achieve her goal.  I was shocked by her forthrightness and it made me think in new ways about things I had never really given much thought.  Patriarchy is not dead, not by a long shot.  That is her real message; feminist historians need to wake up and smell the coffee, because there is much work left to be done.
