entry.title: Empathy and my Understanding
entry.content:
“Does a historian need empathy to understand the past?”

In short, yes.  Empathy as I understand it, is understanding the emotions of people from the past and withholding our judgement of them.  It is rather presumptuous to think that one can truly understand what a person felt in, for example, the Reconquista on either side of the conflict but plenty of clues and decent guess work can land a historian in the right direction and like most things in the historical field, trying is a good portion of the battle! I must admit though… passing judgement always seems to sell books, Crusaders as evil doers or heroes seem to stock the  minuscule medieval history shelf at  any Barnes & Noble or Borders book store.

“Should the historian have the obligation to approach that past culture with the anthropologist’s cultural relativism?”

No. I feel this is limiting the historian to a specific view and I am far to pluralist to allow this to happen.  I enjoy reading different schools of thought on the same period as they keep each other in check.

“Finally, is “culture”, and however *you* define that term, an indispensable object of historical inquiry? Is it the most significant? How do you define it?”

First, to define “culture,” I have no problem with the anthropological definition of the way of living done by a group of people at a certain point in time.  And culture gives context to historical inquiry, I would be weary of separating them.  Concerning it significance, it depends on the question asked, after a context is established the historical inquiry could deal with an infinite amount of topics, and culture itself wont be the main discussion.

entry.title: Empathy and the Historian
entry.content:
I was a little sad that this discussion got cut off early last week, and I’m even more sorry that it has taken me this long comment on it. Empathy, the ability to really get into the mindset or feelings of others, is a very useful ability in life; when you tell your friends “I feel for you,” you’re at least claiming empathy, and a lack in empathy makes any social interaction much more difficult, let alone a study abroad experience or reading works in a foreign language. When you’re a historian, empathy allows you to take a relatively unbiased look at a period, to at least attempt to get inside the mindset of the historical actors and view them from their own context, rather than your own—even when you fail (as you inevitably will), at least you will have made the attempt and gotten closer than you would otherwise. In the case of the Crusades, my area of study, the use of empathy allows me to look at the sack of Jerusalem through the eyes of the fighters—tired, hungry, thirsty, baking under the sun, having undertaken the longest land journey imaginable for someone in Western Europe, harassed by Muslim armies the entire way, devoid of effective leadership, angry, filled with religious zeal… That doesn’t mean that I have to approve of their actions, or not condemn the slaughter in Jerusalem, but I can understand how it came to that.

Now, this doesn’t mean that I necessarily agree with moral relativism. I am, perhaps, preprogrammed to believe in the righteousness of my culture (ok, ok, nix the perhaps), but I think some things are wrong, and I refuse to disregard those beliefs—oppression of women, slavery, etc. etc. However, I don’t think my personal disapproval necessarily makes me a bad historian, or the fact that I think some things are universal wrongs. I can accept that, while I think they were wrong, they lived in a different time, and my views are immaterial. Will it come through in my writing? Probably. But that’s unavoidable, and at least I embrace the fact that I am biased.

Historians need empathy; but that doesn’t mean they have to approach history without any personal biases or a belief in moral/ethical relativism.

entry.title: Foucault
entry.content:
Foucault starts the book with a public execution for a man convicted of regicide in 1757. He rightfully spares no detail in the proceedings of the execution, notable for its terrorizing use of state-sponsored violence(3-5). These details are necessary because it is central to his work that this type of sentence blurred the line between crime and punishment. Foucault incisively looks at the changing philosophies of the penal system, including notions of punishment from physical pain to the suspension of liberties, the concern over the body or the soul of the detained, and the role of judges and nature of judgments(19, 21). I was particularly interested in this section on the way the vengeance of the king was carried out, since an affront to the law is an attack on the king’s figurative person. However, the king did not actually carry out this vengeance, himself, and could always provide a dramatic pardon, much to the crowd’s delight(53). Thus the king could maintain a certain distance from the actual carnage, while the bloodshed was done in his name and by his command(49).

In a similar vein, the executioner had an interesting connection to social control. He bears the brunt of association with state-ordered killing, and is quickly reprimanded if the execution is not carried out correctly. If he administers too much pain, he could be mercilessly insulted and even attacked by the crowd, and if he fails, the person could be freed(though this practice is later stopped)(52). This connects to the designated notion of pain punishments, as a particular amount of pain was to be exacted in response to particular crimes. Even if the person was condemned to death, the crowd watched to be sure they got death only once, unless their punishment specifically decreed otherwise. I had always thought “die a thousand deaths,” was a hyperbole, but it in fact denotes a particular way of killing a person, seemingly equivalent to the pain of dying many times. This system was further refined as punishments were specifically related to the crime (symbolic punishments, especially) and to the amount of pain deserved ( 45, 89).

This show of force could backfire if the crowd sympathized with the convicted. If they died without blaspheming, they could be elevated to martyr-like status. If they died cursing authority, many in the crowd would enjoy that, too, and state officials were left with their “authority mocked and criminals transformed into heroes.”(61). The use of torture could also possibly backfire, as a person who stood up under being “put to the question,” could no longer be put to death, whatever other evidence was collected against them.

In switching focus to discipline, Foucault notes the way the body can be molded toward certain desirable ends, beginning with the example of a soldier. He then defines discipline, and says that “the historical moment of the disciplines was the moment when the art of the human body was born, which was directed not only at the growth of skills, nor at the intensification of its subjection, but at the formation of a relation that in the mechanism itself makes it more obedient as it becomes more useful, and conversely(138).
I think this notion of discipline promoting usefulness is fascinating and is well documented in other parts of the section. Also important, and somewhat disturbing, is the idea of perfect observation, leading to the panopticism.
Finally, Foucault’s analysis of other methods of discipline and punishment toward the end of the book are well placed, since he is right to assert that concern over the penal system does not just take place during reform movements, but is in a more continual state of development(235).

In discussion tomorrow, I hope we can devote some time to these questions, (among others) since these topics were of particular interest to me:

How does the role of the crowd relate to the system of public punishment? How can it enhance and undermine the effectiveness of the punishment?

How does Foucault define discipline and how does this shape this argument for the latter half of the book?

How does religion seem to intersect penal theory, in its various stages of development?

entry.title: Deviance and the Knowledge-Power Dialectic
entry.content:
Discipline and Punish, Michel Foucault

In Discipline and Punish, Foucault argues for a philosophical shift in the punishment of criminals brought about most notably by the French Revolution and the Enlightenment.  These developments altered the state’s foundation of legitimacy, transferring it from the divine right of kings to the social contract.  Crime itself was changing, too.  The demise of the last vestiges of feudal France brought a new set of property relations as capitalism flourished.  Capitalistic property relations saw a “shift from the criminality of blood to a criminality of fraud” where crime was no longer violent and directed at people, but deceitful and directed at property (77). 

More importantly, “the power to judge” no longer depended “on the innumerable, discontinuous, sometimes contradictory privileges of sovereignty, but on the continuously distributed effects of public power” (81).  Logically extending from these developments, the punishment of crimes took on the model of the social contract, whereby the right to punish was shifted from the vengeance of sovereigns “to the defence [sic] of society” (90).

Less concerned with exacting blood for blood, the punishment of criminals under this new system is concerned with the “collective coercion of bodies” (169).  The main function of the power to discipline is “to ‘train’, rather than to select and to levy” punishments upon transgressors (170).  Under the social contract where crime is prosecuted as a defense of society, the punishment of criminals is not designed to force them out of society but to coerce their compliance with the social contract—to train them to be good citizens. 

Through hierarchical observation (that is observation of the masses by some vested authority), normalized judgment (where the knowledge of individuals was used to rank them according to their potential), and examination (the pedagogical science of treating the individual as a case study), outside authorities placed an arbitrary value on the individual offender so that a treatment may be developed to rehabilitate the offender.     

In Discipline and Punish, Foucault presents not just an argument for the evolution of a modern penal movement, but a larger philosophical suggestion that a power-knowledge dialectic has emerged which is rooted in the institutionalization of science and knowledge.  Perhaps the strangest extension of his system is the recasting of power from a negative, exclusionary or oppressive element in society to that of a generative or producing element.  Under such a view, the modern individual is little more than a composite of the empirical data obtained through being observed.  Such a view fits nicely within Foucault’s Carceral Continuum where all social relations are relegated, in some form or another to the pervasive desire to identify deviance.

entry.title: About Crime and Punishment…
entry.content:
What frightens me about the nature of our penetration system isn’t the nature of those who go in, though certainly the socioeconomic slant is troubling. What bothers me more than anything is the nature of those who come out. It seems like “reform” might be to arbitrary a term and the process might be to broad to affect much actual change.

However, change is often stagnant because most of the effort for change is, for better or worse, rooted in the cause of the same socioeconomic slant that seems to prejudice some into more and longer incarceration than others. However, since justice, to many people, as an immediate connotation, the gap between “prevention” and implementation might never actually be breached; and many see them as the same function.  In effect, the implementation of punishment for some is a misplaced punishment of crime yet to be committed. Until people can transfer the excess of punishment into a concerted effort into improving  the socioeconomic factors that go into crime, they may always exist. Indeed, it seems as though until people begin to trust active social improvment over an over emphasis on incarceration than there will always be a sense of injustice in the justice system.

entry.title: Reflections on 'Discipline and Punish'
entry.content:
How ought society to deal with crime and criminals? What is the ultimate objective of “justice”?

Michael Foucault in his 1975 opus considers those thorny and age-old questions. And it is perhaps to his credit that in his treatment I found no real answers, but instead even more questions.

When considering the sick spectacle that was torture executions, many perhaps would be inclined to glory in the more enlightened state of 21st-century humanity. But that, of course, would be foolish. Biologically, we are no different than they. Culturally, we are not at all far removed from their world. So what reason is there to think that we possess some inherent moral superiority that would preclude us from indulging in such coolly calculated atrocities as did they (or others in more recent centuries and decades)?

Or, as Foucault (Page 91) quotes Lacretelle saying, “God, who has imprinted in our hearts an aversion to pain for ourselves and for our fellow men, are they then those same beings, whom thou has created so weak and so sensible, who have invented such barbarous, such refined tortures?”

As for the purpose of punishing criminals, and the deeper psychological issues underlying that question, again I am unsure, and more to the point, I am unconvinced that our society is sure.

It seems that the fashionable mindset remains this: “The prison, though an administrative apparatus, will at the same time be a machine for altering minds” (Page 125). OK. But for better, or for worse? That’s something else entirely.

At any rate, these things trouble me.

entry.title: hist510- Foucault
entry.content:
When I first discovered that the book for this week was written by Michael Foucault, I must admit I was less than excited. I have not had much direct exposure to Foucault prior to reading this book, but what brief writings I had read and from hearing discussion of his idea, I was fairly sure that I would not enjoy his study. Although Discipline and Punishment is still far from my favorite book assigned throughout this class, it was nonetheless much more enjoyable than I had anticipated. My biggest complaint stems from a personal distaste for strongly theoretical works, which Foucault’s certainly is. The ideas he presents are interesting and thought-provoking, but I cannot bring myself to enjoy theoretical analysis as much as narrative forms of history. On the positive side, however, I found the foundational subject for this book, prisons and the shift in penal punishment, to be incredibly interesting. This is not a topic with which I am very familiar and I greatly enjoyed Foucault’s treatment of the material. Another factor that stimulated my involvement with the book was t its surprisingly brutal nature. I appreciated Foucault’s decision to incorporate such stories simply because, for me, the vivid descriptions helped counteract the somewhat callous and disassociated tone of the book. 

It took a great deal of time and rereading to get through Discipline and Punishment, and even at the end I was unsure I completely understood all of Foucault’s arguments. He puts forth a great deal of constructed relationships to help explain the shift in punishment that occurred from the mid eighteenth to mid nineteenth century, such as power-knowledge or body-object. Often these models prove useful for understanding Foucault’s ideas, but it can be difficult to grasp the many nuances Foucault perceives to exist in these relationships. To my surprise, I found myself rather convinced by Foucault’s argument that punishment shifted from a corporal form of vengeance to a disciplinary one focused on control. I believe there is much merit in his analysis of cultural shifts and their ensuing impact on how power was perceived during the advent of the modern age. Torture fell into disuse as the primary concern became the creation of “docile bodies,” which involve a subjugation of the mind- Foucault would argue the soul- rather than a subjugation of the body. According to Foucault, this necessitated the disassociation of power from the body as disciplinary institutions sought to increase the efficiency of the body while imposing a strict subjugation to ensure the power relationship. This new goal could only be achieved through constant surveillance and an ability to control. In addition, it must be achieved through non-violent means because the creation of a docile body is an internal phenomenon. Such criteria could not be met prior to the expansion of institutions and advent of modern technologies that occurred throughout into the nineteenth century.

Although I did enjoy this book, I would have like to see an in-depth expansion of Foucault’s analysis beyond France. He addressed other countries as well, but I wondered to what extent his conclusions would apply to other countries, such as Spain, had they received the same level of attention as did France. Perhaps one of the most enjoyable aspects of this book was its though-provoking nature; I certainly reflected more upon this book and its implications than I do in most. I am not an unconditional supporter of Foucault’s power theory, but I do find this interpretation to be very interesting because of its broad applicability. Personally, and I believe this holds true for most of Foucault’s readers, I could not read this book without reflecting on contemporary penal institutions and the nature of the power-knowledge relationship in today’s society. After reading and reflecting, I finally came down on the favorable side of the book despite my initial misgivings. Regardless of one’s personal feelings toward Foucault, I believe that at least an awareness of his theories is important for any professional historian.

entry.title: Thoughts on Foucault…
entry.content:
To be frank, Foucault was an intimidating read. However, as I read along i found myself thinking I knew a great deal of what he was talking about and realized that it was Foucault’s clear message that made itself the standard for our modern day understanding of crime and punishment.  I sincerely struggled to decipher its relevance to Historiography and it took conversations to fellow students to decide on a idea, that being that culture is merely the rituals of power.

When Foucault is chronicling punishment and its uses by the royal authority and its change into punishment by state authority, it can be understood as an exercise of power to denote cultural change. His exploration of the purposes of Torture really demonstrate this.  Looking at culture in this way did however leave a sour taste in my mouth, particularly with Punishment.  The shift of Punishment from public torture to Prison was most interesting.  The message that punishment sends to the masses(for lack of a better word) that is the direction of power, as I understood it.

entry.title: Discipline and Punish-- The Birth of the Prison
entry.content:
Our reading for this week was a philosophical extavaganza, Discipline and Punish: The Birth of the Prison, by Michel Foucault.  Just in time for Halloween, part one offers a horrific scene of punishment through several forms of torture designed to mimick a trip to hell, ending with the offender, a regicide, being quartered and burned to ashes.  Nice!  Seriously, this is a very thoughtful and thought-provoking look at how our society deals with punishing criminals, and how their treatment reflects an evolution of our intentions in disciplining and punishing.  Spoiler alert, we (the public) have systematically removed ourselves from the equation.

The book takes us, with a mixture of chronology and topic, through the development of punishment as public spectacle, which prevailed until the late 17th century, through a reformist period typified by the Philadelphia prison, to the formation of our modern day prison system.  Foucault’s study is more than just a historical survey however, it is a study of the cutltural change that lead to how we envision discipline and punishment.  Foucault draws interesting parallels here to the idea of the fetishism of capitalism we’ve studies in previous readings.  “If economic exploitation seperates the force and the product of labour, let us ay that disciplinary coercion [imprisonment] establishes in the body the constricting link between an increased aptitude and an increased domination,” (pg 138).  In short, there is an underlying sociological theme to discipline and punishment that involves why we do it, and how we do it.  Our reasons and methods have changed over time to reflect our own evolving ideas of what the role of the prisoner in our society. 

Not all things have changed drastically, and not all things reflect the supposed more humain society we live in today.  This is the paradox Foucault presents us with.  The individual cell is a prime example.  A monachistic throwback that has gone through many uses in the history of the prison system, practically every inmate has an individual cell in the modern version.  On a final note, I found Foucault’s discussion of the prison system as business philosophy from the 18th century onward to be intriguing in light of current issues with prison systems in Arizona (a la their new immigration laws), and the ongoing search for a new Guantanamo.

entry.title: Off with Their Head
entry.content:
I first opened Foucault’s “Discipline and Punish: The Birth of the Prison” a while back.  After the first few pages I knew I would not have wanted to be a criminal, and I put it down.  After finishing it this week, it was interesting, and a little strange.  The writing was rough.  I’m guessing it was translated from French, which explains a bit.  I really hate it when a writer says something like, ‘there are four items of import. First,” and then there is never a second, third, or fourth, you just have to guess what the others are.  Once I got past that, it got a little better.  Moving from a tortured death to public executions, the idea was to make people not want to commit the crime, which was covered very graphically in the first chapter.  This was on the idea that the crime was essentially against the king, and he was exacting vengeance.
Once the move was made to reform the way punishment was handled, things began to change.  They still kept the different punishments for different social strata – gentlemen could not be imprisoned by commoners, but the idea of reforming the criminal came about.  The old adage of letting the punishment fit the crime (104) and making crime not glamorous were nice.  You can see a lot of modern prison ideas in the old reforms as well.  Like the idea of a punitive city, (113) sounds like the old penal farms, and placards and hats to distinguish the inmates gave way to prison jumpsuits.  They also caught on that locking people up for all offenses would simply not work, so let’s retrain them went the idea.  Along with time off for good behavior, you can see the Protestant work ethic being administered here in the idea that if they are taught to like work they will not return to criminal ways.
The panopticon was an ingenious idea. I kind of thought of it like the surveillance cameras at the store.  You’re not sure if the camera inside that black ball is looking at you or not, and this is to keep down shoplifting.  Now, image a place where they beat you with a stick if the eye in the sky sees you get out of line.  After all this fun, we move onto the retraining of the criminal by educating them, putting them to work at different endeavors, even the idea of chain-gangs to control order.  Yet, the author seems to return all the while to the idea that all the prisoners are really learning is how to be better criminals.
In the end we see that the prison and punishment of criminals and delinquents are born within the society that produces them.  If there was a way to remove the criminal desire from the person it would be a wonderful world.  However, because there is a little outlaw in all of us, the prison will forever be within our society.

entry.title: Empathy, Culture, and the past
entry.content:
Just my personal opinion, but yes you need to be able to understand how a people feel about something to be able to write a proper history of them that is more than just facts and figures.  An example would probably be in order here.  Let’s take the Powhattans and the Jamestown colonists.  You can give facts and figures like, this many died, this and that happened, and so on and so forth.  However, to actually advance an idea of why this and that happened, to look at the social history of the situation, one has to get inside the mind of the participants.  In the case of the English, you can research the teachings of that time, the education that many had, the experiences leading up to the colonization, and a host of other items to enter the mindset of the people.  I think it was Thor Heyerdahl that called this emulsion in the past living history.  I’m not saying that you have to go so far as to live the experience by spending a week at the Jamestown settlement, but to speculate what the motive for actions were requires a more anthropological approach.  The idea of the past as a foreign country to me does not mean that it is something that will always be unknown.  It means that it is something that is different from my own views and perspectives and when writing about it one must always remember that yours is one view among many.
Culture is significant when it comes to history, but I would not say it is more important than personal experience or class location as it pertains to the historical character you are researching.  Looking at a society as a whole, culture is still one aspect.  There are several layers of society.  Take America for instance; we are considered to have a culture of consumerism and all are capitalists.  Yet, there are different groups within America that would differ from that assumption; like the Amish, Mennonites, socialists and communists groups, and many others.  Yes, culture is import to understand some things but it can’t answer all things.

entry.title: Discipline and Punish
entry.content:
Hmmm, last week the wink, this week the gaze…

The cover of this book says it’s about the birth of the prison, and the title includes the word punish. I was not looking forward to reading it, and the first chapter more than confirmed my trepidation. It went beyond making a point to pure sensationalism. I was in a pretty foul mood as I began the rest of the book.

However, even with a bad attitude and three nights of inadequate sleep, this book managed to be better than I’d dreaded. Within the framework of narrating the evolution from bodily punishment that proved the monarch’s power to internal discipline and training as a more subtle and pervasive way to control behavior, Foucault made several observations that I appreciated. And then, rereading a book for my historiography project, I thought I recognized an idea, and—yes!—Gorski had indeed included Foucault in his bibliography. I feel like maybe I have a toe in the doorway to this club called History.

So, here are a few of the thoughts I had, in no particular order, since my brain is apparently on strike.

Pg 98-99 different punishments for different people: this is still true for teaching and parenting (an association I made over and over through this book, by the way) but we don’t seem to apply it much for criminals, beyond cushy prisons for some and nasty prisons for others. I wonder what stands in the way of discovering a criminal’s button and then pushing it, instead of just using incarceration for everyone.

It’s not the severity of punishment that’s its best deterrent; it’s the certainty of punishment. I found that was true with teaching. I could have a ridiculously minor punishment, but because it was so consistently applied, it really did keep the kids from misbehaving. I wish we could apply this to greater society. If jail were shorter but certain, with no hope of evading the police or getting off for some technicality, maybe it would be a better deterrent. Really, after seeing what power a two-minute detention had, I’d believe most anything.

He returned often to the relationship between power and knowledge. He kept the discussion pretty close to his theme of prisons and punishment, but they interact in dozens of other ways in our society, too—lobbyist, expert testimony, psychologists overriding common wisdom, nutritional fads, scientists on a pedestal, and so on. The person with the knowledge does have power over those who don’t really know. It works in arguments, too.

Observation is an element of power. How does that speak to anthropologists who observe groups of people—does that give them power over those groups? Are there different kinds of observation, or just different uses for the results? Observation yields knowledge, so that’s related to the knowledge/power connection. And again with the teaching—the better I knew my students, the more clearly I knew their buttons and could adjust their carrots and sticks. I just can’t get over how often this book was just parenting/teaching writ large. No wonder I wanted out of public schools!

It does bug me that I don’t see why this book was included in the syllabus. What did it contribute to the development of historiography? What was Foucault’s new angle or insight or paradigm?

entry.title: Foucault and Power
entry.content:
When I started reading this book, two things struck me immediately—first, this was much more interesting than I expected, and secondly, I had no idea how it connected to historiography.

I quickly got at least one of the points. The opening section of Discipline and Punish shows a fundamental shift in Western thought not only on punishment but on the concept of the body and personal rights. The section, Torture, discusses the marked change from atrocity to humaneness in punishment rituals, looking at how it went from reflecting the horror of the crime physically back onto the criminal to having to demonstrate the humaneness of the ruler. This is really a description of the power dynamic between ruler and people; a breach of the law is a personal affront to the sovereign, requiring a display of the sovereign’s power in order to rectify the challenge to his authority. The punishment is a ritual that confirms the ruler’s power, and the societal model based on the ruler’s power—the torture, the punishment, the confessions, etc., all are part of a rectifying of a breach of power.

The idea that comes across most heavily, at least to me, is that culture and society are based on power relationships, and within this text punishment and law are the power relationship between the sovereignty of the ruler and/or the state in relation to the people. Activities like torture, imprisonment, etc., are all “rituals of power,” the trappings of these power relationships that allow it to function.

The changes throughout the rest of the book, the change in punishment in general, is representative of both a change in government and a change in the perception of the body and its relationship to individual rights.

Foucault wasn’t as intimidating as I thought. This is an interesting book, because I would not have thought that you could use such a specific historical analysis to explain a greater philosophy of history, but it worked out really well.

entry.title: Empathy
entry.content:
Many people confuse empathy and sympathy. Empathy doesn’t mean sharing someone’s feelings, or having pity on them; it means recognizing that they have feelings (and motivations, assumptions, fears, etc) and that they are, in fact, humans and not objects. As such, empathy is fundamental to any human interaction, unless it’s some inhuman, brutal force of power where one treats another as an object. Maybe one aspect of severe autism is that those children don’t have empathy, and so can’t understand and interact with other people.

In any case, if historians are studying people, real human beings, they need to have empathy for their subject. Historians need to—as much as possible—understand who those people were inside, what motivated the behaviors under examination. Figuring out the reasons for events requires empathy, and provides coherence and significance to the description of those events. If a historian somehow managed to study an era without empathy for it, the write up would be a list of random, disconnected impressions that create confusion instead of clarity. That’s not history. Statistics, maybe, but not history.

entry.title: 10/28 Foucault
entry.content:
I’m going out of town this weekend and I’m not certain when I’ll be back, so writing this early…

After reading the Foucault book, I can certainly tell that he has philosophical leanings. Not being much of a philosopher myself, or being someone who cares for the subject, I’m not completely certain what to make of this book. I really enjoyed the first half of the book in which he discusses the public nature of penance and the ways in which it was imposed on the body (largely because the idea of the “public” and corporeal history are two fields that greatly interest me), but after that, around halfway through, I felt as though Foucault really lost his grounding in history and the philosophy took over. At times, it felt more like he was simply creating points for his argument rather than basing them in actual fact.

There’s a strong thread in the book, especially in the second half in which he discusses private penance in the penitentiaries, in which Foucault really seems to almost prefer the public, body-based penance. In discussing his antipathy toward newer forms of societal discipline, I think he goes too far in equating the soul-based, regimented penance of prisons with, for instance, reforms in the public schools (educational issues are a topic for a different post). Nevertheless, his assertion that private punishment was primarily a deterrent toward others considering committing the same crime rather than an actual chastisement for the offender is interesting; however, I think the same could apply to public body-based punishment as well. Similarly, toward the end of the book Foucault discusses ways in which the new types of penance are centered in the hands of the state. However, discipline had always been a part of the state, in the sense that it was in the purview of the king, as Foucault notes. Additionally, in the pre-modern era, church and state were not separated in the way that they are today; thus, ecclesiastical punishments carried out by the Inquisition can be considered a type of state-based discipline.

Thus, there were parts of this week’s reading that I enjoyed and parts with which I disagreed. I’m interested to know what everyone else thought, and I’m looking forward to the discussion on Monday.
