entry.title: Empahy and cultural relativism
entry.content:
I think empathy is certainly required of the historian, as it relates to the cultural relativism of anthropology. The historian cannot become a participant-observer of the past, but I think it is her/his duty to be sensitive to ideals/thoughts/realities of the past. As historians, we attempt to understand the past society that we study as much as possible; only then can we begin our studies. As Sahlins pointed out in his article, there are some tribal groups in which societal knowledge and history is absorbed by the tribal leader. Without understanding that, or by association the ways in which past societies functioned, we miss a key point about that period/group, and we are unable to do relevant history about it. We risk projecting our modern, western views, morals, and norms onto another group for which they would be alien. That being said, our work is grounded in documents and evidence. Thus, the understanding and empathy that historians espouse should be rooted in what we can know or discern about a society, not what we imagine for it.

I’ve purposefully avoided the phrase “a culture” in the above paragraph, so that the idea of culture could be addressed here. I think culture is the evolving intellectual construct by which societies operate—intellectual and not also physical, because we discussed in class Monday, and as found in Geertz, an eye twitch is an eye twitch. It is how we consciously react to the twitch that gives it relevant meanings. I don’t believe that culture is most significant object of historical inquiry, but it is certainly an indispensable one. With it, we can attempt to make sense of historical actors and actions, but there are other considerations. As James Wilson noted in his post, the importance given to culture depends on what we find in the documentary evidence.

entry.title: Empathy and Cultural Relativism
entry.content:
In many respects, empathy is a polarizing concept similar to objectivity—it is either a goal to be sought or a mental construct which can cloud historians’ judgment of the evidence.  To be sure, the latter is quite plausible, and most historians would agree that identifying too closely with peoples under investigation is a danger.  Improperly used, empathy can tend towards simple imagination and perhaps even counterfactual flights of fancy.  It can also tend toward over-identification with historical actors.  Though it may be admirable and entirely warranted in certain instances, over-empathizing can cause sympathy for historical actors, which is an obvious threat to the historian’s judgment.

On the other hand, historical empathy offers a way to recognize the differentness of the past, and to understand the variety of perspectives held by historical actors.  In this sense, empathy offers a window to understanding the question of why historical groups or figures acted the way they did.  In situations with minimal or contradictory evidence, empathy could be a useful tool because it brings historical events away from theoretical constructs or dispassionate words on a source document and places it back in human scale.  In certain instances, then, empathy is a useful tool in abductive reasoning (which is much better way of describing what is otherwise historical “guesswork”). 

Empathy thus has its pros and cons, but which side is the historian to take in the discussion?  Perhaps the safest answer is to say that empathy is a useful tool to be used in moderation.  The greatest benefit of empathy is its ability to bring the story of history back to the human level so that readers may better understand the past.  Empathy also permits the historian to frame research in useful ways when sources are problematic.  Over-indulgence, however, is to be avoided as it may diminish the effectiveness of professional research.   

From this framework, understanding culture is an important part of understanding the past.  Defining culture then is a key to understanding the past.  Culture seems to be the intellectual framework within which a given society operates.  Understanding culture, then, creates a lens through which we may view the events of a given time relative to their setting and actors.  As historians, it allows us to make connections between events, people, places, movements, and ideas which may not otherwise be evident.  Culture, however, is not necessarily the most important factor in understanding the history of a given time or place; culture’s importance depends on what the evidence shows. 

Tangentially related then, is the difference between history and anthropology: anthropology, at its most basic is a search for definitions, to define the human condition; at its root, history is search to answer questions of why events played out as they did.  To be sure, there is a sense of cultural relativism which comes with connecting past events to the society which brought them about.  As historians, however, we are bound by a sense of evidentiary relativism which compels us to form our judgments according to what the sources tell us.  Cultural relativism can be used to complete the picture, so to speak, but as professionals we are tied to our sources.

entry.title: empathy, cultural relativism, and the past as a foreign country
entry.content:
I’m curious, given the truncated nature of our discussion on Monday, where you all stand now on the question, “Does a historian need empathy to understand the past?” If we continue pushing the notion that the past is a foreign country, the historian has no opportunity to become a participant observer of that past. But, does the historian have the obligation, or at least should the historian have the obligation to approach that past culture with the anthropologist’s cultural relativism?

Finally, is “culture”, and however you define that term, an indispensable object of historical inquiry? Is it the most significant? How do you define it?

I’d like to hear more from you, so post a comment below, or make a new post if you feel so compelled. Let the conversation continue…

entry.title: Thoughts on Anthropology
entry.content:
I very much enjoyed this extract as Clifford Geertz uses  his study of Moroccan culture at the time of French occupation to explain the very core of anthropology because I have done past research into French occupation of Morocco, it really touched a good cord with me.  Anthropology as a school of thought has great merits to be exploited by historians,and in my view should aid me in understanding Medieval Spain or Morocco for that matter.   But like all schools of thought it has shortcomings, as a historian I always struggle with generalizations, however I enjoy the social norms they set as cultural standards as they make historical interpretations easier.

I enjoyed Geertz’ synthesis of anthropology as a school of thought that busies itself with the same “realities that others-historians, economists, political scientists, sociologists- confront in more fateful settings: Power, Change, Faith, Oppression, Work, Passion, Authority, Beauty, Violence, Love, Prestige…” but the anthropologist concerns himself with taking “the capital letters off them.”

Concerning the Book Barber and Berdam, The Emperor’s Mirror. Tucson: Univ. of Arizona Press, 1998, I thought it was a fantastic intro into anthropology and ethno-history, and I particularly enjoyed ethno-history as it combined Anthropological approach and history into one as I had discussed earlier.

entry.title: 10/24/10 Ethnohistory
entry.content:
The Emperor’s Mirror was an interesting read. It was much more like an instruction manual than I had anticipated, and I think it would have been well suited to an undergrad methods course. At the same time, I see its benefit for giving us an overview of what ethnohistory is. I appreciated the long methods section because I think many of the techniques would be relevant to any historian, not just those undertaking ethnohistory itself. As a medievalist, I’ll certainly have to do my share of paleography, and even though there are certainly more advanced/specialized books out there for medieval paleography, this was a nice introductory overview of some concerns to be aware of.

The reality-mediation model, as I understand it, seems such a straightforward idea that it’s surprising that no one had articulated it before. Or, perhaps, it was just such a common tenet that no one felt the need to actually write it out before this book. As I see it, the model states that authors, either consciously or unconsciously, modulate reality/the Truth when they create documents. Perhaps by purposefully leaving out or altering information or perhaps by subconsciously not noticing the importance of an event, an author’s record of events does not exactly equate with what happened. As we discussed last week, this shows up in inaccurate eyewitness testimonies of crime scenes today. As historians, we must be careful when reading primary documents to tease out any biases from the author, and to avoid, as much as possible, mediating the reality, however altered it may already be, found in the primary source.

Geertz’s article emphasized the public nature of culture and the importance of thick description and emergence into a society to understand its culture, as a way of explaining anthropology. The wink/twitch example was really helpful to latch onto throughout the article. Sahlins asserts that anthropology and history, even though they sometimes reach different conclusions and have different methods, can be used to inform each other. I liked his example that for some tribes, the “history of the leader” approach isn’t as outdated as we tend to universally think it is. For some groups, the tribal identity is subsumed into the knowledge and person of the leader; thus, a chronicle of the chieftain is a chronicle of the tribe, at least from the internal perspective of the group under study.

entry.title: Ethnohistory Reminders
entry.content:
Barber and Berdan’s The Emperor’s Mirror is a book that I thoroughly enjoyed reading. I spent a semester as an Anthropology major at Tulane, after my year-long foray into Theatre and before I made the final switch to History, so I enjoyed reading about ethnohistory as a discipline—the combination of anthropology and history (yes, yes, I know it can be a combo of a dozen other things too) was one that felt relatively comfortable to me, even though my anthropology background is now six years behind me. Wow. I’m feeling a little old.

The first part of this book, while overly basic, was actually very helpful to me. From what I can tell, this is really an introduction to the field, the kind of thing you would use as a textbook in an introductory ethnohistory class, but, frankly, that made it more valuable. My anthro skills are rusty, so having them refreshed was nice, and the terminology used helped me continue fleshing out my own identity as a historian. I didn’t need primary and secondary sources redefined for me, but the terms they used afterwards… well, I’m apparently more interested in personal influence than social forces, though I recognize the value of the latter and use it quite a bit; I think I’m also a bit of an ideationalist, though that might just be a backlash at three weeks of materialism—I still understand and value materialism, but I like the concept that human behavior is primarily shaped by ideas, ideologies, and values. Maybe I’m just naïve. That’s always a possibility. I’m also very much a believer in the conflict theory of human interactions, though this is not always the case, and I am very much a stochastic. I’m so glad that word exists and that I know it now. Chance, chaos theory, random happenstance—oh yeah, that definitely has a role in history.

The second section wasn’t quite as useful personally, though I like that it is a reminder of the wide variety of sources that we can and should use. Obviously, historians know that documents have to be looked at carefully because of bias and what-not, but the number of methods and source types they look at was a good little refresher. The paleography section in particular I enjoyed, as I am really excited for the year-long paleography/history of the book course next year with Drs. Burman and Lafferty. The reminder than pictographs, glyphs, runes, hieroglyphs, etc. are all writing styles, the brief description of ways of writing, the number and abbreviation segments—I’m going to learn a lot more about all of these, and this section pretty much wet my whistle. The calendrics bit was my favorite, I think—I’m doing my capstone fro Marco on Anglo-Saxon England, and the debate over the dating of Easter is pretty important in the whole Celtic v. Roman Christianity debate, so a section on the use of calendar and dating systems, and what they can tell us about both history and a people’s culture was a nice reminder. Linguistics, toponymy, source analysis, etc. were all nice, but they kept reminding me that this really is an introductory book.

The book will definitely be something I keep in mind when I start teaching—I think it could be great for an undergraduate course, like an Intro. to Historical Study or something like that—the chapters are useful introductions to the use of a variety of sources, the appendixes were fun, and the bibliography had a number of texts I want to check out later. It was pretty basic, though, so I was hoping for something a bit more in depth when I turned to the articles. Also, I have to admit that I didn’t see how different ethnohistory was from the kinds of work I already try to do; maybe that means I’m just doing a better job than I thought, or maybe I just missed the point—I don’t think so, though.

“Other Times, Other Customs” by Marshall Sahlin, an article on the anthropology of history, is a lovely little piece, which begins by reconciling cultural/social history with political history, arguing that the political history of kings, the so-called “big man theory,” only works out because of the cultural construction that gives them so much power, allowing them “a disproportionate historical effect.” I thought this was a neat little argument. He also argues essentially that heroic figures and kings are social constructs, that even if they do exist they are really markers of cultural concerns and interests, given power in order to represent specific things to the culture they come out of.

Sahlin looks at a wide variety of cultures to construct his arguments, mostly Pacific Islanders compared to the Western world—Fijians and the Myceneans, Maori and the Greeks, interactions between the islanders and colonizing powers, etc. His final argument is in favor of a historical anthropology, essentially ethnohistory, but with an anthropological focus rather than a historical one.

The other article, the first chapter of Clifford Geertz’s The Interpretation of Cultures, looks at culture as “webs of significance” around man, and Geertz attempts to construct a way of looking at the meanings of culture beneath their enigmatic surfaces. He discusses the basics of anthropology in this section, which was a useful refresher of my Intro. to Anthropology class from my freshman year. He discusses what ethnography is, and argues that it is less observational and more interpretive, regardless of what people might believe, and that analysis, therefore, is a very important part of what anthropologists do. He defines culture as what people do, and sees behavior as a symbolic act, arguing that the only important question as a result is “what their import is,” what any act of culture says about the group.

His mention of cognitive anthropology brought up unpleasant memories of the class that caused me to drop the Anthro major.

Geertz’s article, to me, was more helpful than Sahlin’s. I like in Sahlin’s that he uses a wide variety of cultures from different areas, but otherwise the article did very little for me. Geertz’s article was a refresher course, on the other hand, and reminded me a number of things I used to know about anthropology. I think anthro. is a very useful tool for a historian, and I’m looking forward to this week’s discussion.

entry.title: Emperor's Mirror
entry.content:
The Emperor’s Mirror: Understanding Cultures through Primary Sources was an incredibly helpful and accessible book focusing on ethnohistory, particularly, and historiography, generally. It was in many ways a how-to-guide for beginning historians, detailing methods, theories, and possible pitfalls that those in the field would benefit from being familiar with. It introduced various ethnohistorical terms, particularly in part I: “Concepts,” although definitions were sprinkled through the next two sections, as well. The Concepts chapter established the theories to be occasionally referred to in the rest of the book (such as various assumptions and the use of models). It goes through the changing definitions of ethnohistory and finally settles on “an interdisciplinary field that studies past human behavior and is characterized by a primary reliance on documents, the use of input from other sources when available, a methodology that incorporates historiography and cultural relativism, and a focus on cultural interaction”(12).

This section also defines different approaches and philosophies behind ethnohistory and explains the importance of models to clarify ideas. Some opposing approaches are emic vs. etic(using the world-view of the subject or the historian as the basis for analysis), particularist vs, nomothetic(using specific case studies or looking at broad, generalities), or personal influence vs. social forces as the chief determinant of individual actions or events(16-17). After this, it examines particular assumptions that some ethnohistorians make, also in diametric pairings. Ideationalist vs. materialist and conflict vs. consensus are two examples of assumptions used to explain the supposed driving forces behind all human actions(19). The final section of the book, “Strategies” summed up the practical application component of this book as a directive for successful research topics. Barber and Berdan manage to offer their suggestions delicately, carefully qualifying their findings as possibilities for other scholars to consider.

The Methods section, which makes up the bulk of the book was the most engaging for me, personally. While the other two sections were certainly helpful, this section was filled with not only recommendations for scholarship but also intriguing examples. The case studies at the end of the chapters were applied well to the topics previously discussed, but I thought the examples given in the rest of the text were actually the most enlightening, some examples of which I have decided to mention: The complex nature of pictographs was clearly exhibited, as was the varying nature of alphabetized language(53-66). I really enjoyed the sections on spelling, names, spellings, and calendars. I was fascinated to discover that ten days were removed from history and that the ten days were different in various places due to the centuries it took to convert all of Europe to the Gregorian calendar (October 5-14, 1582 according to the Pope, December 10-19, 1582 in Paris, France, not until the 18th century in America, pages 82, 86). I similarly had no idea that many of the spelling changes that differentiate American and English spellings can be traced back to the decisions of one individual, Noah Webster. I had also often thought that certain spellings clearly favor some dialects over others (for example, based on my Rochesterian accent, I always want to spell emperor “emporer”), but it was interesting to see this validated in this book, as Barber and Berdan note of the language codification efforts of the William Caxton in 1476 who admittedly chose the London accent as his base(67).

Source Analysis was also a helpful part of this book, detailing not only physical and content analysis for spotting forgeries, but also for designating a source’s value. This was followed by discussion on the benefits, possible pitfalls, and methods of quantitative analysis, then visual sources, with maps in its own chapter. Then, in a fitting final chapter of this section, the book discusses recognizing complementary sources and combining one’s analysis to utilize both. As mentioned before, the examples used throughout this section made it more enjoyable for me to read and made historical study seem once again like an exciting pursuit, not just a daunting task.

entry.title: Understanding Context
entry.content:
The Emperor’s Mirror, Barber & Berdan | “Thick Description,” Geertz | “Other Times, Other Customs,” Sahlins

The Emperor’s Mirror presented as a good introduction to the field of ethnohistory.  From an operational definition of ethnohistory as an “interdisciplinary field that studies past human behavior and is characterized by a primary reliance on documents, the use of  from other sources when available, a methodology that incorporates historiography and cultural relativism, and a focus on cultural interaction,” the authors set about to explain the intricacies of field’s methodologies and basic assumptions.  Interestingly, the authors seemingly reject the established methodologies for their own construct of “reality-mediation” in which sources are viewed as texts that mediate and simultaneously distort the external realities they record.  Within this framework, therefore, it is the historian’s task to describe the external reality as presented by sources and to explain the effect of the sources’ innate perspectival inadequacies.  On the whole, the book was interesting, though I often found the authors’ literary style lacking.  It is an excellent introductory textbook for exploring ethnohistory. 

“Thick Description” by Geertz expressed much the same sentiment.  According to him, ethnography is a field of interpretation—it assumes that “culture is composed of psychological structures by means of which individuals or groups of individuals guide their behavior” (11).  Because “culture is a context,” an unengaged objective point of view is removed from reality as the details needed to “comprehend a particular event, ritual, custom, idea, or whatever, is insinuated as background information before the thing itself is directly examined” by the source or observer (13, 9).  At its essence, then, ethnography is simply an attempt to understand culture.

Sahlins’ “Other Times, Other Cultures” sets out to prove a rather simple point that “different cultural orders have their own modes of historical action, consciousness, and determination—their own historical practice” (518).  In establishing an investigatory framework, the author argues that “history is culturally constructed from the bottom up … [and is based on] the prevailing inclinations of the people in general” (517).  History, therefore, is a given culture’s hybridized consensus of its participants’ individual actions. The author sets about supporting his position through several very complicated discussions, however, and I fear that I may have misjudged the impact of his argument.

entry.title: hist510 Ethnohistory
entry.content:
Unlike several of the books that have been assigned this semester, I found that I could offer no real complaints about The Emperor’s Mirror. I felt this was an extremely well-done book that provided a great deal of useful information in a stylistically enjoyable manner. Although much of what the book contained was not necessarily new information, it was nonetheless useful to have some basic methodological approaches clarified and expanded upon. Many of the points Barber and Berdan brought up were, for me at least, familiar considerations that had been introduced since I began my historical training in undergraduate college. Regardless of any former acquaintance with these foundational factors, I still found it enlightening to have issues such as the influence of background, complications with evidence, and basic research methods directly addressed. 

Reading this book was particularly interesting following Peter Novick’s That Noble Dream. Ethnohistory as put forth in The Emperor’s Mirror seemed to assume that objectivity is an impossible goal, although Barber and Berdan would not consider objectivity to be a desirable end in the first place. I have always been a little uncertain as to the exact definition of ethnohistory, and this book did a great deal toward clarifying some of the questions I had regarding this new approach. Personally, I felt that the differences between history and ethnohistory were quite subtle; as a historian, I am still not sure I entirely agree with ethnohisory’s identity as a completely separate phenomenon from historical study. It seemed that ethnohistory’s methodological approach would work well as a sub-area of the historical profession as well, although I am sure the same argument could be made for incorporating it into anthropology just as there is a valid argument for its independent existence. 

I found myself agreeing with much of what Barber and Berdan defined as ethnohistory, particularly in relation to the goal of ethnohistory. Relativism has a much-respected place within this methodological approach, as I believe appropriate when attempting to study the interaction of different societies in the distant past. I especially enjoyed the distinction that ethnohistorians were attempting to provide a medium through which the past could be viewed, to create an understandable discourse with the past that allows modern readers access to a completely different world. As the authors stressed, ethnohistory embraces a multiplicity of interpretations rather than seeking a universal, or even generally consensual, explanation. The Emperor’s Mirror does a good job at providing a convincing argument for the existence of and acceptance of this diversity. As almost all historians acknowledge, the background and experience of individual authors necessarily affect their perception of historical events. Although evidentiary differentiations are just as important when explaining the past, this factor does not often receive the same degree of attention. I felt that the extensive treatment Barber and Berdan devoted to highlighting the many possible interpretations the same piece of evidence could have, for both contemporaries and modern historians, to be one of the most useful and interesting parts of the books. I believe most historians are aware of evidentiary complications, but personally I will be much more conscious of such difficulties than I was prior to reading this book.

Geertz’s excerpt likewise dealt with the emergence of ethnohistory as a methodological approach. Geertz’s work was a more theoretical piece than The Emperor’s Mirror and focused on the idea of providing “thick description,” where thick description provides for the subtle meanings societies attribute to actions according to cultural norms. Ethnohistory as described by Geertz seemed to resemble anthropology more strongly than the historical tinge it had in Barber and Berdan’s book, which doubtless contributed to his emphasis on the interpretation of culture. According to Geertz, culture is a public phenomenon that provides the framework against which meaning is attributed. I found Geertz’s example of the wink versus twitch to be particularly enlightening. Another interesting point was his assertion that ethnohistorians should attempt to capture the individuality of cultures while still exposing “normalness,” or general patterns. Drawing this distinction reminded me of an earlier week’s debate on the validity of grand theories as opposed to localized studies, which we likewise concluded was best solved by a compromise between the two. Although the reading for this week did not strictly deal with the historical profession, I still found them to be some of the most interesting and helpful works so far.

entry.title: Reflections on Sahlins, Geertz, and Barber and Berdan
entry.content:
Within ethnography and historical anthropology are found some intriguing ideas about and approaches toward the gathering of historical knowledge. And the writers named above attempt, with varying degrees of success, to explain those ideas.

Of the three works, I found Sahlins’ “Other Times, Other Customs: The Anthropology of History” to be by far the least accessible. I see and understand the thesis provided on Page 518, there are some interesting historical tidbits scattered throughout, and yet I still had a difficult time discerning the manner in which all of it fits together to illustrate the point the writer is trying to make in this short but still rather prolix essay.

To a lesser extent, Geertz’s “Thick Description: Toward an Interpretive Theory of Culture” also suffers from a lack of tight focus. I understand the concept of, and have in fact practiced, thick description. Still, I found it difficult to follow the writer’s train of thought, insofar as all included concepts interrelate. On the other hand, the essay was enlivened by several engaging passages, such as these:

  • “(W)hat we call our data are really our own constructions of other people’s constructions of what they and their compatriots are up to.”
  • “(C)ulture [is located] in the minds and hearts of men” (quote from Ward Goodenough).
  • “Understanding a people’s culture exposed their normalness without reducing their particularity.”
  • “(I)t is not necessary to know everything in order to understand something.”
  • “Cultural analysis is intrinsically incomplete. And, worse than that, the more deeply it goes, the less complete it is.”
  • “(I)f you want to understand what a science is, … you should look at what the practitioners of it do.”
This latter gem encapsulates a sentiment also found in Barber and Berdan’s book, “The Emperor’s Mirror: Understanding Cultures Through Primary Sources.” Comprising an exhaustive look at the work of ethnohistorians, this work at the same time is wholly engaging and accessible; therefore, it was the reading I enjoyed most.

Although the information regarding concepts and strategies was informative and well-presented, my favorite aspect was Part 2, which dealt with methods. More specifically still, as someone with interests in language and genealogy, I was engrossed by the chapters on paleography and interpretation of names. (As an aside, though, I am a lifelong Southerner, and my family’s roots in this region stretch back some 300 years; still, I have never known anyone named “Bobby Don” [Page 136]).

All in all, I feel that Barber and Berdan succeed especially well in making clear the basics of their discipline.

entry.title: Ethnohistory and "Thick Description"
entry.content:
Our readings for this week were Toward an Interpretive Theory of Culture, by Clifford Geertz, Other Customs: The Anthropology of History, by Marshall Sahlins, and The Emperor’s Mirror, by Russel Barber and Frances Berdan.  These readings give an interesting view of the contemporary thought on what it means to do anthropology, and some time-honored practices to aid in the practice of anthropology and ethnohistory.  The Emperor’s Mirror, published in 1988, offers is set up like an instructionl manual for performing ethnohistory, and many of the tips and sundry case studies could also easily cross over to the study of history.  The book offers many avenues of approach for dealing with primary sources with the purpose of performing a micro to macro style historical research which is where it derives its ethnographic influence. 

The Anthropology of History, published in 1983, also stresses this micro to macro method of doing history.  “The idea is that history is culturally constructed from the bottom up: as the precipitate, in social institutions and outcomes, of the prevailing inclinations of the people in general,” (pg 517).  With this in mind this essay also stresses that the historian always be mindful that earch culture has its own mode of historical activity and its own historical consciousness that may look very different from our own.  The idea of Heroic History in many cultures is used as an example, as it varies in form from the European idea that the “theory of history is that social outcomes are the cumulative expressions of individual actions,” (pg525).

Thick Description, first published in 1973, contends that many old anthropological notions, such as Skinnerian behaviorism, objectivism and operationalism are no longer viable in ethnography.  ‘Thick description’ is instead an attempt at proper interpretation of the symbols that every culture uses in order to discover the context behing a subject’s actions.  Conversely, the objective detailing of a person or cultures actions with no regard to their context if ‘thin description.’  Ultimately, Geertz asserts, ethnography is, at its heart, an interpretive activity, and not an observational one, because things “we call our data are really our own constructions of other people’s constructions of what they and their compatriots are up to.”  “Most of what we need to comprehend a particular event, ritual, custom, idea, or whatever is insinuated as background information before the thing itself is directly examined,” (pg 9).  So, beyond the good practices of observation and dilligence in collecting information required by the historian as well as the ethnographer, it is also crucial that the researcher becomes very skilled in the art of cultural interpretation as well.

entry.title: Reaction to Berber and Berdan…
entry.content: As an introduction to  a subject, this book felt like a hand book nearly to the point of distraction by monotony. However, given what they were attempting to do it  seems to require a systematic approach. However, it seems like the primary difference between this and a potential handbook for historical studies is merely one of interest. History, it seems,  has become a polyglot and has absorbed in many ways culture, literature, art, and archeology. It felt a little like Barber and Berdan through  ”Ethnohistory” was either attempting to do the same thing or were simply applying historical methods to a new set of criteria. Many of the examples  of “ethnohisotry” seem to include references either to non-native records of native doings (either in an imperial or exploratory setting) or of native records that through imperialism or nativization has lost some manner of native connection to the past. In one sense, Ethnohistory appears to be searching for precisely the type of history that is the hardest, using historical methods to come up with archeological or anthropological conclusions. In essence, it is searching for something which historians use but do not necessarily concentrate on: human “behavior” (taken from Barber and Berdan’s definition) which seems like a strange sub-group of history and something which seems only technically differentiated from the larger group.

entry.title: Questions for tomorrow….
entry.content:
Here are a few questions to ponder before tomorrow’s class…

Q#  1: In Chapter one, as Barber and Berdan begin to define ethnography and explain it’s methodology, in what ways if at all does it differ from our definition of history or (more importantly) in its methodology?

Q# 2: What is an eitlogue? (pg 37) How does it relate to the Reality-mediation model? What are the four ways in which Mediation effects the “true” communication of stimuli? (pg 39)

Q#3: In what sense does Barber and Berdan use “deconstruction”? Given the goals of this book, is this a choice? (44)

Q#4: What are some of the issues one must consider when engaging in Paleography?

Q#5: What factors go into the creation of a calendar and how do these determine how “time” is conceived by various cultures?

Q#6: What are some of the more nuanced properties, functions, or practices in language and how does this make translation difficult? Why do you think Poetry is considered more difficult to translate than “regular” prose?

#7: What can place names tell us? (120-125) What can an individual’s name tell us about them and how can this be confusing?

# 8: What are the internal and External Methods of Textual analysis?  What relationships must an author have in relation to an event they are reporting on to be considered not only authentic but authoritative?(Chapter 7)

#9: What are the potential pitfalls of quantitative analysis? What can be gained by it?

#10: In what ways are visual and textual analyses similar/ different? When describing the uses of visual media and the pitfalls in interpretation of these media, could many of the same principals apply to both written word and pictorial art?

#11: In what ways Is the study of Maps complicated by the fact that they are representations of a reality? In what ways are these complications tied to complications in textual or visual interpretations?

#12: What are the problems with using “oral accounts” as sources? Why do Barber and Berdan conclude that textual sources are better?

entry.title: Through the Mirror, Thickly, and Others
entry.content:
Mirror, Mirror, what can I see?
“The Emperor’s Mirror” is a deep book.  Lots of info about categorizing, analyzing, alphabetizing; if it could be zing-ed, it was covered.  Don’t get me wrong.  I found every bit of it quite interesting and informative.  I wish this book had been assigned in my undergrad days as part of the honors research program as we went over a lot of the same material but through different books and the instructor explaining these processes to us.  This one book put it all in one place.  I especially loved chapter 12.  Research design, or lack thereof, could make or break you as you push toward your goals.  This gave me much to ponder and it follows a lot of what we are pursuing in this class currently.  Finding a valid topic, getting a list of reading together, making a plan of how it fits, methods to use, things to watch out for, it is all very helpful to me.  Chapter 13 as well, Working in Archives and Elsewhere was quite helpful.  It is always important to remember that you can’t just “Google” everything.  Research has to involve going through archives, and talking with the archivist as some holdings are not listed in catalogs, but the curator knows they are there.  The last thing anyone would want to do is research something that has already been researched.  This is definitely a book I will keep to reference often as I proceed in historical research.

Thick Description
The excerpt Thick Description opens with a quick speech on trying to define culture.  Then, we get inundated with possible meanings and variations of what a wink/twitch could mean based on concepts of what our culture construes as a wink/twitch.  However, we did learn that this sorting out what it could mean is what ethnography is. (7) We also find that it is note-taking about what the ethnographer sees; this by his recounting of the sheep incident in Morocco, where we learn that identifying established codes is also important. (9) We get a decent overview of what culture is, and a little of what it is not – power.  We learn that in the end, the ethnographer studying a culture is only writing what he sees, analyzing those views, and not predicting anything from it only adding to the general knowledge about a certain people and their culture.

Other Times….
Marshall Sahlins started well wanting to support the idea of a “life of communities” (517) as opposed to an elite history.  It got murky when he began the heroic history section, but I tried to keep up.  With a history tied to kings it seemed a bit elitist, but I believe the point was the people saw their lives as tied to their king – the “cultural order” he called it. (520) That would explain why it is so hard to get a picture of regular people in ancient societies; their understanding of self was as a subordinate to those in charge.  Once he started with the New Zealand war of the Maori, I was almost totally lost.  The best I could come up with was that he was applying anthropological information to see the history of a people in a new light – one where the people constantly relive the heroic leader history of their society, just with new players.

entry.title: The Emperor's Mirror
entry.content:
This book was exceptionally clear and well organized, with lists, and definitions, and everything a control freak with a short attention span could want. It was liberally sprinkled with clever language and very elementary concepts. It should have been a very quick read. But, it was stuffed full of topics that reminded me of various events and situations throughout my life. The margins of my copy are full of references to these, and most of them I didn’t write down. The entire time I spent reading this book, I was visiting classes I’ve taught or taken, books I’ve read, jobs I’ve had, my grandma’s kitchen, trips I’ve gone on, and so on. So, while it’s obvious that this book is a great overview of and introductions to the field of ethno-history, with extensive references cited for further study, it’s much less obvious that it also makes a fabulous memory jogger. Apparently, I’ve been living as an ethno-historian without realizing it.

In between mental field trips, I enjoyed the book for its own sake as well. A lot of the information was stuff I’ve either learned or figured out long ago, but in between such momentous revelations like the difference between primary and secondary sources (memory of teaching third grade) were little tidbits like why people were so fond of brown ink long ago (59) which I’d often wondered about but never looked up, and a handy chart of when different places converted to the Gregorian calendar (86). I love it when my procrastination is rewarded like that.

I also appreciate their structure of giving just a general, introductory orientation of each subject area, and then referring to more complete sources. This enabled them to cover a lot of ground in a manageable volume, and to provide a very positive introduction for potential colleagues or supporters (like we discussed in class last week about the dangers of becoming obscure and then extraneous). I found myself thinking several times that this would be a great handbook for public school teachers, because they touch on so many topics that get covered in school, in such an accessible manner. Even the chapters I expected to dislike (calendars and maps) ended up being interesting, possibly because I knew the least about them before reading.

I do wonder, though, how ethno-history, as per the definition on page 12, differs from just plain history. Is it only in that last phrase, about cultural interaction? Because the rest of it is pretty much what I think of as history. Am I in LaLa Land again? What am I missing?


The “Thick Description” chapter was interesting and informative, but—probably because of the on-screen format—my notes are a list of random bits, like a magpie took them. I noted several observations about what constitutes culture, and what ethnographers do. The clearest analogy for me was comparing ethnography to diagnosing a patient. You need some expectations and experiences as a frame of reference (sort of like the research design from Barber and Berdan) but you mostly focus on what’s in front of you, fighting all the while against coloring your observations by those expectations and references.

“Other Times, Other Customs” was a slog. Either I was just too tired, or the screen aspect overcame me, or it was poorly written, but I did not tease out a main point that tied it together and gave it a reason for being written. The last page finally said, “Anthropologists rise from the abstract structure to the explication of the concrete event.” (534) This was interesting and well said, but I missed what the Fiji and Maori stories had to do with it. I’m looking forward to discussion, and hoping we’re about done with pdf’s. Although, I read plenty of them for my annotated bibliography and didn’t struggle…hmm, I’m leaning toward door number three now.

entry.title: Respons to Peter Novick's That Nobel Dream
entry.content:
Firstly, there is nothing more depressing for me than this quote: “it was not unusual for a bright young man to become\a full professor within a few years of receiving the doctorate, and to achieve national eminence before he was out of his thirties.”
over all, it seems like about half of the content of this book could be considered merely a collection of relatively minor incidents surrounded intentionally with a quality batch of witty quotes; that is not to say there isn’t much to be gained from this book,but it meanders more than it must.
Most Interesting to me in this book is the discussion of “relativism”; Novick, at one pint asks, “But what if authority ceased to be consesnual”?What is interesting is that the myriad of possible answers. There are those who subscribe to schools, which are internally relative to some work or collection of works on a theoretical level even if the standard is used with much variation. There are those who retreating history to making technical arguments surrounded by a larger review of the schools or individuals mention. Indeed, how Novick traces “relativism” is to my tastes the most interesting discussion in te whole book.

Tied to this discussion is Novick’s discussion of personality/ political leanings/ and personal “agenda” as we might call it today.  It is interesting that he seems to point to personality as a far more influential force than politics at least directly) in how they interpreted relativism. Perhaps one remove still further away, though certainly in the same vein, is that modern eyes pained to read both the pendantic attitudes of earlier writers (though recognizing the values) as well as the illusory and/or biased nature with which some people allowed to guide their research.  Some might say this means that we have learned to not trust anyone; it might be a bit closer to the truth to say that we learned to never trust ourselves.

entry.title: Thoughts on "That Noble Dream"
entry.content:
That Noble Dream: The “Objectivity Question” and the American Historical Profession by Peter Novick

This to me was a very entertaining book but above that It made me stop and think of my own understanding of history.   It managed to enlighten me on the greater discourse that seems ever present in modern historical writing, that being Objectivity vs Relativity. Two very difficult concepts to define, to my understanding Objectivity is the school of historical thought ever obsessed with obtaining Truth.  ”Truth is one, not perspectival.” Standing against this belief of a Truth within the Past are the relativists who embrace perspective and the multiplicity of relative truths, not simply one.

This dilemma really baffled me.  Where do I fall?  I realize that obtaining “THE Truth” from the past is seemingly impossible but the attempt must not  be abandoned.  When it comes to my understanding of Truth I would more likely fall with the relativists, but concerning my methods I would go with Objectivists as attempting  to undertake an understand of historical interpretations relative the “the historian’s[me] time, place, values, and purposes,” would bog down my work to no end.

Concerning my thoughts on Mark Bevir’s article,  it was a nice complement to the historical profession as he advocated a justification for objective knowledge outside the critiques “the historicity of our being, the influence of power on discourse, [and] the absence of any stable meanings” by applying by applying something very familiar in the historical tool box, Comparison.

entry.title: Reflections on Novick, Bevir and historical objectivity
entry.content:
Objectivity surely is an ideal that most of us would agree is worth striving for, even if we disagree regarding the extent to which it is attainable.

Peter Novick’s “That Noble Dream: The ‘Objectivity Question’ and the American Historical Profession” seeks to trace the evolution of attitudes toward that have accompanied the subject.

“‘Historical objectivity,’” he says, “is not a single idea, but rather, a sprawling collection of assumptions, attitudes, aspirations, and antipathies.” That said, he outlines some of those permutations, along with their causes and their effects.

In my estimation, Novick does an excellent job commingling his specific topic with the larger backdrop of American history. Therefore comprising, as it does, a more-or-less linear narrative, this work was one that I found highly engaging, and sometimes downright compelling.

His account of the rise of “professional” historians, their standards and their idea of truth was intriguing. Certainly, the 19th-century brick-making analogy was a good one.

I especially enjoyed Novick’s examination of how the historical profession’s development mirrored the socio-political history of U.S. from the Civil War era to the aftermath of World War I.

In the case of the former, I found it interesting to see another deviation from the idea that history is written by the victors: As pertains to slavery, the “War Between the States” and Reconstruction, “the southerners cared so much more about the points at issue that in the interests of professional comity it seemed wise to let them have their way.”

As for the cataclysmic effects of the “Great War,” American historians certainly were not immune, losing “the optimism and faith in progress which … had grounded their faith in objectivity,” Novick says.

It’s interesting to note that the subsequent relativism, which some said helped make World War II possible, certainly did not vanish after the latter global conflict.

And then there is this quote from Frederick Jackson Turner: “Each age writes the history of the past anew with reference to the conditions uppermost in its own time.” The fact that he wrote those words in 1891 would seem to put to rest any notion of historical revisionism as a new phenomenon.

Still, when thinking of changing attitudes toward certain once-revered historical figures and events, I cannot help but be struck by Novick’s position that in times past, “It was easy enough – indeed, requisite – that one take a loving attitude toward landmarks in the development of liberty and constitutionalism, or toward moments in the expansion of national power.”

Meanwhile, in his article “Objectivity in History,” Bevir attempts to set forth a “how-to.”

Certain of his principles, including the nature of truth and the importance of criticism, square nicely with ideas found in Novick’s work.

But Bevir takes matters a step further with his emphasis on “comparing rival webs of interpretations in terms of agreed facts,” in a “more or less continuous” fashion.

In doing so, he presents what seems to be a credible argument for a worthwhile approach to the pursuit of objectivity.

entry.title: 10/17 Novick
entry.content:
In Chapter 11, Novick notes that the post-WWII swing back to an historical consensus was like a pendulum swing back from the relativism of the interwar period. I had this idea throughout the book as the author presented his main narrative, apart from the side story and details of increasing numbers of professors and history doctorates awarded and the decreasing salaries. In reading the book, I felt that the pendulum was often driven by the societal contexts in which the historians were working: endowed positions that sought historians who fulfilled the views of donors, the interwar lack of optimism, for lack of a better word, and the general consensus found, at least superficially, after WWII.

Novick’s book was interesting, but sometimes difficult to wade through. I feel as though I’ve been presented with so many names and opposing ideas that I can’t keep them straight. Becker and Beard, who came up quite frequently, are certainly two who are memorable, with their relativist leanings.

Bevir’s article is an interesting take on objectivity and seems to be an attempt to reach a middle ground. Absolute objectivity cannot exist, contrary to the views of American historians c.1900, but complete relativism is also unwarranted. As a budding historian considering how objective it is possible to be, and how much my experiences/circumstances/life will color or should color my historical interpretations and writings, I can see merit in his idea that a type of objectivity can be found through comparison of theories and arguments with an eye toward finding where they agree and how they diverge. He draws an important distinction between responding to criticism through simple defense of a theory vs. altering or advancing that theory in response to critics.

Though I agree with that thrust of his argument, the article itself is a little too philosophical for me, and I take issue with some of the assertions he makes and the way he supports them. I often found that he used an extreme case as an example and then generalized the result to more moderate instances. The best example is his argument that because humans can perceive the difference between a dog and a wolf (and therefore continue to survive), human perceptions are generally true. There’s a biological, survival instinct that encourages us to know the difference between something we can trust and something that could eat us. The inability to perceive facts and correct theories in history may deny us a degree and subsequent employment in the historical field, but it, on its own, will not kill us…

entry.title: Objective comparisons
entry.content: Mark Bevir wants us to look at objectivity in history based on comparison.  It is his idea that objectivity can be found through debate between rival theories where the two sides can find some common ground on a subject.  The two parties then debate based on rules, which govern their intellectual honesty.  All of this sounds good until he goes into the part of the anthropologist and the tribe getting to an understanding where they can communicate about their world views, and compare the merits of each.  I have a question on that as it pertains to history.  Unless the tribe has a written history before contact, I would think that anything learned from the anthropologist will be incorporated into the tribe’s understanding of their own history.  Thus, that history is altered by the contact.  I think that a historian would rather record the tribe’s history untainted instead of discussing world views with them.  Would it not be more objective to learn their history rather than impose upon them yours?

entry.title: Objectivity
entry.content:
Mark Bevir’s article is an incisive look at historical objectivity; supporting the rejection of a “given past” and instead rooting objectivity in comparative study. The notion that history can be understood in terms of a “given past” has been rejected by Foucault, Gadamer, and Derrida, among others. Humans define things necessarily using present understandings, therefore historians cannot fully divorce ourselves from present assumptions inherent in our logic and reasoning. This means that “we cannot grasp the past as a presence, and that this threatens the very possibility of objective historical knowledge.”(329)

However, Bevir argues that “historical objectivity which relies on criteria of comparison, not on our having access to a given past”(329). He offers a rejection of empiricists, in line with Foucault, Gadamer, and Derrida, saying that “we do not have pure experiences. The nature of a perception depends on the perceiver”(330). However, Bevir does not discount human perception entirely. While any individual perception may be flawed, human capacity to perceive the world around them on the whole is generally reliable(341). I would go further to say that if we discount all human perceptions as inherently without value because they are depend on certain underlying assumptions and on subjective understanding, then we have nothing left to work with and all historical study becomes a moot point. Bevir also cleverly points out that there are underlying assumptions in the hard sciences, as well as the humanities, since all are based on human experience in some way(332).

Central to Bevir’s argument is a separation between “fact” and “truth.” He writes that “a fact is a piece of evidence which nearly everyone in a given community would accept as true (333). This denotes perception and theory as part of the observation. He argues that it is not the historians job (nor is the individual historian capable of) discerning universal “truths,” rather we must content ourselves with endeavoring to find what is most “correct,” based on available facts and objective interpretation(332).

Bevir then examines interpretations of Locke’s Two Treatises in accordance with his theory. He also points out the importance of intellectual honesty in remaining objective and advocates the necessity of collaboration at arriving at the best possible interpretations over time. Criticism needs to have a positive replacement to be of value, not simply attempt to demolish previous “webs of interpretations,” and historians must respond to criticism without blindly adhering to existing webs, but being open to new interpretations(337, 335). In this sense, I wonder if it would be fair to compare Bevir to Charles S. Peirce, in the idea that knowledge is only possible through prolonged, collaborative effort.

Sections I-III of Peter Novick’s book, That Noble Dream, relate to this article in a few ways. Most obviously, the subject of this work is also objectivity. Novick charts the differing notions and forms of objectivity in American historical scholarship, starting in the 19th Century with the founding of the American historical profession through the 20th Century(16). He also presents a difference between the understanding of fact and truth among some scholars(103). Additionally, in his evaluation of Turner, he also presents a passage from that historian that echoes Bevir’s arguments for intellectual honesty and having a web of interpretations. Turner argues that a historian is “the parent of a family of hypotheses; and …he is forbidden to fasten all his affections unduly upon any one”(92).

Particularly interesting to me was Novick’s attention to the way various wars have impacted how American historians interpreted objectivity and their role in society. First mentioned here is the drive to promote reconciliation and “nonpartisan” views of the Civil War(72). This then coupled with racism as a “consensual ‘usable past’” was also tied to Anglo-Saxon heritage and genetic “evidence” of black inferiority(74-76). This philosophy was extended backward to revision the history of the American Revolution, as well(82). Objectivity was challenged during and after WWI, as “many historians lost the optimism and faith in progress which, as we have seen, had grounded their faith in objectivity. And the war itself became the subject of interminable historical controversy, undermining the faith that professional historical scholarship could converge on a consensual objective truth”(111). WWII shattered any moral standing of cultural relativism, some going further to say it weakened the nation against communism or fascism. There was a new interest in finding universal values between times and cultures(284-85).

Finally during the Cold War, there was the creation of Western civ and the claim that objectivity was one of the principle unifying characteristic of this Atlantic world. This sought to distinguish totalitarianism with the freedom of the West(299). Unlike the historical trend following WWI, the post-WWII and Cold War “mobilization of historians” lasted for decades(302). Important to each of these war periods, however, was the notion that dissent was unpatriotic and the somewhat malleable idea of objectivity.

All in all, the quest for objectivity seems to be a perilous one, particularly when we as historians admit ourselves to be influenced by both subliminal and tacit imperatives of the present. I would tend to agree with Bevir’s evaluation, that objectivity is attainable by examining evidence based on a criteria of comparison, but would probably qualify it by saying objectivity is most approachable in this manner, but may not be fully attainable. That said, limited objectivity does not preclude a workable understanding of the past, and besides, our biases will give the historians of the next generations additional points to discuss. I don’t intend that flippantly, as I tend to agree with Peirce, that the more analyses the better, however individually flawed each may be.

entry.title: Objectivity in American History
entry.content:
Peter Novick, That Noble Dream | Mark Bevir, “Objectivity in History”

I was struck this week by Peter Novick’s sweeping review of objectivity; in many respects, Novick’s work was less a history of objectivity and more of a history of American professional history.  Objectivity is cleverly used as a vehicle to examine the growth and development of the profession. 

In its infancy, professional historians found a sense of certitude in history as the story of man’s progress.  Because they were rooted in scientific processes, methodological, cultural, political, and ideological judgments were unassailable and protected them from criticism.  The Great War changed all of that; the pre-war certitude which characterized the profession’s faith in progress eroded, creating a declining confidence in professionalism that helped call the associated doctrine of objectivity into question during the 1920s and 1930s.  Relativism would reign supreme during this period.  

Similarly, World War II would shift the foundations of the industry yet again, as relativism, pragmatism, legal realism, and the social sciences came under increasing attack.  During the post-war boom, historians constructed a new, somewhat chastened, partially hybridized objectivist synthesis which trivialized the relativist critique.  Novick ultimately asserts that American historians were compelled to take sides in a larger ideological struggle; because it was a war of absolutes, the Cold War could not allow for indecisiveness and relativism. 

The logical extension of Novick’s argument is that American historians have never really been concerned with objectivity at all, that it was merely a buzzword of the profession used to defend professionalism.  From this perspective, Novick’s assessment corresponds to Bevir’s argument against empirical objectivity.  Bevir suggests that empirical objectivity is impossible because man’s experiences or observations are innately personal and embody the theoretical categories of the individual having the insight.  Thusly, man cannot determine conclusively whether an individual theory is true or false because such judgment will be based on theoretical assumptions embodied in his observations. 

Bevir then argues for a comparative objectivity.  For him, objectivity is created by “comparing and criticizing rival webs of interpretations in terms of facts” upon which most historians tend to agree within their specific discipline (334).  Reduced to an analytical exercise, objectivity is rooted in ideas of professionalism and comity which require: criticism to be given and taken seriously; frowns upon dismissing contrary evidence as a mere exceptions or deviations from the truth; a presumption against purely face-saving responses to critiques of theories.  In short, Bevir’s comparative objectivity is founded on little more than intellectual honesty. 

Of the two, Novick’s was certainly the most thought provoking read.  Objectivity has certainly ebbed and flowed in American professional history, and Novick suggests that while there have been concerted dissents for and against relativism, objectivity, and professionalism, the flux of objectivity is largely the result of events outside the control of historians.  Objectivity is, therefore, an ideal which is—depending on which side of the aisle you are on—either a goal to be sought after, or an unattainable pipe dream which clouds the true motives of history.

entry.title: The Objective Past
entry.content:
Objectivity is an elusive, elusive thing.

The book we read this week explained more than just what objectivity is and why it has been such a major part of American historiographic tradition, but took us through the development of historiography in the United States. I found this a very informative and helpful work, and I’m noticing that as the semester moves on I am having an easier time defining myself as a historian and what my philosophical views on history are.

I have to say that in my beliefs of the probably, I agree with the relativists that true, objective fact is not going to be attained, and that assuming a historian can do so is both naïve and dangerous. That being said, this book, and looking through the debates, makes me want to champion the objectivist cause, because I believe the pursuit of objectivity, in its original, real sense, is the most important thing a historian can do. This book gives example after example of how historians have constantly been driven off the straight and narrow path, deviating from the objective lessons of history both due to their own personal/societal faults (like the big section on racism) or because of political expediency (both WW1 and WW2 showed a lot of that). It certainly is a false hope to believe that people will ever be able to either get to the entire truth of an issue or to put away all of their own biases, but I think it’s a horrific idea to abandon the quest simply because of its unreachability.

Perhaps I listened to the Don Quixote soundtrack too much when I was a kid.

In any case, I think “that noble dream” is one that is vital for the profession. I know that there is a strong motivation in a period of economic uncertainty to make the humanities somehow more “relevant,” as if learning about the world is not relevant enough, or to market them as practical skills (they’re not, really), but to give up the idea of pure truth, the quest to discover the Platonic ideal of the past… well, that’s the death of history as a field worth studying.

We will, of course, never really know the whole truth about the past. Our use of documentary evidence immediately prevents that goal, because we have to rely on biased sources. But the quest, the journey towards the truth—that is what we do, and even if we fail, and perhaps because we fail, that is how we become epic.
