entry.title: On American trends in Objectivity and Relativism
entry.content:
Our readings this week were thought provoking accounts on the various manifestations of Objectivity and Relativism theories in American historiography.  We read That Noble Dream: The “Objectivity Question” and the American Historical Profession, by Peter Novik, and an article from History and Theory titled “Objectivity in History,” by Mark Bevir. 

I read the Bevir article first, and several questions crept to mind.  In employing objectivity to historical research, how would you work out problems of commensurability when the worldview of, for example, a medieval knight cannot be worked out from a twentieth century historian’s point of view?  In this sense, the rationalization on pg 233 that “facts” can be related to each other to get at truth, is not enough tou counter the possibility of specious correlations by the author, which is a question of relativism.  I felt that Bevir did not address this problem sufficiently.

I need not have felt alone in this assessment, however, That Noble Dream was filled with many objections to the aspirations of objectivity by historians throughout America’s history of the profession, which began in the 1880s.  Novick’s thesis is that, in general, ojectivists won out over the majority of the historiographical timeline due to extenuating circumstances in American history such as World War II and the Cold War, which gave rise to conformist attitudes among historians in order to defeat external threats to the nation.  However, Novick credits relativists like Becker and Bean with performing “an important service in freeing historians from the belief that ‘the facts spoke for themselves,’ (pg 410), and suggests that a happy medium has developed over time despite the often heated debate between objectivism and relativism.  Perhaps subconsciously, American historians adoped a historiographical philosophy Bruce Kuklick described as that of the “ideal observer.”  According to Kuklick, this person “has the characteristics attributable to the ideal historian:” “There will be one correct evaluation in every situation calling for evaluation… It will be necessary, at least theoretically, for everyone finally to agree on the truth-value of any evaluation…”  These evaluations would then be declared ‘objective,’ (pg 409).  In the end, this is very close to Bevir’s idea of objectivity, but it also allows for an amalgum of personal judgement, which the relativists taught is impossible to avoid, and objectivism, which is an admirable goal, but is equally impossible to achieve.

entry.title: hist510 Objectivity?
entry.content:
When I first began reading That Noble Dream, I was initially impressed with Novick’s approach and the clarity of his analysis. Although I remained favorably inclined to these aspects throughout the remainder of the book, my enthusiasm for the Novick’s work diminished somewhat the more I read. To be fair, my relative disinterest stemmed solely from preconceived expectations that remained unfulfilled and not from any shortcomings within the book itself. My biggest shock was the degree to which Novick focused on institutional and technical elements of the historical profession, such as the shifting status of professional historians and changing job prospects, to name a few. Upon reflection, however, I acknowledged that incorporating such information was simply weaving in yet another important strand in the history of objectivity in America. 

Perhaps my biggest complaint with Novick’s book is the somewhat negative attitude he adopts toward American historiography. In the interest of objectivity, I realize that my offense probably stems from an innate sense of patriotism that resists the suggestion that American historians lack the finesse, skill and creativity of European historians. While I did not feel that these statements were direct criticisms of American historiography, I nonetheless wondered how different a book on objectivity in America would have been if written by an American, particularly the link between European historical developments and their ensuing influence in America or if such as link would even have been perceived. Once again, however, my personal complaint does not detract from the overall authority of the book.

I believe that overall That Noble Dream is a well-researched study that provides an informative and enjoyable overview of the role of objectivity in the American historical profession. I liked that Novick used the concept of objectivity as a focal point and examined how American historians have regarded and/or sought the realization of this goal over the last one hundred years. I was surprised at the degree to which Novick related internal academic developments to external forces, although I absolutely agree that approaching objectivity in this manner is critical to truly understanding America’s “quest for objectivity.” Historians recognize that World War I and other major developments impacted nearly very aspect of American life, but rarely have I considered the intellectual and institutional ramifications of such events within an academic context, as does Novick. 

I thoroughly enjoyed the complicated narrative of objectivity laid out by Novick; I did not get the sense that he attempted to constrain the history of objectivity into a neatly developmental path. Rather, he embraces the challenges this ideal faced as well as stimulants contributing to its furtherment in American history, both of which combined to create an intriguing picture of how this most elusive concept has contributed to the historical profession. As intended, Novick’s study highlighted the undeniable relationship of objectivity to the American historical profession. Objectivity is not just an unreachable ideal that historians maintain in the interest of professionalism. It is and has been an important factor influencing American historiography, just as developments within American historiography have affected professional interpretations of objectivity. The mutual influence of this ideal with other aspects of the historical profession was one of my favorite parts of this book. I must also admit that I enjoyed the manner in which Novick treated historical study in America as a developing profession; he advanced a theory that assumed a more evolutionary and time-consuming process of professionalization than is frequently put forth. More importantly, however, he examines how the search for objectivity played a critical role in this process of professionalization. Overall, I found Novick’s book to be informative and thought-provoking. It is certainly a long read, but one well worth the effort.

entry.title: A Noble Dream it is
entry.content:
Imagine that, some of the wealthiest people in the area where American students of history first went seeking doctorates in Germany were the very professors they were learning from.  Of course, these students were from the upper class of America as well, but it was the idea that knowledge and learning commanded prestige and wealth that is so striking.  Now, all that is left is the prestige and honor of the title.  But I digress.  These early students brought the ideas of von Ranke back with them and began building American historical ideals.  The greatest achievement these early historians sought for was the elusive ideal of objectivity.  If they could get the study of the past down to a science then bias would be removed entirely.  The problem was using the right science.  In the period before WWI, historians were looking to professionalize their ‘guild’ by setting certain standards and maxims.  Among these was defining truth as being what all who investigated found, or the idea of replicability, and redefining historical work as an “academic” enterprise. (52)  Thus professionalization would allow objectivity to exist. 
After WWI the idea of objectivity disintegrated.  Relativism entered the scene and the fight was on.  For the war, historians had been pulled into creating history for elementary and high school.  This history was directed by the government though, seeking to indoctrinate the children with the exceptionalism of the U.S. and the greatness of American society.  Between the world wars, history was being replaced in the classroom by social studies; part history, part social science, but all relative to becoming good American citizens.  As historians relinquished pre-collegiate classrooms in the quest for autonomy, they found their salaries continually lowered by universities and the students seeking admission to those programs, who would become the next generation of historians, coming from lower social strata than before.  The interwar years saw a growing number of scholars who pushed the idea of conflict and disunity, something the older generation vehemently sought to avoid with its Civil War views. 
The negativity and doubt of these years were replaced with the search for certainty as WWII exploded onto the historical stage.  Relativism was linked to cynicism and nihilism as the world was divided by scholars into the “free” first world, the “totalitarian” second, and the odd men out third world. (281-3) After the war, many historians’ loyalty was questioned in the era of McCarthyism.  To be painted with the subversive brush was to see the end of even the most promising academic career.  Ideologies were the buzzword of the day, and if yours did not match the norm, then here’s your hat and there’s the door.  This mindset brought objectivity back to the fore as it became the hallmark of thought in the Free World. (299)  The war also gave birth to “Western civ” classes to help further this Free World indoctrination, while historians saw “the defense of freedom as the thread which wove American history together.” (333) The postwar years saw a rise in confidence by historians, which came from better criteria for evaluation, a dominant research ethos, and more autonomy – the main desire of professionals. (361) In closing with the view of Richard Hofstadter, “if a new or heterodox idea is worth anything at all it is worth a forceful overstatement.” (338) Basically, go big or go home, which is in line with modern popular sentiments.  If we are not willing to go all-in in this game of history, then we must settle for less than the best we can be.

entry.title: That Noble Dream
entry.content:
This has been my favorite book since The Footnote, and for many of the same reasons. Both books deal with social and cultural themes in a chronological sweep, both use a particular topic as an organizing structure for a lot of wide-ranging information, and both have really fun writing styles. These are the sorts of books that generated and sustain my love for history. The biggest difference between them—even more than world versus American scope—is that this book stuffs so much information in that I don’t feel like I got it all. I really want to read it again this summer when I can go more slowly, and write down the great quotes and metaphors and bits of irony he sprinkled throughout. I like language as much as history, and this book was full of both.

I did find it kind of ironic and cheeky that in a book about objectivity, he seemed several times to be giving a fairly clear preference to relativism, and thereby rejecting objectivity on two levels simultaneously. Right away, on pages one and two, he explained objectivity in such overblown terms and outsized expectations that he set me up to be skeptical. I wondered at that point if he would lead us toward a more reasonable definition of objectivity, but if he did, it must have been after section three. He also seemed to present objectivity as a goal with an agenda. First, it would make historians more scientific and professional, then it would prepare citizens to be loyal and patriotic, then it would distinguish us from those ideological communists. He seemed to lean toward conflating objectivity and absolutism. In chapter three he said that objectivity forced historians to deny their assumptions, which made them the more powerful for being hidden (84). Relativism, though, was presented in a positive light, as measured and reasonable and even gracious (401). The only agenda I found here was a different way to create a universal perspective on history than the path objectivity was pursuing toward that same goal.

I liked the connections he made between historiographical trends within and characteristics of culture without. Before WW1, historians pushed objectivity as a way to seem scientific and professional, even as science was emerging and Literature and Art were leaving old moralizing for modern invisible authorship. During and between the wars, relativism emerged both in response to discrepancies forced by wartime compromises and in tandem with developments in Literature, Art, and even Math, Physics, Logic, and Journalism. After WW2, objectivity was pulled out again as a way of distinguishing Us from Them—They were forced into ideological positions by repressive governments, but We were free from coercion and so able to write the Real Truth. I also appreciated that even as he used this artificial periodization, he didn’t bind himself within it; he showed how trends developed slowly and in the presence of the opposition, so the generalizations I just made were mitigated in the book.

He also connected the fortunes of objectivity and relativism to the status of the profession in general. The clearest place was in chapter nine where some historians objected to relativism because it would damage the field’s professionalism, prestige, and morale. That seemed an odd argument since—possibly due to his leading—I see relativism as more honest, and honesty as more professional.

Obviously, with a book this full that I liked this much, I could go on and on (keep the groans down, please) but I’m just going to say again that I loved this book. I hope the rest of the semester’s are just like it.

entry.title: Weber and Wood
entry.content:
The Origin of Capitalism presents a very interesting argument that capitalism, often assumed to be the natural result of social/economic progress, is in fact neither an inevitable outcome nor is it likely to be the permanent one. Ellen Meiksins Woods distinguishes between market opportunity and market forces, as she argues that compulsion more than opportunity directs interaction in capitalist exchanges(7). This idea that individuals in a “free” capitalist society are actually compelled by market forces acting on them is thoroughly explained and well-supported. She roots much of this shift in England tenant farming, where rent competitively determined land access. The farmers themselves had to improve production to be allowed access to the land to garner subsistence. The need to constantly improve production relative to one’s fellows, however, shifted the focus from subsistence to profit. The reason for this change among the peasants was “not the opportunity to produce for the market and to grow from petty producers into capitalists, but the need to specialize for the market and produce competitively—simply in order to guarantee access to the means of subsistence and to the land itself”(53). This was contrasted to other countries, such as France, which could rely on extra-economic coercion(96, 100).Wood states explicitly on page 80 that this shift in social property relations that made individuals dependent on the market that generated capitalism. Capitalism is, however, unstable to its core, since it is based on continual growth and consumption in an ultimately finite world(85). Wood directly expresses her concern for the continued viability of such as system in the conclusion(198-98).

Wood acknowledges Weber’s interpretation of capitalism, noting that he also implies capitalism’s inevitability as it is only absent in cultures where particular structures impeded its implantation. She notes that his analysis also furthers his goal of “distinguish[ing]Europe from other parts of the world”(17). This is not what most struck me about Weber. I found his argument about the changing attitude toward work the most interesting of his ideas. There is unquestionably a break between Catholic and Protestant teachings on the role of work in society. In Catholicism, faith and good works together are required to ascend to Heaven after death, but in Protestant religions, an individual gains salvation through faith alone. However, one’s profession ought to be to the glory of God, as opposed to a less congruent sample of good works accumulated throughout a lifetime, as Catholics were believed to do. He argues that to Protestants, one’s profession was one’s “calling,” which necessarily took on a religious character(28-30). He also notes, however, that Catholics are more likely to become master craftsmen, which I do not see how that bolsters his argument.

Weber’s attention to the fact that Luther translates work in different ways is very important to his argument and a sound historical observation(55). However, there were many other places throughout the book where I felt he lacked historicism. In addition to his clear bias toward certain religions, he also failed to fully explain his own analysis, insisting that definitions are better left until later or that “this is not the place for” further inquiry. I disagree with the editor that the shifting nature of his terms and lack of concrete definitions or explanations allows him to “constantly elude refutation”(xxiv). I did not think historians allowed one another to avoid peer criticism by being deliberately vague. Weber spends a section of the work talking about the individual Protestant sects, but then, as he is relating them back to his thesis, insists that one(Calvinism) will be sufficient to demonstrate his point. After taking time to highlight the differences within Protestantism, he then discounts it(105). It was an interesting idea that individualism has its roots in Calvinistic doctrine, since each man is fully on his own, and no one can help him gain salvation, but I do not think he adequately supports his claim that this is the foundation for the spirit of capitalist. It may be a contributing factor, or an intriguing psychological parallel, but I am not convinced that it is the sole genesis of this all-encompassing worldview(which I would also argue, we still have yet to adequately define).

I enjoyed reading the two together (and enjoyed reading Wood) because Weber certainly falls into one of Wood’s criticisms that we consider capitalism the fated conclusion of economic development; Weber could not be more triumphalist in his examination of capitalism than coupling its birth with the Protestant Reformation, a movement he clearly supported.

entry.title: Materialism Episode 3-- The Revenge of the Capitalists
entry.content:
These readings were a perfect cap for materialism, and I got really into them, much to my surprise. Ellen Meiksins Wood’s book, The Origin of Capitalism, was a fantastic little read, and I managed to be done with it by the time I touched down in Philadelphia. I liked the view of agrarian capitalism, which she very convincingly portrayed. It is clear, to anyone who studies the medieval world, that trade and urbanization alone cannot be the only factors needed to create capitalism. The Dutch Republic example was very persuasive, and I thought of examples of international trade routes like the Amber Road and the Silk Road, the gold and slaves route through the Sudan during the Roman and Arab periods, the Phoenician trade networks… city-states and trade networks, metropolis and urban societies have existed for a long, long time. If cities and trade were all that were needed, with some industrialization mixed in, why wouldn’t Byzantium have succeeded?

The English agrarian model, which blames the English for capitalism (and yes, I know that was not what she was saying, but over the last few weeks I’ve started disliking capitalism more and more), makes perfect sense, and the fact that it capitalism creates the proletarian-industrial mix in this theory really works for me. I personally believe agriculture to be the backbone of any economy (yes, I have dark thoughts about the house of cards of Western prosperity as a result), so the agrarian model really touched a chord with me.

The line she uses, that production of the basic means of survival being market dependent is the marker of capitalism (p. 140) is a great way to look at it. No choice outside of the system.
Max Weber’s work was a fun read. I’m not sure what of it I buy, but it was enjoyable and different. Unlike Wood, who argues that capitalism is neither universal nor inevitable, and certainly badly misunderstood, Weber doesn’t argue the universality or inevitability of capitalism, but looks at the “Protestant ethic,” something I’ve heard about for years—the idea that Calvinism is a direct source of capitalism and the doctrine of prosperity. Given the doctrine of predestination, where you are either saved or not, you have to live like you are—this means prosperity and blessings have to be upon you, and you have to KNOW you are saved—you have to be so convinced of your self-righteousness that you never doubt it, because doubt is a sign of not being full of grace and thus being damned. The inherent problems with that idea are so vast, and outside of this paper, but MAN I dislike Calvinism as a theological doctrine. Where this comes into play materially is that you are expected to be prosperous and have a life filled with the blessings of the Lord, so you work hard to keep yourself out of trouble, earn a lot, create something for yourself to show that God has favored you. Just make sure not to enjoy it.

These readings were, on an enjoyment level, much better than the last two weeks. I like that they look at different roots of capitalism, and challenge the concept of capitalist inevitability.

Good readings, looking forward to the discussion.

Oh, and did anyone else notice that Weber said basically that Catholics are all the scholars and Protestants all the business men? I know the second part is his point, but the first? I love it.

entry.title: Reflections on Weber, Wood and capitalism's genesis
entry.content:
“Capitalism is the astounding belief that the most wickedest of men will do the most wickedest of things for the greatest good of everyone.” – John Maynard Keynes
“The inherent vice of capitalism is the unequal sharing of blessings; the inherent virtue of socialism is the equal sharing of miseries.” – Winston Churchill
“History suggests that capitalism is a necessary condition for political freedom.” – Milton Friedman

Surely, few would debate that capitalism is by now a significant global phenomenon. However, just as that system’s merits are debatable, so, too, are its origins.

Max Weber’s pioneering 1904-05 work, “The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism,” was his attempt to frame that economic system’s start in socio-religious terms.

In the process, as he delves into the Reformation, he invokes the specter of predestination. And here he delivers one of his most intriguing ideas. Per that particular doctrine: Folks’ eternal destination was already decided, and there was nothing they could do about it. Per Weber’s corollary: For many, the suspense was too much to bear, naturally, so they sought a sign; they worked to show themselves that they were approved unto God, as secular success must mean heavenly sanction.

How bizarre. How paradoxical. And yet, how viscerally satisfactory.

So it is with many of Weber’s explanations. His is ultimately a well-reasoned, if rather unscientific, treatment (as noted, criticized and/or excused in the Norton Critical Edition’s “Contexts” section).

Ellen Meiksins Wood, in “The Origin of Capitalism” (1999), likewise presents a wholly plausible account. However, her approach – framed in socio-cultural terms – seems more balanced than Weber’s, or, put another way, less encumbered by a predestined conclusion.

For example, her ideas regarding capitalism’s specific provenance are more convincing than Weber’s rather vague views on that count.

Meanwhile, her key criticism of attitudes whereby capitalism’s emergence was “the realization of ever-present tendencies” is hammered home a bit too frequently, perhaps, but still is well-taken.

All in all, I find both works to be quite compelling in their own ways – Weber’s as a triumph of the imagination, Wood’s as an exercise in thorough, unremitting rationality.

entry.title: The Orign of Capitalism and The Protestant Ethic
entry.content:
Our Readings this week were Max Weber’s The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism and the Origin of Capitalism: A Longer View, By Ellen Meiksins Wood.  I found their writing styles to be lighter fare than our last few weeks’ readings, having digested Marx, Engels, Stern et al with difficulty.  However, these two theses were no less compelling studies, and built upon the others’ theories while bringing some excellent observations to bear.

Aside from Weber’s sweeping generalizations about peoples of varying religions behaving in one way or another, and his Darwinesque depiction of Protestantism winning the battle over capital, I thought he made a very similar argument to that of Wood.  That is, they both believe that true capitalism started in England, though I think they would disagree about the timing.  On the other hand, the major difference between the two is that Weber seems to fall into the trap Wood warns us against.  He assumes that capitalism has everywhere in various forms at least since the Middle Ages, and that it is a natural economic evolution.  For her part, Wood believes that capitalism was in no way a foregone conclusion, and that it formed late in the pre-modern era amid much jockeying for position among different types of economic systems in France, Germany and the Italian city states. 

Furthermore, while the two would agree that capitalism won the struggle, and is firmly entrenched in every corner of the globe today, they would likely disagree that this is the result of a natural order of things, or that religion played the key role.  Wood argues that protestant rhetoric likely formed as a result of capitalism and not the other way around.

entry.title: 10/10 Weber and Wood
entry.content:
I found this week’s economic readings much more interesting than those of the previous weeks, likely because the books this week had a stronger cultural emphasis to which I could respond. On one hand, I rather wish we had read these two works, or at least Wood’s, as the first foray into economic history, as it clarified several points for me. On the other hand, I can see how her reading would have biased us about the other works (and of course, if she’s going to discuss Marx, it helps to have read some of his writings in advance). Also, I am unable to say whether I understood her work better because it was written on more of an intro level, or because I had been previously and recently exposed to some of the concepts she is discussing and the theories against which she is arguing.

Weber’s exploration of the capitalist spirit as it intersects with religion was intriguing, if outdated (oh, sociology-type writings from the early 1900s…). His idea that the spirit of capitalism originated in the asceticism of Protestant religions, with the combination of the concept of a “calling” and doing your work on earth to please a god, was interesting, if unconvincing. I would have preferred if he had expounded on his views about Catholicism, as they contrast to those about Protestantism—it would have created a stronger foundation, I feel, for his conclusions. In reading his descriptions of the four Protestant religions under study, I found the one about Calvinism to be the most developed and lucid. The remaining three seem to be shorter and less developed, largely since they play off all the ideas already set down for Calvinism, but I still found them lacking. I came away from the Calvinist description with a strong understanding of how it might contribute to the “Protestant work ethic,” as Weber sees it, but I was left unsure with the remaining three.

Wood’s goal is to situate the development of capitalism in a specific time and location, with specific causes, and I admire her for doing so. Not being very familiar with economic history, I am unable to comment on her views that most economic historians either take the origins of capitalism for granted or explain them by virtue of capitalism existing, in a begging-the-question fashion. Her book argues strongly against the idea that history ended with the fall of the USSR, as we discussed last week; her idea that capitalism originated under specific circumstances implies that a new economic system could begin, given the right situation. I felt the last part the book deteriorated when she began discussing the role of capitalism in imperial societies and in the modern world. As to the length of the updated edition, which she discusses, I am torn. The book is rather repetitive with its assertions, especially in the beginning when she repeatedly critiques previous explanations of capitalism. While this was somewhat irritating, it was also helpful, as she continually reminded the reader about her thesis. (Additionally, I don’t think I’ve ever seen the words “fetters” used so much in one book before—I kept wanting to tell her to find a thesaurus somewhere…)

entry.title: Thoughts on The Origin of Capitalism
entry.content:
The Origin of Capitalism is a book written by Ellen Meiksins Wood.  In this book before proposing her own theory of the origin of capitalism she effectively breaks down previous understandings of the origin of Capitalism such as Marxists understand of its origins and what Marxists claimed to be fighting the “commercialization Model.”  One of her major critiques of previous Capitalist origin theories was their assumption that Capitalism was an inevitable end to human history, that all throughout history, Capitalism has been attempting to surface but was held back by social and political constraints.  This idea is the “Commercialization Model.”   As Wood pointed out, in Marxist critiques of the old system, they still held on to this model, thus making their attacks also flawed.

I enjoyed Wood’s attack of euro-centric Capitalism as she quickly pointed out that the only thing that set Western Europe apart was Imperialism, as it gave Europeans the necessary amount of capital to overtake other parts of the world.

Wood proposes that capitalism was not an inevitable outcome out of feudalism, as feudalism produced many outcomes in Europe, such as absolutist France.  Wood proposes that the development of Capitalism in some areas in Western Europe was due to the lack of goods and thus need in their respective markets to expand outside the continent. Once this need was there it was followed by an evolution of the “social property relations that generated market imperatives and capitalist ‘laws of motion,’ which imposed themselves on production.”(pg 77)Wood does also mention that Max Weber’s Protestant Ethic did influence in part the development of Capitalism in Western Europe.

Max Weber’s “The Protestant Ethic and the ‘Spirit’ of Capitalism” attempted to explain capitalism outside of the materialistic terms that Marx set as standard.  I found this admirable.  He promoted the ideas of work as means of glorification of God and self-improvement through work, which got translated into the promotion of Capitalism.

entry.title: hist510 Capitalism Again...
entry.content:
My first thoughts when I realized that the readings for this week dealt yet again with the issue of capitalism were, to say the least, unenthusiastic. I was cheered slightly upon being told that the approaches adopted by Weber and Wood avoided the materialistic basis of previous readings, but the initial dread still loomed. When I finally brought myself to read the selections, however, I must admit myself pleasantly surprised. It was quite refreshing to read a more culturally-derived analysis of capitalism, and I found these examinations to be much more intellectually stimulating than materialistic explanations. Perhaps it is because my knowledge and understanding of economics leaves something to be desired, but for me Wood and Weber’s arguments provided a more historically grounded and encompassing study of the development of capitalism, although I was not always entirely persuaded of their conclusions. 

Although I did not initially expect much of Weber’s writings, it took only a few pages to grasp both my interest and my respect. Weber was clearly an intelligent man, but more than that I respect his boldness and innovation for advancing such a theory in the first place. The link between religion and capitalism is not one that many would discern, much less be able to provide support for. This is not to say I was entirely convinced of his assertions, for much of the time I felt that he either over-emphasized or over-generalized parts of his argument.  His central contention for the influence of Protestant ethics on the development of a capitalist society is, however, intriguing and deserving of serious consideration. 

As I read Weber’s text, I grew increasingly curious about his opinion of capitalism and the ensuing capitalist society. It soon became clear that the constant for Weber was religion, not capitalism. This does not mean that Weber saw religion as unchanging, merely that he always maintained a positive attitude toward the inclusion of religion in society. According to Weber, when capitalism first emerged it did so in response to new religious mores that advocated hard work and perseverance. Under these new Protestant ethics, particularly those held by Calvinists, people were not only free to pursue the accumulation of wealth but indeed compelled by duty to do so. Only by refraining from idleness and dedicating one’s life to improvement and work could one please God.  Weber referred to this as the “spirit of capitalism” and it was this mood that characterized the early stages of capitalist development. When religious ethics played a part, Weber appears to be okay with the presence of capitalism. As capitalism grew to be more firmly entrenched, however, it depended less on people and became more of an impersonal self-sustaining system. At this point, Weber’s tone turns much more critical. I found his overall approach interesting because it entailed the forced continuation of such a system, not its voluntary maintenance. People participated in capitalism because they had to; it had grown to be far too encompassing for individuals to exist outside of. 

My favorite part of Weber’s argument, however, was his brief examination of how Protestant ethics affected not only the development of capitalism but aspects of a capitalist society. Indeed, I was intrigued simply by his emphasis on the existence of a capitalist society. It is certainly not a new concept, but it is one that  I had not dedicated much thought to previously. When I thought of societies and cultures, I usually defined them in terms of nations, etc. When I thought of capitalism, my mind turned to purely economic matters. I enjoyed having a conscious redirection that integrated the two ideas and made me think of capitalism in a substantially more rounded, and admittedly more accurate, manner. Weber’s ability to draw connections between religious ideas and ensuing cultural developments never failed to leave me impressed, regardless of the level of conviction with which I regarded them.  At times, however, I grew somewhat impatient with Weber’s deep analysis of religious principles. I sometimes felt as if I was reading a theological survey more than a historical inquiry. I may not have preferred it, but Weber’s dedication to proving the beneficial involvement of religion in society made this approach at least understandable.  His later writings in particular stressed the positive advantages gained by incorporating the religion into daily life, notably in capitalist societies where the Church could serve to counteract the individualistic and impersonal tendencies that dominated fully-developed capitalism. Although Weber provided a religious explanation for the growth of capitalism, he does acknowledge the importance of considering materialistic explanations as well.

If I was pleasantly surprised upon reading Max Weber’s writings, I found myself strangely delighted at Ellen Wood’s book. Between her decision to focus on society rather than economics, the book’s clear and concise writing style and the innovative ideas it contained, On the Origins of Capitalism was easily my favorite book so far this semester. It was made even more appealing because it followed the series of, for me, less enjoyable books we have read in the preceding weeks.  

Wood’s main emphasis fell on addressing social influences on the development on capitalism as opposed to Weber’s focus on religion. There were a number of other comparisons and contrasts between Weber and Wood that I found very interesting; I was glad to have the Wood book to guide my reflections upon Weber’s work so that these links were clarified. Wood identified several main goals she hoped her book would accomplish: emphasizing social influences on capitalism, challenging the inevitable treatment capitalism has received, and advancing a forced interpretation of involvement in capitalist societies. By advancing these arguments, Wood placed herself in opposition to much of what Weber wrote, although the two agreed on some points. One thing the Weber and Wood did share was distaste for fully developed capitalism, although in Wood’s case distaste is perhaps an understatement. I thoroughly enjoyed reading such a strong critique of the capitalist system, particularly one that challenged the Euro-centric nature of much of the literature on the development of capitalism. 

Perhaps my favorite part of Wood’s argument was her conviction that capitalism needs to be understood as a historically specific phenomena that emerged in response to a particular set of social relations. I believe that this approach provides a better understanding of capitalism because it does not try to force the development of a single all-encompassing explanation, and it also redresses the injustice done to historical studies that try to impose the capitalist system where it does not fit. According to Wood, feudalism was not a necessary precursor to the emergence of capitalism. She proves this point even within Europe by surveying both English and French historical developments that began from a similar starting point yet ended up in very different spots. Wood argues, contrary to much capitalist literature, that true capitalism began in the English countryside in response to a shift in the social relations between peasants and lords. From England, it spread through the international market to other areas as well. I enjoyed this interpretation of capitalism’s development even more once Wood analyzed other historical aspects from this perspective, such as her analysis examining how changing social relations and the beginnings of capitalism contributed to a sense of national identity. 

Wood’s book was a very informative read, not just because of the innovative ideas she provided but also because of the brief historiographical survey she included as well. It was interesting to see the invisible constraints that seemed to exist on capitalist studies, deterring the introduction of a truly revolutionary approach to the development of capitalism. I also found this book relevant to our earlier discussion concerning the value of big narratives as opposed to local studies. I felt that Wood did an admirable job of studying a broad theme without sacrificing the importance of regional variations, a difficult task to successfully achieve. To me, her book stressed the advantages of both sides; local circumstances played a critical role in her assessment of capitalism, but she posed her study within the larger framework of capitalist studies. Even when challenging predominant interpretations of capitalism, Wood needed to operate within this framework in order to provide a relevant historical study.

entry.title: The Origin of Capitalism
entry.content:
Ellen Meiksins Wood explores the origins of capitalism and comes to a unique conclusion in this book.  She first outlines the various debates and Marxist alternatives to the creation of capitalism.  However, the main trouble she has with these treatises are that they assume the germ of capitalism existed before recorded history, and the emergence of capitalism was unavoidable once the removal of those pesky inhibitions of people to acquiring wealth were removed.  She posits that “capitalism was born when market imperatives seized hold of food production.” (81)  She goes further to say that capitalism did not begin in the city but in the countryside, and the rising number of propertyless rural labor gave the landowners a surplus labor pool to use. (95,102,103) 
The idea of ‘agrarian capitalism’ foreshadowing industrial capitalism is interesting in that it is based on large land holders squeezing unproductive tenant farmers to the wall while utilizing wage laborers, which differs from the  Marxist format of landlord-tenant-laborer.  The tenant farmers would be market-dependent if their land could not produce enough to sustain them.  This led her to the idea that market dependence was the cause of mass proletarianization. (131)  Since the landlords and farmers produced more food, a larger population was sustainable.  This would allow industrialization. This larger population would naturally live in cities, which made their means of self-reproduction market-dependent just like their means of production in that they must now buy their food.  Their consumption of necessities would drive both agricultural and industrial production goals.  This is what the author claims as the basis for the capitalist mode of production. (141) 

The need to sustain a growing population required that land was ‘improved’ and not left idol, which meant increasing its output or production.  The idea of property rights became entangled with the need to improve it or lose the right to own it.  As colonization began for England in the Americas, this idea of improving the land’s production was brought along as well.  Whereas the Spanish argued the right of conquest to control their claims and the French formed working relations with Native populations, the English applied this natural law to their endeavors.  In their view, since the Indians had not fenced in any land, or tried to improve it in any way like building houses, or raising cattle, then the land was open for the English to take as they would do what God had ordained and improve the area and make it valuable. (159)  To me, this seems an underhanded way to steal from people.  Didn’t the nobility in England have land that was not used for anything except hunting?  Was it their absolute dislike that these half naked heathens had some of the best land in the world that drove them to devise such a scheme as this?  Did they actually think that history would see them as noble for providing this ‘gift’ to the backward people of the Americas?  At least the Spanish were honest in that they in essence said, “We want this and this, and we’re just going to take it.  Try and stop us.”

entry.title: The Ethics and Origin of Capitalism
entry.content:
The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism

This was a charming read, but it made me very grateful that the age of corsets and upper-class certainties is over. Weber tried so hard to be scholarly and objective, and yet the overwhelming impression is of someone holding forth in the smoking lounge after an Edwardian dinner party.

He said on page 29 that this would be a serious work and not a sermon, on page 30 he holds his tongue about genetic causes because they didn’t yet have evidence, on page 45 he promised to leave behind “vague and general concepts” (Ha!), on pages 47-48 he claimed to look at examples before defining the Spirit of Capitalism, on page 91 he limited his goals and claims, on page 182 he rejected “judgments of value and faith” and he ended the book with a call for further study, all of which suggested a work of careful and thorough scholarship.

But throughout the work he tossed in jewels like the imaginary workers’ “congenial” life being “destroyed” by a capitalist (66-68) ,which he defended in the endnote by saying it was “of no consequence” that it was imaginary (200). On page 73 it’s “hardly necessary to prove” that this work ethos wasn’t present before the rise of Protestantism imposed it. (Since proving that is the point of the book, I started smelling brandy and cigars again.) In chapter three he outdid himself: “…dimly felt rather than clearly perceived…” (81), “…hardly necessary to point out…” (82), and “…unnecessary to go into detail…” (83). After that I lost interest in collecting these little baubles, but I do wonder if some of the mind-numbing pages of details and proof in other books is a reaction to the blithe opinionating of Weber’s era. If so, I’d like to call for a little moderation—support your points with actual examples instead of fancies, but don’t describe every example to death. And please cite your sources; that’s a fabulous innovation that I’ve loved and taken advantage of for years without truly appreciating until now.

Ok, scholarship aside, his book did try to make some interesting points. If I lace myself up and accept his sloppiness, I can see where this would have been an exciting innovation a hundred years ago The distinction between amassing wealth for consumption versus for reinvestment is instructive (and rather remarkable considering the conspicuous consumption of the Gilded Age). He tossed in the idea that Calvinists’ frequent refugee status may have influenced their approach to economics, but he didn’t do anything with this. His generalizations on pages 59-61 about people working only enough for subsistence echoed last week’s book, yet it also seemed like justification for poverty wages.

I only know a little about Luther, but Weber’s presentation of him supporting passive acceptance of your lot in life does fit with that scrap. It was interesting, on page 89, that he admitted the original Calvinists didn’t advocate amassing wealth as an end. This means he’s considering other religions at one point of development, and Calvinism at a different point. I am more familiar with Reformed theology, and from that position I have to say that either he found some obscure little slice to examine, or else he just ignored inconvenient realities in favor of stereotypes and myths that supported his thesis better. Confession and forgiveness have always been central, in one form or another, and predestination (before the unfortunate addition of double predestination) was a bedrock assurance of salvation irrevocable by any error or omission on the part of the sinner. His comment in the Anabaptist section about asceticism being a denial of joy in this life also contradicts all I’ve read and heard on that subject. Everywhere else, it’s a means of intensifying and focusing a deeper joy. So, his chapter on religion was wrong except where I don’t know very much.

Chapter five, where he pulled together all of his opinions to prove his theses did hold together well, if I suspend a lot of disbelief. There was a pervasive sense of duty in the 19th century, though I never saw it as denominationally limited. I do have a sense—as unproven as his—that Southern planters were more leisurely and New England manufacturers were more uptight, but I always figured it was the climate. And his claim that once Calvinism had established the capitalist ethos it became unnecessary for its perpetuation was very clever. That eliminated all sorts of arguments based on present (even his present) realities.

However vague and opinionated this book was, it has the gracious advantage of being lightweight and entertaining. At this point in the semester; it’s nice to have a little charming recess.

The Origin of Capitalism: a longer view

In this book, Ellen Meiksins Wood mentions and refutes several explanations of capitalism’s rise, shows the elements that other explanations got right, and then gives her idea of what caused the shift to capitalism and how it then was able to spread around the globe. Throughout the book, she is occasionally defensive and consistently repetitive, but despite those shortcomings she presents a clear and convincing argument for what really distinguishes capitalism from previous systems, and how it was set in motion, however inadvertently.

To avoid her repetitive habit, let me just say that her recurring complaint against Commercialization, Demographic, and World Systems/Dependency Theories as well as the Sweezy/Dobbs & Hilton Debate was that they all assumed that the development of capitalism was natural and inevitable. They described various ways it developed, obstacles that had to be removed, and varieties of development, but none explained how it began, because they all assumed that it just did. Sort of the “if you remove the obstacles, it will arrive” theory. They also—to one extent or another—assumed that people naturally choose greater productivity and wealth when given options, not the greater leisure and familiarity that Weber suggested in his high wage/low wage example.

She listed as well the people from whom she pulled pieces of her theory. Karl Polanyi, Karl Marx, Perry Anderson, Robert Brenner, and EP Thompson all got glimpses of her reality even though they each fell short in one way or another. My favorite part here was in the Perry Anderson section where feudalism was described, very drily and objectively, as the union of political and economic control. David Lewis (in God’s Crucible) called it the greatest protection racked every perpetrated by the powerful against the weak, or words to that effect.

Finally, she distilled all their contributions into her theory. Basically, England had centralized political power and localized land ownership. Because the landowners couldn’t squeeze surplus by force, they charged rent, and eventually figured out that they could maximize their wealth by making rent competitive—giving land to the highest bidder. This introduced increased productivity, which led to many pieces that combined into capitalism, well before industrialization or large and free cities in England. The competition led to many people being driven off the land, becoming landless wage workers in London. The greater productivity meant that the fewer remaining farmers could still feed the country despite the population explosion that seems to always follow advances in agriculture (even as long ago as Cahokia in 11th century North America). The mass of workers meant that industry had to develop efficiently to provide their basic needs cheaply. The central location meant that the market was unified and therefore competitive.

She briefly mentioned that England also had the best-developed transportation network that also supported this transition, but she never considered how England’s distance and humongous moat might have influenced its different development.

She did spend some time with the 17th century’s fascination with “Improvement.” She says this new focus grew out of the new need for productivity and competition, not from fear of not deserving your salvation like Weber claimed. This makes a lot more sense, frankly, since so much of the Protestant Revolution was about throwing off the vestiges of having to earn your salvation. She also showed how this idea had developed from as far back as Thomas More in 1516, and how it was used to justify both enclosures at home and colonial appropriations abroad, all under the delusion that they were actually contributing more value to these communities, not stealing their livelihoods.

She ended by saying that post-modernism is the latest school to conflate capitalism with something else, this time Enlightenment values. Because they’re intertwined, post-modernists want to overthrow the benefits of the Enlightenment in order to overcome the negative consequences of capitalism. Only as we understand what capitalism truly is, apart from all the things that developed alongside it, will we be able to see a way to replace it with a more humane system. And what capitalism truly is involves economic coercion by The Market, instead of military coercion by force. Capitalism compels productivity just as insistently as previous systems compelled conformity to their needs.

My last observation (complaint) is about her endnotes. They would have been much more helpful if they’d included a very brief description of what we’d find if we tracked down the citations she provided. She created in the text proper questions and hopes for examples or specifics that just are not answered by looking at the name of the source where they could be found. I’ve never been a fan of “look it up; you’ll remember it longer” and this was a case of just that. She also didn’t have an alphabetical bibliography, which I missed.

I hadn’t realized until this week what an endnote Goldilocks I am. “Give me details, but not piles of them. Give me facts, not stories (in the endnotes—I like stories in the text). Give me sources, but not in place of answers. Craft your endnotes to my specifications so they’re Just Right.” (“Please.”)

entry.title: Weber-- The Protestant Ethic
entry.content:
I used the 2003 Dover edition of this book, which I was told would be okay since we are to focus on Weber’s writing.  I’ll try to use chapter references instead since page numbers will not line up.  Weber undertakes the task of identifying what capitalism is by looking at it through various division of Protestantism, occasionally comparing them to Catholicism.  His overall stress on the argument seems to be that capitalism could only happen in the Occident – Western Europe and America.  In the introduction he calls it “the most fateful force in our modern life,” which is a big statement.  He further clarifies that unlimited greed is not true capitalism, and that a form of capitalism, or pre-capitalism, has existed everywhere.
He starts with the notion that Protestants make better capitalists than Catholics because the latter’s disdain for accumulation of wealth and ecclesiastical piety prevent them from making enough money to rise above the station in life wherein they were born. (Ch. 1)  He goes on to break down denominations like Calvinists, Lutherans, Pietism, Methodists, and the various Baptist sects to explain how each brought capitalism into an accepted place with the Christian faith.
As I was reading this, I got to the place in Chapter II where it said, “The sound of your hammer at five in the morning…” and I thought, “Isn’t that from Poor Richards Almanac?”  Sure enough, when I turn the page, and from then on, Weber is referencing Franklin as the quintessential worker bee of capitalism.  He also uses Franklin as a baseline when comparing the various religious groups as he worked to separate himself from any denominational affiliation.  Of course it helped that he was a deist.
One last note I wanted to bring up.  At the end of the next-to-last paragraph of Chapter III, Weber states, “At the same time we must free ourselves from the idea that it is possible to deduce the Reformation, as a historically necessary result, from certain economic changes.”  Did a lot of people in that time think that the Reformation was caused by economic forces?  That is most interesting.  He also said he believes the Reformation did not create capitalism, which is good since he first said that capitalism has been around forever.  Just my two cents.

entry.title: Capitalism
entry.content:
Ellen M. Wood, The Origins of Capitlaism: A Longer View

I was struck this week by Wood’s rather slim volume on the origins and development of capitalism.  Yes, Max Weber is important, but Wood is able to dismiss him with a barely a single page of commentary.  According to Ellen Wood, the rise of capitalism was not inevitable—if anything it was an historical accident spurred on by a precise set of circumstances in a confined location.  Wood begins her discussion by dismissing the current historiography of capitalism’s origins—including Marx—arguing that the dominant works either ignore the question of capitalism’s origins, focus their investigations towards questions of why it did not develop elsewhere, or that they are invalid because they are anachronistic.  At their core, they all take on basic assumptions that profit is the single motive of mankind, and that capitalism arises naturally out of that motive.  Thus, the rise of capitalism is discussed in terms of overcoming obstacles to its ascension. 

The prevailing understanding fails to acknowledge the particular imperatives of capitalism, the mechanizations of market operations, or the laws of competition, profit maximization, and capital accumulation.  In Wood’s opinion, capitalism is a very recent response to a specific set of circumstances arising in the agricultural economy of early modern England.  According to her evaluation, a basic market system existed in farming leases in which substantial landowners (most aristocrats) abandoned systems of extracting substantial rents out of tenet farmers in favor of coercing them to be more productive, thus increasing their rents.

Supported by Locke’s ruminations on property ownership and “improvement” of the land by using it to its maximum benefit, a system of agrarian capitalism developed.  The agrarian model promoted efficient farming, thereby enabling the most successful and efficient farmers (who produced greater income for their landlord through their efficient success) to work more land with less labor.  Thus, a largely landless laboring class developed which provided the requisite labor for Britain’s nascent industrial revolution.  Britain’s industrial growth was seen as a threat by other European nations who then forced capitalism on their societies in order to keep the pace in a zero-sum political system.  Imperialistic by nature, a fully capitalism caused Britain to embark on an age of empire-building, thus setting the stage for the eventual globalization of capitalism.

Overall, her theory is coherent, but I think there logical fallacy in it.  Wood’s argument suggests two things: (1) that capitalism is not natural, that it is just a happy accident arising out of a specific set of circumstances, and (2) that as such, there are viable alternatives to capitalism which we may impose upon society.  Wood suggests socialism as a viable alternative.  The fact that she does not provide any framework for doing so can be overlooked.  The key is that she suggests it is possible because capitalism is not natural and was a choice.  Yet, in her own argument she posits that capitalism is, by its very nature, expansionistic—it will constantly spread by exploiting technology, labor, natural resources, and any other means at its disposal.  As an accidental development, it is entirely possible that capitalism might never have come into being.  However, given her stance on capitalism’s innate expansionist drive, is it possible that having been established that capitalism can ever be toppled?  I don’t think she has made her case for the reversibility of capitalism.

entry.title: Reaction
entry.content:
First, let me say that, while I hate to complain about the legnth of such a quick and short book, it could have been much shorter; It seems as though Ms. Wood felt the need or the desire–depending upon her arrogance, I suppose– to make a point and then spend five to ten  pages repeating it.

Second, aftern  noticing on the back that the cover design to my verson is attributed to  ”random”, I noticed that it really is.  At least Webber’s book has a picture of the proto-protestant on its cover.

Third, I really like the Idea of capitalism being essentially a social event, such as Brenner and Thompson present.  Wealth seems to have gone from serving a practical and social purpose (first, stability then the acquisition of luxury items) to becoming the purpose of effort; which may or may not be the defintion of capitalism.

This brings me to my point: I take issue with what appears to be her definition of Capitalism and what I believe to be the general definition of capitalism. The Capitalist ethic, most people might agree, is that a person uses an advantage in a product–whether it be a surplus or even simple availability– to sell for more then it cost to acquire or produce. Her alienation of worker efficiency from “extra-economic” advantages– or the separation of “market” and  ”Markets”, which seems to imply that competitive advantage is eliminated once the technology of transportation is eliminated and causes people to look for another advantage–  allows her to make a social point about the all-inclusive nature of capitalism  but removes perhaps the “spirit” of common capitalist critique. Morally speaking (and I am not saying she is making a moral point) ,  Capitalism then becomes not just the evil of greed but instead is just the evil of exploitation; I am not sure the difference is so important.

entry.title: Thoughts on Confronting Historical Paradigms
entry.content: This was a heavy read, but the overall message I truly appreciated.  The point of the book was to challenge the sweeping general theories of the Capitalist World System, Labor, and peasantries by using Africa and Latin America as the case examples to how the system doesn’t fit.  I enjoyed how the creation of the world capitalist system was done by historians who did not engage in “issues of anthropology and social science, language and literature, and ‘native’ worlds of knowledge and scholarship.”  The ignoring of  these schools of thought by what the book often refers to as “north atlantic historians” failed to point out that agrarian society vs industrialized society don’t fit Capitalism World System.  Peasantry resistance to Capitalism essentially denied the Capitalist World System with use of flight, banditry, refusal to produce cash crops by returning to subsistence farming and sabotage of cash crops.  When the authors analyze the Latin American and African contexts, the Capitalism World System simply doesn’t fit the complexities of non-western society.

entry.title: Confronting Historical Paradigms 10/03/10
entry.content:
I must admit that this book was a little difficult to get through; I’m not a fan of economic history or Marxist theory. Even though the work seemed to deal largely with peasant movements, it still had that feel of economics about it, which I find sometimes difficult to understand and often hard to become engaged with.

That being said, I did like the focus on peasants as individuals and the idea that we must study peoples as singular units instead of lumping them together. Though I do not have a background in economic historical theory, it seems to me that the world-systems theory does subsume many people and cultures into the desire to create a label and a paradigm, which likely is not as universal as it wants to be. Stern’s discussion of the Potosi silver mine was an insightful dismantling of Wallerstein’s thesis, I thought.

I particularly enjoyed Isaacman and Roseberry’s essays, perhaps because they did not concentrate on the historiography and the theory quite as much (or perhaps their essays were just longer, so the theory took up proportionately less space), areas with which I’m not familiar. They seemed more engaged with the actual history and with presenting concrete examples, along the lines of Stern’s Potosi mine, to illustrate/discredit the theories they were discussing. I would have liked for some of Isaacman’s information to have been more developed; it felt at times as though he was slinging snippets of data at the reader to prove his point by the sheer number of examples he could use. Roseberry’s section was very good at pointing out that Marxism often doesn’t consider the agrarian peasant—it focuses on the wage-worker.

As Amanda has said, when I began reading the book, I was expecting the authors to be blatantly anti-Marx. Instead, they seem to accept some of his basic ideas, but with some modifications, specifically the need to address groups individually instead of universally.

entry.title: Confronting Historical Paradigms post
entry.content:
I think the organization of this book added to its effectiveness. As outlined in the introduction, each essay looked primarily at a specific historical paradigm relating to the study of Latin America or Africa. I agree that placing Africa and Latin America side-by-side added to the study, as certain similarities and differences in past scholarly assumptions were highlighted. The introduction sets up the splintering of traditional modes of thought about Latin American and African studies nicely; rooting it in various experiences of the 1960’s and 70’s, while still noting earlier examples. This book now deals with further changes in scholarship, starting from the 1980’s. I though Stern’s argument against viewing Latin American economics as either the result of feudalism or capitalism was very persuasive; it is clear that neither alone suffices. Cooper’s evaluation of the changes in African scholarship were the most interesting essay to me. It is somewhat embarrassing how many scholars in the past dismissed African history entirely. This necessitated a generation of scholars that affirmed African uniqueness, but there was still more work to be done. As Cooper states, “that Africans had their own points of view and their own history was revealing only to people who believed they did not. A new generation of students took that point for granted and found that Africanists offered no particular set of questions and theoretical issues.”(85) Coopers addendum to his original work was also interesting, to see how scholarship has progressed, and I think his point that “underdevelopment” leads one to think there is a point of normalcy in other nation’s developments that Africans are behind, is very well taken(196). It is always interesting how certain biases seem to come back around, even from historians with good intentions.
Isaacman looks at how the study of peasants voices has progressed; its insight and its potential difficulties. It is certainly true that misinterpretation, either culturally or language-based, is a potent danger for scholars or varying experience dealing with unofficial reports of the people at large, who many times have shared vocabulary and mutual understandings unique to them(225). The essay then looks at studies of how peasant lives changed under capitalism, and peasant accounts are a vital record to these and other studies. The book then shifts back to Latin American was Roseberry’s essay, who looks at peasants, as well. I think this essay was wise to come last(besides the conclusion), because it notes the scholarship already contained in the book and expands off of it. Finally, the concluding essay nicely ties the essays back together with certain themes and areas of future research. This was an impressive bit of scholarship. While it must be admitted that it is probably not intriguing or necessarily accessible to the casual history reader, for our study of the study of history, it was very helpful.

entry.title: Reflections on 'Confronting Historical Paradigms'
entry.content:
It is by now axiomatic to say that the 1990s were a decade that changed the world. Of course, when Americans express such thoughts, they typically are referring to political developments in their world – i.e., the First World.

But in this work, which was released in 1993 – and which is subtitled “Peasants, Labor, and the Capitalist World System in Africa and Latin America” – the authors consider other realms, and the roots of the economic dynamics found therein. In doing so, those writers address developments that often get short shrift, to the extent that they are remembered at all, in the U.S.

In considerations of the “underdeveloped” state of much of Africa and Latin America, the principles of dependency theory and world-system theory traditionally have been evoked. So it is interesting to see this book’s authors characterize those beliefs as overly simplistic and even “circular” in their logic.

Likewise intriguing are the writers’ examination of, and sometimes outright challenges to, notions regarding the nature and origins of peasantry and the African slave trade.

Finally, because this work, as tends to be the case with any such effort, comprises a snapshot of views as they then existed, as shaped by that which had come before, it is interesting to take the authors’ interpretations and compare them with what since has happened (e.g., the spread of poverty in Latin America, the official end of Apartheid in South Africa, the furtherance of Robert Mugabe’s controversial land reform program in Zimbabwe).

That’s the sort of thing we now, like they then, can do with the benefit of hindsight.
