entry.title: It's A Small World, After All...
entry.content:
OK, I’m going to attempt to do less summarizing and more opinion oriented blog posts on the books from now on.

I actually really enjoyed this book. The essays really tear into modern Marxist conceptions of the world-system. I enjoy seeing universalist concepts being overthrown, because there are no absolutes in history. The region by region analysis of the capitalist world-system, pointing out a hundred exceptions to it, very effectively tears a hole in the entire concept. The world-system is revealed to be a very, very small world, consisting mostly of Europe, North America, and prosperous Asia, with Africa and Latin America being shown to not fit in with the neat conceptions. The African examples were, to me, even more powerful than the Latin American ones, which used a number of modes of production and had their own economic platform, but were still practicing capitalist forms of economic practice. In Africa, on the other hand, “peasants” among others actively and successfully resisted incorporation into the capitalist world-system. The capitalist model is neither universal nor inevitable.

The chapter on peasants in Africa was my favorite. I like resistance stories anyway, and a description of the systems by which the “peasants” resisted integration through everything from flight to banditry, and refusing to partake in cash crop economy by returning to subsistence farming. The Latin American segment afterwards reinforces, to me, the fact that Marxism doesn’t take into account the agrarian world nearly enough, a fact Mao and Lenin tried to incorporate in their own ways, though their theories are failed ones in my opinion as well. Agrarian societies are so far out of the scope of the industrialized world that Westerners don’t know what to do with them—or at least the Marxist world-system doesn’t.

So if the world-system breaks down when you look outside of the industrialized world, what does that leave us? Is Marxism invalid? I think economic superstructure is still a valid jumping off point, but the progression of universal capitalism into socialism seems to be pretty much not true.

entry.title: Confronting Historical Paradigms
entry.content:
Confronting Historical Paradigms, Cooper et al.

The overall thrust of Confronting Historical Paradigms, is that the established analytical frameworks of history are inherently ethnocentric in that they are generated by a capitalist culture (either directly or by way of a response to it) that ultimately force native populations into foreign universal paradigms without regard to cultural applicability.  A prime example is the Marxist envisioning of peasants in Africa and Latin American as members of the European proletariat.  Generalization is classified as a useful tool, but this comes with an important caveat: in evaluating history the world system must not be seen as the most important factor, it must be carefully balanced with accounts of local cultures, peoples, and governments (which may defy linear metanarratives).  Thus, the authors deconstruct the monolithic world system, arguing that it is actually defined by a multitude of local factors and experiences.

The ethnocentric paradigms were difficult to give up, and scholars searched for ways to force their evaluations into the structure of existing paradigms.  By the 1980s “a series of ‘post-isms’ and events in the Third and socialist worlds all contributed to blowing most paradigmatic lids off permanently.”  In arguing that foreign or ethnocentric structures are no longer valid, the book suggests that academic openness is the key to preventing similar forced evaluations in the future.  The goal is to keep the avenues of debate open to human agency, regionalism or localism, and to include as many different perspectives as possible. 

While not perfect, when taken as a whole, the book provides a good framework for understanding the development of the different conceptual structures western scholars have used to examine non-western and colonial cultures.  Such a discussion cannot help but reveal the misconceptions created by such a system or the historical blinders it places on academics evaluating these periods and places.  Thus, while I dislike the book’s organization because I feel it presents a lack of continuity, it was a useful read.

entry.title: African laborer, Latin American peasant, or something else...
entry.content:
It seems to be the same pattern with each of the texts I read.  In the course of learning what the author is attempting to elucidate, I get a secondary education in words and authors.  This go-round, I learned words like reification and obfuscation, which are nearly opposite.  I got to learn about Wallerstein’s core, structural-functionalism, African agency, modernization theory, underdevelopment theory, and modes of production analysis. The five authors cover these topics very deeply with examples and case studies, and enough notes and references to make another book.  Seriously, Chapter 4 alone was 60 pages long, and then had 54 pages of notes/references to back up what Isaacman wrote about peasants in Africa. 
I won’t rehash a synopsis of the book, but a couple things stood out to me.  First, all the authors seem as if they are covering time-frames in African and Latin American history from a capitalist-Marxist viewpoint. They are following what is happening in these areas as the people move with fits, sputters, trials, and tribulations toward capitalism.  Isaacman refers to all these attempts at labeling and studying such changes as paradigms. (209)  The peasants, slaves, workers, and various other non-elite characters are viewed as they go about resisting capital’s control, thwarting capital’s advance into their life – forcing changes they do not want.  Second, they are critiquing and expounding ideas of others in light of new research of themselves and others and recent ‘paradigm’ shifts.  Mostly they advocate listening to the peasant voices, both from oral histories and those hidden within written records of the controlling political powers.
My problem with all this is that these authors are trying to place all of this within the context of a capitalist-Marxist world view.  I feel that both Africa and Latin America, and even North America and Asia for that matter, are areas that developed for millennia outside the European sphere.  Asia in the form of China and Japan achieved a written language long before the others, including Europe, and even the Mesoamerican empires of the Mayan, Inca, and Aztecs had their own form of written communication.  Asia is touched upon at the end of the book as a reference, and the author did start on hegemony, (388-9) but they did not go that much deeper.  The main idea that leaps out at me is that the European nations exercised the idea of ‘might makes right’ over established nations who could not match them militaristically, or better as the right of conquest.  China was able to withstand their onslaught until the opium wars I think, when the British used their military to broker a business deal the Chinese were unwilling to make.  Africa and Latin America did not have such a large unifying government like the Chinese.  The Aztecs were close militarily until disease reduced their numbers and their vassals decided to deal with the Spanish – that really turned out well for them.

What these authors seem to be writing about is the continued resistance of those conquered people.  If these dissimilar groups could agree that ‘the enemy of my enemy is my friend’ then they may be able to assert their collective will to achieve a better life for their descendants, or as seemed the case time after time, to be left alone in their world without greed and ambition.  Who knows what kind of world system would have emerged if these people had been left to develop at their own pace and in their own way.

entry.title: hist510- Against Marx
entry.content:
When I first began reading Confronting Historical Paradigms, I  expected to encounter a strong anti-Marxian critique that systematically proved the fallibility of his economic and historical theory. What is actually contained within this book is much different and, to my surprise, much more enjoyable. Taken as a whole, the book would be somewhat lengthy and difficult to slough through due to the detailed information contained within its pages. It is clear that each contributing author is intimately familiar with their particular subject and that knowledge comes through in sometimes overwhelming force. Fortunately, Confronting Historical Paradigms is a collection of individual essays confronting the imposition of dominant historical paradigms onto non-Western countries and arguing for the advent of new paradigms that allow for greater variability. The book’s division into self-contained chapters makes it much easier to get through, as well as keeping it interesting by providing several different opinions on the same general topic. Overall, I found this book to be engaging, thought-provoking and above all persuasive in its claims.

I found the first main chapter of the book, that by Steve Stern, to be one of the most interesting sections. His focus on Latin America highlighted many of the limitations of Marxian economic theory when applied to non-Western countries, particularly through the two case studies he provides. I also found his critique of other systematic historical paradigms to be rather enlightening, notably his critical assessment of Wallerstein’s theory of a world system. I found myself in complete agreement with his assertion that history is simply too complex and varied to be explained with a single paradigm. This is even more true when that paradigm is derived from the experiences of Western Europe and then forcibly applied elsewhere, regardless of applicability. This section once again emphasized the Euro-centric aspect of much historical scholarship and the limitations of such a development. Stern does a convincing job at explaining why existing historical paradigms are insufficient for some areas of historical study, although he does not really provide a valid alternative. Marxist theory in particular does not work because, according to Stern, his system does not incorporate all aspects of historical life, such as peasants and peasantries. A more specific approach is needed to truly understand Latin American history.

 The chapter by Frederick Cooper on Africa and the World Economy was also rather enjoyable, although a little more difficult to get through due to the huge amount of information compressed into a few pages. Thankfully, Cooper provides a brief overview of the three primary historical paradigms used for studying African history, a decision I appreciated as someone who is somewhat unfamiliar with theoretical studies of Africa. Cooper main contention against existing paradigms differed from Sterns; Cooper argues that these models do not provide a deep enough analysis and such questions as why, for whom and at who’s expense need to be addressed more thoroughly. Cooper does not have an issue with looking at Africa as a whole; in fact, he asserts that is it appropriate to study Africa in context with the world economy because of its undeniable influence on African history. However, whatever system is used needs to be more flexible than those in existence. According to Cooper, and I found myself in full agreement, the Marxist system is too mechanical and does not allow for changes and variances. I was particularly interested in his section on the different development rates of capitalism and how some precursors actually hindered its development. I think one of his biggest criticisms of Marx, although he does not come out and say this, rests with the impersonal nature of Marxist history. His theory simply does not allow for much human agency, particularly on the part of peasants.

Chapter 4 by Allen Isaacman focuses almost exclusively on the difficult role of placing peasants in history. I found Isaacman’s defense for greater incorporation of peasant studies to be persuasive. For me, at least, this chapter was also just an enjoyable and interesting read from the very beginning with his discussion on the complications involved in the term peasant. I was also surprised to find a strong Foucaultian influence throughout this section as well, although after reading it I believe that this particular approach was an excellent decision and added a great deal of depth to his argument. It was interesting to think about peasants not as a unified class, but as a much more complex social group that experienced both interclass and intraclass struggles. Isaacman also made a good point in his explanation for the history of peasant studies and the changes it has undergone in recent years as well as some of its limitations: evidence. The type of evidence a historian utilizes determines to a great extent  what conclusions will be drawn. In stark contrast to Marx, Isaacman believes that it is necessary to use a much more localized approach to historical study; he believes there are simply too many variations and anomalies within peasant life for a single system to apply.

The last main chapter of the book, that by William Roseberry, was my least favorite. Although he made some interesting points, I did not enjoy his approach as much those taken by the other authors. He provided a thorough examination of the structure of agrarian questions rather than looking at some of the questions and their results, which I would have been more interested in on a personal level. Theoretically, however, this section was enlightening and certainly expanded my appreciation for agrarian history. Like Roseberry, I would agree that agrarian history should be incorporated within the larger historical narrative in order to provide a more complete picture. One of the most interesting points of Roseberry’s argument was his critique of Marxist theory. He argues, correctly I believe, that the dominance of Marxist history has pervaded history to the point that many scholars do not question the application of his ideas and categories. These categories, however, are not always appropriate and are certainly not applicable to Latin American peasantries. It is wrong for them to be lumped into a class context against a capitalist versus non-capitalist background, for this particular approach fails to accurately grasp the nature of agrarian societies.

This books was both an interesting, enjoyable and insightful read. It was refreshing to see so many convincing arguments against the Marxist theory, particularly ones that provided what I believe to be a fuller historical approach. I also enjoyed the variance of ideas proposed within the book’s pages; instead of one critique expounded upon by contributing authors, each provided an individual refutement of Marxist ideas based upon knowledge of their particular subject. For me, this made the book much more engaging and, I think, convincing overall. I put Confronting Historical Paradigms down conscious of the importance of regionalized variations, the importance of human agency and the many ways in which different historical paradigms interact to propel new advancements in the methodological approach to historical study.

entry.title: Marxism, Excepted
entry.content:
Once again we have a long-winded book full of so many trees I can’t enjoy the forest. My favorite part of the entire 400 pages was the bit about the women resisting expectations to create erosion control, because I can totally identify. I don’t like economics, I don’t understand economics, and I’m tired, tired, tired of spending days and days of my life trying to decipher interminable monographs about economics. It takes so much effort just to find the gist of their articles that I have no energy, time, or motivation left to evaluate or synthesize them. So, here’s my hard-won summary, but that is as far as I can go. I have had it with this book.

Chapter one, by Steve Stern, introduced the theme that recent scholarship has evolved away from grand narratives to more localized and specific studies. This seems like splintering and loss, but opens up the possibility of discussions and resonances. It put me in mind of the step from singing in unison to parts—it’s difficult and confusing at first, but eventually yields much richer and more beautiful music.

Chapter two, also by Steve Stern, evaluated Wallerstein’s theories in light of Latin American evidence. Wallerstein said we have to look at the whole world as a system, the core/semi-periphery/periphery have different labor styles, labor methods determine political possibilities, and capitalism finds the best combination of free and coerced labor.

When Stern tried these out for the silver industry, he found that various labor relations existed concurrently, and while Latin America’s silver affected the world as expected Wallerstein’s theories didn’t explain the world’s effect on Latin America. In order to explain Latin American development, you need to include local power sources and their goals, and peasants’ resistance to becoming wage laborers.

Looking at the sugar industry showed weaknesses in the periphery equals slavery idea, because slavery was only resorted to after other labor systems didn’t work, and even within a system of slavery, there were bits of autonomy and accumulation.

So, the grand theory didn’t hold up to focused, detailed, specific examples, because they offered too much variety for a generalized system.

Chapter three, the longest and most irritating, was written by Frederick Cooper, who seriously needs some time in a journalism class. Brevity and succinctness are good things, though apparently very elusive in academic writing. First, he looked at different grand theories, and how they fared against evidence in Africa. Neo-Classical scholars have a single model, only one idea for rational motivation so when Africa didn’t fit it was seen as inadequacy in Africa, and a focus on markets and products instead of the structures and people who influenced them. Dependence and Underdevelopment models look at a core that drains surplus from the periphery, and define periphery as where surplus is drained from, so end up saying nothing. Cooper says they have a good idea, but it’s too crude and general to provide useful insights. Marxism looks at production instead of markets, and says capitalism didn’t develop in Africa because they couldn’t eliminate alternatives to wage labor because about the same time efficiency would have become necessary, transportation advances made the status quo a better option, so no class was able to accumulate enough to begin the capitalist cycle.

Then he looked at events across time. In Gold to Slaves he said that slavery was a method of controlling the populace in addition to being a source of funds and power, and it didn’t require excluding others from resources so it didn’t lead to the accumulation necessary to start capitalism. In Slaves to Peanuts, he looked at merchant capital and their need for peace instead of the violence that had supported the slave trade. Imperialists had as much trouble controlling the populace as African leaders had had, so once again, capitalism didn’t develop as the theories had predicted. In Agriculture and the Colonial State he looked at many attempts to corral the African people into their role as wage laborers and how those attempts have failed. Local leaders only knew domination and plunder, so they weren’t good partners; the enforced peace gave workers new options to avoid becoming wage laborers, and they consistently preferred food crops and autonomy to cash crops and subjection.

Then he provided many more pages of examples of ways Africa didn’t fit the tidy European model of Marxism. His basic point is that Africa has too much available land and too much peasant resistance for the standard sequence to work. Capital in Africa has had to create new goals and strategies in order to salvage any kind of success.

His conclusion was—shockingly—that previous ideologies had imposed our schemata on African situations, but since Africans have different circumstances and priorities, European ideas don’t support their history.

Chapter four, by Allen Isaacman, was about peasants in Africa. They resisted colonialism’s imposition of commodity production in a variety of ways, based on the different circumstances and positions of each sort of peasant. After looking at some examples of this resistance, he considered acts of retribution, a la Robin Hood. These made statements, and relieved resentment, and occasionally led to policy changes. Songs, jokes and other cultural contributions provided a perception and identity that supported actual acts of subversion and so are also a form of resistance.

He looked at conflicts within peasant communities as well as peasants against rulers, though even here he said that the imposition of colonial/capitalist expectations intensified those conflicts in many ways. As young people and females resisted elders and males, they got experience and confidence to resist other forms of power. Organized political resistance developed when everyday forms of subversion were no longer possible. A good area for study is how peasants act to organize their resources for these concerted rebellions.

Chapter five, by William Roseberry, looked at peasants in Latin America, and how research has evolved over the years. In the 1960s people asked questions about the peasants instead of considering questions of the peasants, which cast them as props or victims instead of as actors. Researchers lumped all peasants together as those oppressed by colonial powers, and assumed some recent upset that had instigated the current upheaval and suffering. These sweeping universals ignored varieties and missed insights that come from closer, deeper looks.

Historians and anthropologists each have something to contribute to the study of peasants in Latin America. As they communicate and swap ideas, they’ve come to a regional focus that allows a good balance of specificity ad connection, and also uncovers new sources of data. Looking at variations in haciendas and coffee production has already produced new insights and led to new questions.

He concludes by saying that studies need “historical and sociological content” (359) in order to substantiate their conclusions and theories, and gives evidence that this is beginning to happen.

Chapter six, by Florencia Mallon, summarized and synthesized the other chapters, and called for the next big idea. She said there had been two scholarly revolutions within her career, the one in the 70’s moving from world to local, and the one in the late 80’s going from communities to sub-groups like feminism and such. They’ve both challenged previous assumptions and over-generalizations, which was helpful, but they’ve left scholars with no way to organize their findings. Now it’s time to find new theories and structures to guide inquiry, but this time these scaffolds need to be written in pencil as supports instead of in pen as mental cages. After a whole book that showed the inadequacies of overarching ideas, she ended by saying that researchers can’t just eliminate structures because they’re the way to turn discrete data from particular cases into coherent narratives that provide insight and significance.

Then she spent some time comparing various studies and articles to show how their differences could inform and strengthen each other. She added subaltern ideas from India as another source of perspectives that would strengthen productive dialogues.

So, after 400 pages, we have: old over-generalized theories don’t work in Africa and Latin America. Once researchers looked at specifics they found more exceptions and variations, and so they need new ways to consider their data. Communication between areas and disciplines will provide richer ideas and questions, and lead to a more elastic and accurate overarching theme. Color me underwhelmed. And cranky. Obviously.

entry.title: On Confronting Historical Paradigms
entry.content:
In Confronting Historical Paradigms by Steve J. Stern et. al., the authors provide detailed critiques of the attitudes and language employed by world systems theorists and make suggestions for the improvement of historical analysis.  Specifically, the authors advocate taking an approach toward Latin and African materialist models and their affects on the individual peasantries, as opposed to earlier attempts to define a single peasantry construct.  However, they also point out that even world systems theory doesn’t always apply to the European model, which was the metropole to developing peripheries.

The major issue with world systems theory, and its offshoots, as these authors point out, is the overgeneralized, even false classification and characterization of peasants, as if they were the Marxist model of a European proletariat, or as if they existed as voiceless, unchanging shadows in a capitalist system.  The grouping of the differing seigneurial systems in Mexico and Oaxaca into one model is a prime example; as is the differing situation of peasantries in South Africa and the Western Sahara.  However, the authors are clear to point out that it is not wrong to place a particular group within an economic system, as long as proper care is taken to avoid the pitfalls of viewing the world system as the most important for historical analysis, as opposed to peoples, regions or states.

My overall impression of this collection is that the authors did an good job of using specific example to, not completely condemn, but explaining and break down some of the historical misconceptions that were developed within cultural and social mindsets from the 1950s to the 1980s, while offering up positive trends toward productive alternatives for future historical analyses.

entry.title: Marx-Engels and Postone
entry.content:
I began the reading this week with the Marx-Engels Reader. I read a selection and then switched to Postone’s book before finishing with Marx. I am very glad I did, because I feel Postone’s analysis helps express some Marxist theories in a slightly more accessible way. I enjoyed that selection, though it took a while to wade through, because it successfully presented Marxist theories in a way that complemented(and occasionally challenged) more typical interpretations. The selection from Postone dealt specifically with the Captial Vol. I section of the Marx-Engels Reader. However, I was interested to see how many of the ideas had already presented themselves in the section of “German Ideology,” which I had previously read. For example, the circulation of commodities was explained in Postone’s work (page 264) as “a quasi-natural network of social connections; although it lies beyond their control,” based on Marx(207-09). However on page 162 of the Marx-Engels Reader, the idea of an oppressive world trade that “hovers over the earth like the fate of the ancients, and with an invisible hand allots fortune and misfortune to men, sets up empires and overthrows empires, causes nations to rise and to disappear,” was already introduced. This is also true of the rejection of Hegelian interpretation of history(Postone, 285; Marx 148-49, 154). This is not surprising, since these are fundamental components of Marx’s worldview, and some continuity of theme would lend some fluidity to the work(if also some redundancy). However, I think it is important to note, that in all the discussion of empirical evidence to support his theories, there are certain narratives that are supported above others with a persistence that makes me wonder what evidence to the contrary may have been purposefully excluded.
I was particularly interested, in reading both these works, by the divisions of concepts such as labor, value, and time, into smaller subcategories. These notions are often conflated in my own mind, so to read them as separate, though intrinsically linked, entities was very intriguing as a way to broaden my own analysis of history. The one I was especially interested in was the multiple divisions of the concept of time, and further how these separate components of time impact value. I think the argument is particularly strong when it discusses the notion that “value is an expression of time in the present.”(Postone, 296) The argument that as advancements become generalized, they are no longer seen as advancements, but become the new baseline of normal production can certainly be seen in our society to this day, and it promotes the idea of perpetual need for growth and a directional nature of development expressed elsewhere in the work. I am glad to have read more about Marxist philosophy, rather than the abridged versions I have dealt with in the past that discussed only the need for revolution. While certainly prevalent throughout the Marx-Engels reader, these arguments are much more complex and intriguing than simply the high school summary of “capitalism is corrupt, workers unite!” to which I was first introduced.

entry.title: Reflections on Marx-Engels and Postone
entry.content:
Socialism, communism, Marxism. These ideologies, as grounded in the works of Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels, unquestionably changed the world. They were espoused by forces of political revolution in Russia and China, which in turn spread/imposed those ideals within their spheres of influence.

An overly simplistic summation, certainly, but it gets to the heart of a notion that for decades was embraced by the “the Iron Curtain” and feared by the capitalistic West.

Certainly, Marx’s words leave no doubt as to the mutual exclusivity of those two worlds. As he wrote in “Wage Labour and Capital,” “(E)very social reform remains a utopia until the proletarian revolution and the feudalistic counter-revolution measure swords in a world war.” Scary stuff.

That “real movement which abolishes the present state of things” (as described in “The German Ideology”) was to represent “an act of the dominant peoples ‘all at once,’” leading ultimately to a classless society.

Sounds good – in theory.

But for all their expounding of economic principles, for all their historical ruminations, for all their cynicism, Marx and Engels display remarkable naivete as regards human nature.

So it is that the Soviet Union and Red China cannot be said to represent anything even close to a true “dictatorship of the proletariat.” So it is that the former, economically and morally bankrupt, collapsed in the early 1990s. So it is that the latter, with its billion-plus consumers, has become quite willing to do business with, and to a growing extent emulate, the capitalist world (although one wonders if this phenomenon could to some extent play into Lenin’s prediction that “The Capitalists will sell us the rope with which we will hang them”).

At any rate, Marx wrote that “We shall try to make our presentation as simple and popular as possible” (“Wage Labour and Capital”). The extent to which he and Engels succeeded in this regard is debatable. But Postone’s “Time, Labor, and Social Domination: A Reinterpretation of Marx’s Critical Theory” does little to further the cause.

By and large, and perhaps of necessity, Postone merely restates Marx’s ideas in different words. He occasionally does offer interesting elaboration or clarification. But original insights seem few and far between. Among them, however, is his assertion that “Marx’s conception of the social relations constituted in the sphere of production cannot be understood solely in terms of class relations of exploitation.”

entry.title: Thoughts on Marx and why I will to my best to Avoid him in the Future…
entry.content:
Marx says, “The relations of production in their totality constitute what is called the social relations, society, and, moreover, a society at a definite stage of historical development, a society with peculiar, distinctive characteristics. Ancient society, feudal society, bourgeois (or capitalist) society, is such totalities of relations of production, each of which denotes a particular stage of development in the history of mankind.”

He is boiling down society in history to mere production of goods or commodities.  Now as a historian in training I will not deny the importance of economy in politics(arguably they are mirror images), a great deal of events throughout history can be attributed to economic standpoints, HOWEVER, the fact that he ignores the affects of culture is simply repulsive.  Culture which in my view is intimately tied with Religion has had great impact in history weighing in as much as economics in the course of time.

Being a Medievalist, I cannot deny that individuals or classes in the medieval period acted for economic gain, however i cannot also deny that they did not believe in the religious righteousness of their actions.  An example would be the Crusades.  European Crusaders fought for the Holy Land for many reasons, Economic, Political and Cultural. Marx’s seemingly economic extreme denies that any individual would do anything without attaining some sort of commodity in return.

Postone explained “the circulation of commodities overcomes the temporal, spatial, and personal barriers imposed by the direct exchange of products.” This might be what Marx said but it’s does not take into account how Culture resisted and denied the circulation of commodities in certain places and times.  China and Japan resisted global markets out of cultural reasons and were only brought to the fold of globalization after invasion or coercion by global powers.  Marx never fully appreciates the power of culture and its imposition on economics itself! He always assumes it goes the other way around.

entry.title: Marky Marx and the Funky Bunch
entry.content:
I’ve always heard that Marx was a good historian (sometimes this would be replaced with philosopher) who was a terrible fortune teller. I think, in a large way, those impressions were right.

There is, however, a lot to good to say about Marx. There are many who dismiss him simply because Communism failed in eastern Europe. That is, however, short sighted.  While many of the compliments thrown his way are summed up best when Foucault called him a “founder of discursivity”, it seems prescient to reiterate just how influential his work was: even those who disagree with him are forced, in essence, to speak his language.  However, I believe where the true dissonance appears between Marx and his detractors appears when we fail to recognize the social conditions of his day. It seems Marx had an odd connection with the Romantics for a man who disagreed so much with non-concrete or non-empirical evidence.  I wonder, too, if the Romantics on a fundamental level were more successful than Marx in actively engaged change. The “Communists” Marx speaks of– who require revolution– in one sense came before Marx in the form of Blake and Byron. They are separated now not only through history but ideologically (though both are generally and anachronistically placed on the left) in how they attempted change; for the Romantics usually fought localized wars and battles while Communists had a more global aim.

Again, these are anachronistic comparisons. Certainly, the horrors of everyday life (especially for the poor) we made all the more ghastly by the machine’s which Marx writes of, both in terms of poverty and in real violence and accidents.  Certainly, the world in which the totalitarian governments who ostensibly claimed his philosophy operated   offered an even more dangerous method of implementation.

Marx, I think, would have shuddered in fear and hatred at the government which came to be associated with his philosophy thought nothing of the people. And, perhaps, thats where the implementation of his philosophy failed: as his philosophy  was born with a bent toward a consciousness based purely on physical conditions, he left too little room for the human element to stand as a last line of defense against atrocity.

entry.title: German Ideology
entry.content:
Okay, I’m a little lost in all this.  Are Marx and Engels pro-Hegel or anti-Hegel, or do they just not care because it all concerns religious matters not political ones.  Marx moves from the philosophical, Hegelian, concerns to real human beings in historical settings.  It all comes to that division of labor angle for Marx, starting with ownership.  Tribal, communal and State, Feudal, and Monarchal all rose and fell through conquest.  His idea of ascending from earth to heaven (154) says a lot about his humanist tendencies.  He wanted real life, which is where he felt positive science began. (155)  History in four moments is interesting; you live, you have needs, you procreate, then you interact.  Now we come to division of labor and private property, along with oppression and want.  It comes to a call for communism, and a fight against the enslaving world market.  Once national and local barriers are removed, communism will allow the proletariat to have all things in common, and then will history truly have meaning.  Until that time, history is separated from ordinary life. (165)  Marx explores location as important in the production of historical consciousness.  The French and English follow political illusion, but the Germans operate on religious illusion; the Hegelian philosophy.  This is where the starting point of history is, the religious man puts the production of fancies in place of the means of subsistence and of life itself.  Marx seems more anti-religious than anything else.  Not just with the religious “fancies,” but also in saying that the “realm of God” existed only in the imagination. (166)
I like his definition of an historical product – the result of the activity of a whole succession of generations, each standing on the shoulders of the preceding one.  I would also agree with him that the nature that preceded human history is the nature which no longer exists today. (170,171) 
The basis of ideology: town vs. country/ burgher vs. lord / laborer vs. serf
The town provided order, defense, and a political association.  This was the beginning of the separation of capital and landed gentry.  In the towns, capital was from individuals; the merchants emerged as the separation between production and commerce.  The burgher’s ability to organize their town for defense and to link it with other towns for information and trade raised their class against the nobility.  After feudalism had succumbed, the guilds were the new threat to this new class of elites.  The merchants led to the manufacturers who could produce in quantity for large markets.  This in turn led to big industry and world markets, which Marx claims as the beginning of world history. (185) From this we see capitalists appear along with the working class, proletariats.  Marx’s main idea though is communism, where the individual subjects the material power and abolishes the division of labor.  So then, the proletariat must overthrow the state to assert itself. (197,200)  With all this going on, you can see why the Germanic area was also the physical battleground of Europe as well as the philosophical.

entry.title: Engels on why there are babies and States...
entry.content:
I do not know why the feminist movement did not latch onto Engels during the Women’s Lib era.  His findings that women were the main power manipulators of ancient times should have been a major attraction.  That men forced themselves to the head for economic reason should only re-enforce women’s sense of disfranchisement, when he claimed the first class oppression as being the female sex by the male. (739)  It would seem that Engels is very down on marriage, at least the monogamous kind.  His belief that only oppressed people can have a truly loving relationship seems more politically created rhetoric.  In his struggle with the capitalist class, Engels appears as if he is trying to place a seed of doubt in the minds of the ruling class by questioning their true loyalty to even their marriage partner.  Perhaps this is where the idea of a pre-nuptial agreement came into being.  He further tries to bring the children into the fray with the idea that their greedy parental units could easily disinherit them because they did not like them.  If I forget, ask me in class about my personal knowledge of this.  Back on point; he does come back to the notion that true sex love is marriage, and it is by nature monogamous.
Engels history of the State is quite insightful.  Why the original association of peoples, the need to protect their territory, the need to organize society and maintain order.  Why taxes are actually necessary – proper use of the revenues gained is an entirely different and very long discussion.
The political power and class control the State provides allude to the change in purpose it has undergone while in operation.  That politics is co-opted by the producers of wealth for the protection of their agenda is to say that the workers are being pushed out of a place that is rightfully theirs.  His closing call for equality, brotherhood, and universal education are a hopeful note on which to end.

entry.title: 9/26/10 Marx
entry.content:
Like some other people, I certainly found Marx easier to read than Hegel. Having never read any of Marx’s own writings before, and only being familiar with his ideas through the filter of media and education, I was excited to actually read what he wrote. I appreciated his, at least intended, approach to discuss his views in terms of “materialism,” that is, real people, real events, and real phenomena; as opposed to starting with the Ideal of consciousness and trying to relate that back to humanity. However, as I read through the sections, I couldn’t help but think that at times, Marx himself veered off into Ideals. Yes, everything was couched in terms of linen, coats, workers, bees, and use-values, but it’s still all very theoretical and full of supposition.

I found his small sections about labor conditions the most interesting, given the appalling lack of safe conditions in factories at the time; it was noteworthy, though, that Marx didn’t seem to really advance any concrete ideas toward fixing the problems, beyond reiterating how awful/unfair the capitalistic society that had created the conditions was. Also noteworthy was the way in which Marx saw the capitalistic overlords as the descendants of medieval feudal lords, thus making the wage-laborer, who sells his body, in a sense, the descendant of serfs.

Throughout, some of his terminology was difficult to latch onto, and I found myself having to flip back to previous sections to remember definitions. At times, I wondered whether all his theories would just fall apart (beyond what we know of Communism today) if the terms were defined slightly differently.

Finally, I was struck by how much the Communist theory pervaded everything in society, in Marx’s view. I especially noticed this in the “Origin of Family…” section, in which historically the wife became the proletariat. Despite what we know about current theories regarding the potential matrilineal nature of some early civilizations, I didn’t find anything in Marx, per se, that gave evidence toward this. There was simply an assertion that it was so, before linking the idea of the subjugation of women with the oppression of the worker. It made me wonder what Marx/Engels thought about women’s suffrage, or if the idea was postulated simply to further their economic ideas.

entry.title: Marxist Theory of History
entry.content:
Historical materialism operates from the fundamental assessment that history itself is not the collective actions and motives of individuals or groups, but that history is the collective tale of how mankind creates and recreates the material requirements of life.  Indeed, the only thing that serves to separate man from the lower animals is the ability to produces the means of survival.  In order to carry out the production of the means of survival, people enter into a society governed by their interactions regarding the means of production.  Therefore, history is driven by the social context of communal living—more precisely the economics of production. 

The social structure—the context of community—presupposes a larger superstructure known as the state in which serves to enforce the communal good over the individual good and regulate the interactions of production.  Ultimately this generates a group consciousness, but this group consciousness is removed from the individual and exists only as a part of his interactions with other men and serves to delude him into accepting his plight. 

As society develops, the relations of production become more complex, but they are firmly rooted in a growing division of labor and control of production by outside forces.  By the time capitalism emerges, civilization as moved beyond slavery and feudal serfdom, but the control of production is tightly controlled by capitalists, who are the heirs to feudal lords, as they privately own the means of production and commerce.  The more refined the system of production becomes, the more stratified society becomes and the smaller the class of controllers of production becomes.   The producers are reduced to wage laborers who exchange their energy for a meager subsistence represented by the artificial value of money which is exchanged for the means of survival, thus creating wage slaves. 

The principles of Marxist history seem to be easily broken down to a few simple tenets: (1) human society is based on the production of the means of subsistence, (2) the division of labor generates social classes based on type of labor performed, (3) production is based on the technology available, and (4) society evolves over time with modes of production and will eventually end in a socialist state.  Within this framework, then, history is relegated to class conflict, wherein the produces are continually struggling against those who own the means of production.   Society can only evolve when the lower classes challenge the superstructure of society.  The end result is revolution in favor of the proletariat. 

If one were to sum up Marx’s theory of history in a single sentence it might read thus: history is the story of class conflict over the means of production.  According to Marx, civilization develops along a set path determined by the technology of production and the relationship between producers and owners of production.  Ultimately, Marx postulates that this path will eventually lead to a socialist revolution.   Does this mean, then that Marxist history is utopian in its outlook?  How is this truly different from the Universal History of Kant and Hegel? 

Hegel suggests that the central arc of history is to be found in the freedom of the spirit; that history is the study of freedom with given cultures.  Freedom, Hegel, asserts begins as a privilege of despots, which is transferred to a privilege of the few, and ultimately ends in a widespread realization that humanity is free in and of itself (a civilization wherein all enjoy liberty).   Kant suggests that the driving force of history is found in reason.  He suggests that history can be seen as the realization of Nature’s plan for perfection.  Thus, Kant says history is the story of progress towards an unknown, but rational future. 

If we ignore Kant’s valorization of an unknown future state and Hegel’s conception of freedom as best enforced within constitutional monarchies, what difference is to be found as one moves towards Marx?  Marx necessarily supposes a universal history rooted in progress towards what he believes to be the realization of freedom.  Therein Marx incorporates both Hegelian and Kantian theories of history—progress and freedom.  The only difference to be found is in the motives of the actors.  Hegel and Kant would suggest reason drives the action of history, while Marx would say it is economics and class conflict.  Does this shift make that much of a difference?   Is the major difference between these theories they political outlook of the theorists themselves?  Is history simply a method of interpreting the past which is easily corrupted by theoreticians to achieve political ends?

Maybe Marx just annoys me so I want to annoy him.  I want to shout out: Annoy the liberals! Work hard and be happy.

entry.title: Karl Marx
entry.content:
I’m glad we read Hegel before Marx, so I could see why he presented his materialistic interpretation of reality in such a defensive way. Materialism seems so obvious to me that his attitude would have been perplexing if I’d not understood what he was challenging. Marx rejected the idea that concepts have independent reality, let alone intentionality, and began his theories with the fact that humans exist and that they have material needs in order to continue to exist (like Maslow’s Hierarchy). Because he begins with those needs, his worldview is based on production and ownership—everything is about economics.

In “German Idealism” he took several digs at Hegelians, saying that they began in heaven with ideas (154), that consciousness grows from life, not vice versa as they claim (155), and that History has no intent or self-consciousness (172). But on page 162, he said that communism is an ideal that reality needs to conform to, which seemed more than slightly Hegelian to me.

He had many ideas that made sense, but I never could follow his leap from This is how things are and how they should be instead to This change can only happen by revolution. Where did revolution come from? He made that argument several times, and every time I felt like there was a step or two missing, like the old Far Side cartoon where the scientist’s formula includes “here a miracle occurs” to get from one step to a disconnected result.

“Wage Labour and Capital” was my favorite section. I’d never thought of labor as a commodity—usually that word is used for grain, or to distinguish commodity chemicals from specialty chemicals—but it made a lot of sense once he pointed it out. I do think he ignored the presence of specialized labor, though, and only focused on a certain kind of worker. I suppose they were a bigger part of society then, and they were living through an appalling period in the development of industrialization, but even in Marx’s time, they weren’t the only people working for a living.

I also appreciated his comment that capital is accumulated labor. It’s perfectly clear once he points it out, but I’d never thought of it in those terms. He seemed bitter that workers are paid less than the value they create with their labor, but ignored the fact that they’re only able to create that level of value because of the capital investments that provide them tools and materials with which to be so productive. They were certainly oppressed, especially then, but he made it seem like they were the only generators of value.

After al the dense, economic verbiage, it was astonishing to read his bit of poetry on page 216, with the uplifted arms. That was an amazing image, with beautiful language. God star for Marx from the writing teacher!


“Capital” had some good points, but they were hard to see through the glaze that kept creeping over my eyes. I really don’t like economics. I’m hoping that everyone else focused on this one, so I can see how many points I found, and what the others were that flowed past my brain on a torrent of too many words. And saying that suggests that this is a good time to comment on Postone’s chapters, which were also a torrent of too many words. As near as I could tell—both times I tried to read this (ok, I left the pdf on the screen, so that may have contributed to my struggles)—it seemed like all he did was rearrange and describe Marx’s writings. I could never find where he was extending or uncovering or adding to anything Marx had said. I’m really looking forward to the class discussion for this.

“Crisis Theory” was interesting. Over-production is really just over-pricing, so if you lower the price, you have the right amount. It seemed like a convoluted way of explaining supply and demand, cast in terms of the oppressed proletariat who can’t afford to buy all they need. I thought of Henry Ford, paying his workers enough that they could afford to buy the cars they were making.

He had a lot of interesting thoughts about how money changes barter, making it less direct and tangible, and introducing new options for disrupting the circulations of capital. Money makes the social element of trade more abstract so we don’t see it in its real terms.

“Origin of Family…” seemed the least thought out of the selections we read. I didn’t see any proof of a matrilineal origin, and he didn’t explain the change to patriarchy very clearly, just saying “as wealth increased” (735) like that made the whole thing obvious. Over the course of the article, he showed that patriarchy arose as part of inheritance concerns, but he never showed why inheritance concerns became an issue.

His vision of communism transforming oppressive monogamy into free love, unshackled by concerns of inheritance, sounded like someone who’s never actually been married. I’m sure there are marriages based on inheritance issues, but that whole structure seems like medieval royalty machinations, not 19th century capitalist behavior. It was interesting to follow his thought to the idea that proletariat marriages were more likely to be about love because they’re not hampered by concerns for inheritance. Usually the proletariat are presented as helpless, hopeless brutes.

The other prediction that seemed unrealistic and starry-eyed was around the state. Since its only role is to protect the Haves from the Have-nots, once the laborers realize the present system isn’t inevitable, they’ll rise up and eliminate classes and with them the need for a state. That just doesn’t make sense in so many ways, even without thinking about how communism really played out.

All through this essay, I kept wondering if Marx had spent any time in the back of a micro bus painted with peace signs. I know it’s chronologically impossible, but the ideas, the lack of coherent connections, the free love and lack of authority—I just kept smelling patchouli.

And then, in a sudden jerk backwards, he channeled Hegel on page 759, to leave us with a vision of “the next higher plane of society to which experience, intelligence and knowledge are steadily tending.” After all the digs against German Idealism, that was a bewildering way to close this book.

So, I’ve actually read Marx now. He had some good points and interesting insights, as well a whole lot of unrealistic idealism. My biggest question is, How does this relate to the study of history? He was consistently economic, and frequently sociological, but only occasionally historical. Casting history in terms of economic dialectic and class warfare seems very limiting—an interesting fad to dabble in briefly, but whose primary contribution was just to wrench historians’ minds back to humanity, away from abstractions. Thank goodness we have seminar coming up to make all of this clearer!

entry.title: Marx & Engels Reread
entry.content:
You know, there was a time when I would have dreaded rereading Marx. That was before Hegel.
In all seriousness, I read Marx only once before, my freshman year of college in a 200 level philosophy class about the founders of Western Thought. We read Plato, Marx, Dewey, and Rousseau. And I’ll admit, I wasn’t enamored with Marx at the time, because I was a freshman, and all I really wanted to do was party and act like a complete idiot. It’s amazing how when you look back at when you were younger, sometimes you just want to smack yourself in the face.
Needless to say, I got very little out of that class, because I was barely there even when I was physically in the seat. So my vision of Marx and Marxist thought was a little basic, and after reading Hegel for last week, I was genuinely excited to reread him.

Here’s what I get out of Marx:

1. History has a system of governments, of which the final will be socialism. Capitalism, just like feudalism or previous socioeconomic forms, will fail, and the new society will be communism in its pure, non-Soviet sense, a classless, stateless, egalitarian society.

2. History is the story of class struggle.

3. Hegel had a great idea, just horrifically backwards; Feuerbach had a great way of using Hegel, though his conclusions were not necessarily correct. Flipping Hegel’s ideas upside down was the way Marx and Engels described as being the best way to use him. The physical world is what is real, and all of our conceptions are products of it, rather than the cause of it.

4. Historical materialism is basically the concept that all society, all institutions, have an economic framework, the real foundation that everything else is built on. Economics is the key to society and history.

5. Marx was brilliant, and his ideas, while not in vogue anymore, are an interesting way to look at the universe; but Engels is a darn better writer, and makes things much clearer than Marx does.

I enjoyed reading Marx much more this time; the passage of almost 5 years and a lot of growing up helps, as does having just read something infinitely more dense. The other reading, not from the primary source, was significantly less help. I did not find, this time at least, Marx to be all that difficult, or Marx’s ideas to be obfuscated in any way. The Postone reading actually made Marx less comprehensible in my mind.

It was good to reread Marx. I’m excited for Monday’s discussion.

entry.title: Postone
entry.content: Postone states at the beginning of this section that he intends to add something new to the historical study of Marx’s understanding of capitalism.  This addition would seem to be expounding upon Marx’s Capital as nausea.  I wasn’t sure if chapter seven was spent defending Marx or explaining his philosophy a little better.  His work in this chapter was very erudite, but it seemed more pedantic than insightful.  Yes, that last sentence was with tongue firmly in cheek.  The fog cleared in Chapter 8 as I latched onto his idea of productivity levels.  Having worked for several years in a factory, I have first-hand knowledge of how increased productivity leads to new levels of expectation, and how mind-numbing and monotonous the work truly is.  His description of abstract time, historical time and the movement of history took a while for me to wrap my head around, and I continue the endeavor even now.  He closed with what to me sounded like the idea that if we could lock onto a process of a social constitution in working we wouldn’t need capitalism.  Wouldn’t that be socialism?

entry.title: Capital, Vol. 1
entry.content:
“Segui il tuo corso, e lascia dir le genti”

This spoke to me.  It is Italian, I believe.  Someone correct me if I’m wrong, but Marx was going on his own when he wrote Capital, right?  As such, this line would make sense; “Follow your own course, no matter what people say.”  And follow it he did.  This was some heavy reading for me.  Mainly because I have no financial understanding at all, so the arguments about labor, time, commodities, and money left my head spinning.  From what I can gather, he’s saying that a capitalist only lives to make more money and monopolize everything in a worker’s life right down to when he sleeps and how he raises his children.  Now that is the ultimate micro-manager if ever I’ve seen one.  I understand the part about human labor creating value, but having no value itself – it only has potential to create value, and once labor has created that thing with value, labor has no value because it has been spent.  Chapter XIII is where I recognized the pointy-haired manager, whose only job is make sure everyone else does theirs.  Chapter XIV’s assembly line may have been where Ford got his notion , or Marx may have seen one operating, and I would have to agree that children would love school when it got them out of heavy labor.  Chapter XV, section 9 was curious and hopeful.  I still have yet to see the working-class take power anywhere that it was not controlled by a military leader of some kind.  It was good to see that there were those who would fight to protect children from being exploited by everyone, including their parents.  Marx does paint a grim picture of the world in control of capitalists; the few in control of the many, a surplus population ready to do the bidding of the owners of production.  There are times when Marx references scriptures, but then he wheels immediately to shift things in the opposite direction as if to say, “One is a utopia, the other reality.”  At the end, it is easy to cheer for the workers to revolt and expropriate the possessions of the few and give them to the many, especially those who have suffered under the capitalist labor system.

entry.title: Week 6-- Readings on Materialism
entry.content:
Our reading assignment this week centered on the Materialist philosophies of Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels.  I found this to be very accessible and entertaining reading, especially in comparison to Kant and Hegel.  Several passages were assigned from The Marx-Engels Reader, which is an excellent resource for understanding the ideas of these two, well, how to best describe them, philosophers, subversives, or revolutionaries? 
      In “Origins of the Family, Private Property, and the State,” I was reminded of the old maxim I’ve heard a million times: communism looks great on paper, but doesn’t work in real life.  Engels makes the same suggestion about the evolution in society from status to “free” contract.  In the family, which Engels portrays as the ‘cellular form of civilized society,’ (pg 739), the monogamous contract between man and wife is a pleasant fiction that is upheld by legal agreement that appears, at least on paper, to be of mutual benefit, although it is not. 
     Marx and Engels’ “The German Ideology” elaborates on his “materialist conception of history,” which is berates both the Old and Young-Hegelian movements for their “philosophic charlantry,” (pg 147).  For his part, Marx defends Engels and himself in materialist fashion by stating “the premises from which we begin are not arbitrary ones, but real premises from which abstraction can only be made in the imagination,” (pg 149).  “In direct contrast to German philosophy which descends from heaven to earth, here we ascend from earth to heaven,” (pg 154).  This serves as the launching off point for Marx’s materialist theory about the stages of ownership and historical development.
     In “Wage Labour and Capital,” Marx begins his preoccupation with economics that are necessary to prove his points about the development of labor and labor power in the context of a very turbulent point in history, exemplified in the revolutions of 1848.  Marx explains that Wage Labor is the social relationship between commodity producers guided by the character of the means of production.  Capital is the character of the bourgeois society’s means of production.   Marx’s conclusion is that this relationship enslaves the proletariat to capital, or subjects him to a John Henry vs. the machine scenario.  The solution: abolishing wage labour destroys capital! 
     Along this line, our reading of Postone’s Time, Labor and Social domination took a tediously pedantic look at this same economic theory of labor and capital.  Postone attempts to disect and explain “the Marxian dialectic of the forces and relations of production,” (pg263) in order to shed new light on Marx’s theories capital’s destruciton.  I found this work extremely difficult to read through without my eyes crossing.
     In “Crisis Theory,” Marx argues against criticisms that aim at explaining away economic crises in abstract terms instead of material issues such as supply and demand and the dialectic of exchange-value and use-value.  He also describes world trade crises as proof positive of the inherent contradictions in the bourgeois economy, and its natural attempt to right itself.  Marx explains that the general possibility of crisis is contained in the metamorphosis of commodity to money to commodity, or C-M-C, where the connection between purchase and sale erodes due to the fallability of the use of money as a means of payment.

Our reading assignment this week centered on the Materialist philosophies of Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels.  I found this to be very accessible and entertaining reading, especially in comparison to Kant and Hegel.  Several passages were assigned from The Marx-Engels Reader, which is an excellent resource for understanding the ideas of these two, well, how to best describe them, philosophers, subversives, or revolutionaries? 
      In “Origins of the Family, Private Property, and the State,” I was reminded of the old maxim I’ve heard a million times: communism looks great on paper, but doesn’t work in real life.  Engels makes the same suggestion about the evolution in society from status to “free” contract.  In the family, which Engels portrays as the ‘cellular form of civilized society,’ (pg 739), the monogamous contract between man and wife is a pleasant fiction that is upheld by legal agreement that appears, at least on paper, to be of mutual benefit, although it is not. 
     Marx and Engels’ “The German Ideology” elaborates on his “materialist conception of history,” which is berates both the Old and Young-Hegelian movements for their “philosophic charlantry,” (pg 147).  For his part, Marx defends Engels and himself in materialist fashion by stating “the premises from which we begin are not arbitrary ones, but real premises from which abstraction can only be made in the imagination,” (pg 149).  “In direct contrast to German philosophy which descends from heaven to earth, here we ascend from earth to heaven,” (pg 154).  This serves as the launching off point for Marx’s materialist theory about the stages of ownership and historical development.
     In “Wage Labour and Capital,” Marx begins his preoccupation with economics that are necessary to prove his points about the development of labor and labor power in the context of a very turbulent point in history, exemplified in the revolutions of 1848.  Marx explains that Wage Labor is the social relationship between commodity producers guided by the character of the means of production.  Capital is the character of the bourgeois society’s means of production.   Marx’s conclusion is that this relationship enslaves the proletariat to capital, or subjects him to a John Henry vs. the machine scenario.  The solution: abolishing wage labour destroys capital! 
     Along this line, our reading of Postone’s Time, Labor and Social domination took a tediously pedantic look at this same economic theory of labor and capital.  Postone attempts to disect and explain “the Marxian dialectic of the forces and relations of production,” (pg263) in order to shed new light on Marx’s theories capital’s destruciton.  I found this work extremely difficult to read through without my eyes crossing.
     In “Crisis Theory,” Marx argues against criticisms that aim at explaining away economic crises in abstract terms instead of material issues such as supply and demand and the dialectic of exchange-value and use-value.  He also describes world trade crises as proof positive of the inherent contradictions in the bourgeois economy, and its natural attempt to right itself.  Marx explains that the general possibility of crisis is contained in the metamorphosis of commodity to money to commodity, or C-M-C, where the connection between purchase and sale erodes due to the fallability of the use of money as a means of payment.

entry.title: Recession/Panic/Depression = Crisis
entry.content: Marx’s “Crisis Theory” questioned some of the leading economist of the time, Jean-Baptiste Say, David Ricardo, and James Mill.  He seems to laugh at them with the question of their logic behind the idea that there is no overproduction, or glut, of the market, it’s just that other items were under-produced that would make up for it. I had to read that twice to be sure. He calls their idea “fiction” (460).  And just to make his point clear, he spends the next dozen or so pages covering potential crises and what would actually create a crisis. “No crisis can exist unless sale and purchase are separated from one another and come into conflict…” (454)  Later, he defines money as a means of circulation and a means of payment.  In these exchanges, it would seem that Marx is countering the capitalist’s calming statements about economic crisis with statements that the people should be worried because they couldn’t even afford the shoes and shirts they are making if a failure of credit was to happen.  Hmmm.  How prophetic…  Maybe I’m completely off on all this.  What did you all read in this section?

entry.title: I work, therefor I'm not a capitalist, am I?
entry.content:
Marx puts forth some heady ideas in the section on ‘Wage Labour and Capital’.  I see in them a lot of current economic understanding.  The ideas of cost of production, economies of scale, reinvestment into a business, the division of labor and increasing output by mechanizing can all be found here.  So, what was Marx saying, and what does this add to the study of history?  What kernels of wisdom can we glean from this short essay?  I think Marx is laying down the idea of, what his time thought as modern, contemporary definitions of labor, capital, and money.  He was articulating what he saw as a struggle between those who possessed the means of production; proletariat, and those who controlled the means of production; capitalists.  At the time this was new and provocative, and made people ask questions.  I didn’t see any of the “greedy capitalist pig” idea that is later attributed to him.  He was expressing systematically a process whereby goods were produced by people who sold what they possessed - their time.  I really like the way he defined labor as a commodity that could be bought and sold for wages…
 more later…

entry.title: Thoughts on German Idealism & History
entry.content:
When I read Ranke, Kant and Hegel I was dumb struck on several different fronts.  In truth it was Kant and Hegel who made me struggle as Ranke I simply agreed with, for his promotion of Narrative style writing with emphasis on empirical data, i.e. primary documents won the Historiographical Debate in the end.

I take issue with Kant’s underlining theme that history has a finite end to its evolution.  He referred to  it as the “natural course” which in my view is an argument for Destiny.  History in his eyes always has a “logical end” which is in direct conflict of my understanding of history as a “Foreign Country.” A conclusion that I reached with several Historiographical including my current course that when viewing history it should be a distant thing taken into account within its historical context.

The humanist in me enjoys Kant’s belief that states which spend all of their commonwealth on war greatly hold back the “full development of human nature,” which is the ultimate goal, to unlock the betters of human nature with a society as opposed to allowing the worst of human nature which according to him lie in the individual.

Hegel was more detailed in defining history than Kant’s vague Destiny argument.  From my understanding of Hegel, there are 3 kinds of history, Original, Reflexive, and Philosophical.  Original history, in his view, is the history of Thucydides and Herodotus which take on a Political tone. Reflexive histories get divided into three sub-categories; Universal history(which concerns itself with the history of “a people or a country, or of the world” as a whole), Pragmatical history (“reanimating the past to bear upon the present conditions of things”), and Critical history(the history of history, meant to criticize historical works so as to improve them). The final form of history was the most obscure, and I sincerely did not understand it, Philosophical history which Hegel shorted as “thoughtful consideration of it[history].”

entry.title: Reflections on Kant's 'Idea for a Universal History From a Cosmopolitan Point of View,' Hegel's 'The Philosophy of History' and Ranke's 'The Secret of World History'
entry.content:
These writings, which span roughly a century, have much to say regarding the German Idealism shared by their respective authors.

As was typical of that movement, these writers fixated on the idea of a universal manifestation of their particular discipline. Hence their concept of “universal history,” defined by Ranke as “encompass(ing) the events of all nations and periods, with this limitation: that they be possible subjects for scholarly debate.”

Philosophy and – as the movement’s name suggests – idealism are to be found in all these works. The ways in which they diverge are a matter of degree.

The most heavily philosophical – and thus least accessible – of the three works is Hegel’s. Still, mixed in amid all the obtuseness, we find nuggets such as this: “Nations are what their deeds are.” Intriguing, too, is his expounding on the concept of freedom.

The most passionate – ergo, most idealistic – seems to be Ranke. Within his works is found the fascinating leitmotif of unattainable perfection that he nevertheless is compelled to seek. And yet fairly palpable is the joy he seems to have derived from his journey.

Finally, Kant’s work is the most succinct on both counts. Yet he still offers much in the way of intriguing insights as regards world history. However, he looks not only at the past; in a passage more concretely prescient than anything put forth by Nostradamus, Kant offers the “fantastical” idea of a “league of nations” in which “even the smallest state could expect security and justice … from a united power acting according to decisions reached under the laws of their united will.”

Ultimately, the writings noted above do much to distill the essence of those German thinkers’ major contributions to the study of history.

entry.title: Universal History
entry.content:
This is a brief synopsis of three multifaceted and prodigiously expressed beliefs on Universal History by three historians: Immanuel Kant, Leopold von Ranke, and Georg Hegel. All three ascribe to the notion that human beings can advance and are in fact in a perpetual state of improvement. They see history as following a natural course, the study of which must balance the particulars with an understanding of the general trend leading on toward perfection. They each seem to combine scientific ideas with a deep spirituality, whether by asserting that Reason can be used to understand universal truths and divine plans, that evolution does point toward an ultimate goal, and/or that humanity is perfectible with careful study and an inspired capacity for change. The task of discovering these truths is a very difficult one, but one that must be attempted, and studied with great care.

Despite their similarities, the progression of mankind is understood in slightly different ways by each of them, and their views of Universal History are shaded accordingly. Kant writes that human advancement comes from “social unsociability.” It is a competitive drive that lifts humans above other animals, as men both want and detest the society of their fellows. Von Ranke, the continual proponent of archival research, argues that the facts take preeminence in all historical works, with interpretation second, since generations and new documents can sometimes disprove interpretation, but strict reconstruction of how things were will withstand time. I picked the heading of my blog simply in jest, as a play on words of an all-too-frequently used phrase, but von Ranke would maintain that this is, in fact, what we do and our highest obligation. And it is from this careful attention to things as they really were that we have the best chance at correctly identifying “the event itself in its human intelligibility, its unity, its diversity…we deal with humanity as it is, explicable or inexplicable; the life of the individual, of generations, or nations; and, at times, with the hand of God above them.”
Hegel evaluates that role of nature in human evolution. This idea clearly has a root in the earlier writings of Kant, who professed that human beings, like Nature, follow universal laws and evolve. However, Hegel argues that while Nature exists in cycles, the Spirit can be improved toward perfection, and in this humans derive their ability to progress and create(54).

I would argue that these men, despite some of their own claims to the contrary, are much more similar than they are different. The focal point of their conjectures(that humankind is progressing toward perfection in accordance with a divine plan and that the stages of this progression can and should be identified) is accepted by all three, but this is the point of reasoning that I would think many scholars would choose to question today. I found these studies to be very interesting, as both the obligation and limitations of academic history seemed to be laid out in terms of spirituality, which to me, seemed somewhat contradictory to these same scholar’s commitment to scientific precision and detachment. Still, I enjoyed these men’s contribution to a very serious question: can mankind actually improve?
