entry.title: 9/19/10 German Idealism
entry.content:
I must confess that Kant’s take on history seems, to me, to be rather teleological, with its idea to it is possible “to have a history with a definite natural plan for creatures who have no plan of their own” (Introduction) and that man has the ability to continually progress to something better, despite his many attempts to no do so. Of course, this teleological feel has strong elements of the Enlightenment in it. I do find it interesting that Kant doesn’t see that his historical Idea contradicts the efforts of empirical historians; as I understand his theses, it wouldn’t necessarily do so, but it would alter the perception of history and the interpretation of events, such that one would end up producing the kind of history that states that, for example, the Merovingians, the Carolingians, medieval France, etc. were all purposeful steps in the creation of modern France.

The beginning of Hegel’s work is certainly much more comprehensible than the latter parts, in which he delves into the more philosophical ideas of Freedom, Spirit, and Reason—all capitalized. Hegel divides the study of history into three broad categories: original history, reflective history, and philosophical history. While reading the first part of his introduction, I was rather struck by the modernity of his views that sometimes came through—certainly not everything he wrote, but part of it. The critical reflective history, which Hegel seems to disparage, appears to be the type of history that Ranke would have favored with its “criticism of historical narratives and an investigation of their truth and credibility” (7). I found the rest of Hegel rather difficult to wade through, and I am an interested to hear everyone else’s opinion on his work. I did find Hegel’s definition of history interesting, that it is the “development of “Spirit in Time,” (72), again a statement that has a definite Enlightenment feel to it.

I found the excerpts from Ranke to be the most interesting of the three. I’m very glad that we read Grafton’s history of the footnote before reading some of Ranke’s specific text, as it gave me an idea of some key points to look for and, more importantly, made me aware of his place in historiography (otherwise, I would have wondered why we were reading something from this person whom I had never encountered). Most striking was Ranke’s definite privileging of eyewitness accounts, which came through in a variety of ways, whether explicitly stated in his works or not. His view on this certainly seems to have filtered down to today, as James Humphreys mentioned in his blog post.

As a medievalist, many of the secondary works that I read contain numerous statements that qualify the works of primary sources—something along the lines of “It must be remembered that X lived and wrote 70 years after King Y died.” Or its corollary “Z’s writings are especially valuable, as he was a contemporary of Pope W.” Thus, I too have been trained to feel that eyewitness, or at least contemporary, accounts are of the utmost importance. This concentration on first-hand narratives does put an interesting spotlight on last week’s reading, in which we found the denigration of Spanish conquistador accounts of the New World, even though they were the first Europeans to actually visit the American continents and have contact with the Amerindian civilizations. One wonders what Ranke would have thought of their accounts.

entry.title: And I Kant Stand Him...
entry.content:
Oh, German Idealism and its major proponents. I am afraid of Kant and Hegel, of German Idealism in general. Until doing these readings, I had very little knowledge of who they were or what they stood for, or even how they fit into historical thought, but I knew that Hegel was nigh-incomprehensible, and Kant was the founding father, and that was enough.
It’s sad that you’re taught to fear Hegel before even reading him.

Now that we’ve actually read some of Kant’s work, I have a much better sense of why he is important, even if I have some questions. He clearly believes, in these theses, in some sort of destiny, racial if not individual— Kant’s second thesis, the idea that humanity as a whole is going in one, unstoppable, progressively more rational direction regardless of individual actions seems a bit… well, optimistic, really. The idea that humanity in any way can head towards rationality seems, in the modern world, to still be a pipe dream. Technology may improve, but people in general are still as stupid, paranoid, prone to violence, and superstitious as ever. The fact that he doesn’t think individuals head towards rationality proves its idealism, not lunacy, to support his theories, but I think individuals do have the power to change the course of human history in their own way. I wonder what he would think of that.

Kant’s fourth thesis, though, made me feel a lot better, and relax while reading this. OK, there is the ideal vision that humanity as a whole is improving, but humanity improve via antagonism—the old argument of progress through war in philosophical form. The idea of creating a perfect civic state, which he argues for, doesn’t seem to work with this idea, but he admits it to be the greatest problem and goal in human history. This, he believes, is the driving force in human history—the irrevocable progress towards a single civic society where all men live under the rule of law.

The general idea of German Idealism, that the way we perceive the world around us reflects us, rather than the universe, makes a lot of sense to me. Maybe I’ve watched the Matrix too many times, but reality is basically what we perceive, regardless of whatever may be lurking behind. If a tree falls in the forest, and no one is around, does it make a sound? The real question, in my opinion, is does anyone care? And no, for the record—we don’t perceive it, it didn’t happen. I’ve got Kant et al.’s back on this one.

Hegel’s piece opened with his discussion of the three kinds of history: Original, Reflective, and Philosophical. I’m a sucker for Original History. Herodotus, Thucydides, most of the good stuff—deeds and events and states of society? Narrative of the universe around them and their experiences? My favorite kind of sources. I love primary documents, or secondary documents close enough to the source to still be mostly eyewitness. Reflective history is history that transcends a specific time period—a universal history, like Livy, or a pragmatic history, dealing with the present, or a critical history, historiography. Not the best, nor my favorite, though certainly useful in all three forms. And philosophical history… well… a thoughtful consideration of history, as Hegel says, is a good thing, but after last week’s book, I don’t really like this philosophical history, or the philosophical traveler, or any of that nonsense.

Not nonsense. That’s unfair. The book How to Write the History of the New World was just so convincing that I find myself prejudiced against 18th century Enlightenment historians and their theories, and against the concept of philosophical history and travelers. I don’t believe that there are universal laws that can be applied to all of history, or even to the entire nature of the universe. Chance, chaos, whatever you call it, have a very real part in events—history is not predetermined, history is a mutable object. Maybe it is my lack in the belief of predestination that makes me argue against any kind of knowable history, but I don’t not believe in the inevitability of anything.

This relates back to his arguments about Reason in History, in that sometimes things happen by chance, or by accident. Causality can be established, but there does not have to be logic behind it. There is no “ultimate destiny” of the world except for entropy, and the inevitable end of all life makes for either a very poor or a stunningly brilliant guiding factor behind human history. I’m not sure which it is yet.

Now, Hegel’s piece is really interesting, if so dense as to be actually painful to read. The discussion of Sprit, and how it relates to culture and a nation, was hard for me to understand—I wanted Sparknotes to explain to me what the heck he was talking about. I still don’t claim to understand it, but the link to religion, and his attempts to reconcile human history with the divine… well, that did make a lot of sense. Evil and God. History is filled with examples of evil, in all forms, from the great to the small, and reconciling the existence of it with an all-mighty, all-good God is one I am not able to even attempt.

The idea that history is an expression of freedom struck me as another example of the slightly naïve nature of Hegel and Kant. The spirit expresses its freedom through history? History seems more an expression of repression to me. Man, I’m feeling like a major pessimist, but really. Slavery, oppression, autocracy, this is the unifying message of human history. Theoretically free societies pop up like a brief dream, and are crushed under the weight of reality. Athens lasted what, 500 years?, before it was brought back under a monarchy. And it was the longest lasting democracy so far. I like to hope we’ll break the trend, but man. Freedom as the unifying factor in history. Wow. And yes, I know he then says that Freedom as an Idea is natural, and doesn’t exist in practice, but I don’t think even in nature, outside of the human condition, there is a natural freedom waiting to burst through. Queen bees, alpha males, pack leaders, etc., nature has a hierarchy, and there is a low, dominated end of the totem pole.

Hegel is pretty much what I thought he’d be. Really important, but I’ll read secondary sources about him next time.

Ranke, after Kant and Hegel, was a breath of fresh air. I already know a little bit about him from Grafton’s book, and while he’s a 19th century German author, his ideas about modern source methodology are important, and his writing style was quite a bit easier to grasp. I don’t think I’m going to talk much about Ranke, maybe in class, but it’d be interesting to read more of his works.

entry.title: Ranke's historical truisms
entry.content:
Either my parents read Ranke to me as a child or my teachers in grade school preached him, but I’ve always felt that the proper way to present history was through the facts and how things really were.  In reading Ranke’s many introductions and snippets, one can learn of his method wherein he felt that history was a science requiring inordinate amounts of source knowledge.  When I read the part about the “reader is animated by feelings of pleasure and hope, on examining the catalogues,” (61) I thought to myself that he was like a kid in a candy store walking into the archives of the cities.  I also deduced that he was either rich himself, had rich benefactors, or a great expense account to be able to travel to these places and live there while researching in the archives.
Ranke makes several important observations and statements; like saying don’t pity people who like to read old papers because these are the remnants of past ages(70), or that knowledge is inconceivable without knowing the events of past ages(113), or that historical works of great reputation and usefulness become obsolete. (258)  Even though he wanted his work to be his legacy, he apparently knew that eventually it would be eclipsed by better work.  Doesn’t that sound a bit like Kant, whom he disliked?

entry.title: German Idealism…
entry.content:
Immanuel Kant proposes that history is not simply the recorded events of men as they struggle against each other and against nature for survival.  Rather, human history has a meaning, a divine purpose, as it outlines the development of mankind along a path ordained by God.  Kant suggests that God—Nature—has fore-ordained man to develop a harmonious global civilization wherein the individual is freed of barbarousness and vanity.  In Kant’s universal future history, rationality and morality have triumphed over self-interested individualism. 

This development is structured along man’s dual nature of building and destroying.  Man craves cohabitation and community so he develops societies wherein he may live with others, yet his innate individualism causes him to break with society the instant it is established.  According to Kant, this contradiction is divine, and it is the driving mechanism behind history—history is driven by mankind’s inner conflict.  Only over time does man learn to be rational and moral, and only then to societies thrive and become civilized.  Once established, nations develop similarly, devolving into warfare and strife until they can learn to peacefully coexist under a larger, international governing body.  The end of history will be found in the globalization of freedom and liberty, for only then can man truly understand God and assume his true (and possibly existential) consciousness. 

But what does this say about history as a profession.  For the purposes of the modern historian, Kant suggests that history is merely the story of human conflict and the development of a rational morality rooted in the results of conflict.  To be sure, there is a larger meta-history of divine guidance and progress, but Kant simply cannot separate philosophy from history.  As such, his system is innately flawed as he looks for only what he seeks to find.  To a certain extent, all historians to this; but Kant’s philosophically driven history is very narrow in its perspective and may marginalize or obscure the actual causes and meanings of events. 

After reading Kant’s theory of a universal cosmopolitan history, I am curious where we may place a history written according to such parameters within the three constructs of history established by Hegel?  To be sure, Kant’s construct does not fall into the category of original history.  Within Kant’s construct one could arguably find elements of universal and pragmatic reflective history, but there may also be trends towards the larger philosophical history.  Where does Kant’s interpretation of history fit within Hegel’s constructs—into which category does Kant fall?  Do Kant’s and Hegel’s individual theories mesh with each other on a larger scale?

entry.title: German Idealism
entry.content:
Ok, the first thing I have got to say is, Thank goodness these papers were easier to follow than the book from last week. I understood what they had to say, and could discern an outline or structure to their thoughts. Very refreshing and reassuring.

Hegel began by looking briefly at various kinds or styles of writing history—original, universal, pragmatic, critical, and transitions—before introducing philosophical, where he then focused his attention.

The foundation for his philosophical history is basically neo-Platonic. Universal Reason is both the guide and the substance of the Universe. This Universal Reason is progressing toward an Ultimate Goal by way of successive waves of human events and eras. Seen this way, from a perspective of Universal Progress, particular events that would seem tragic can be interpreted as brief and necessary steps toward an Ultimate Good. Humans contribute to this progress inadvertently as they pursue what they think are their individual goals. Reason uses these human acts to accomplish the Ultimate Goal.

On page 36, his said that Philosophy is the process of figuring out what this Ultimate Goal is, so we can correctly interpret the events of history and thereby see—prove—that “the real world is as it ought to be” (36). Seeing this Real perspective makes the ordinary, “incoherent” events fall into a Reason-guided cycle of progress, or Universal History. And then he said that the State—law, morality, government—is the only arena in which this progress is made; it is “the Divine Idea as it exists on Earth” (39). Because the State provides structure and constrains impulses, only it provides the setting for this Universal Progress.

On page 52, he mentioned that people are as limited by their time as by their location, but he didn’t indicate that this applied to him. I refuse to give into the temptation to feel superior here, because he’s right. And it applies to us just as much as to him, except we theoretically understand it, without being able to identify our limitations any more than he could his.

By page 54, he’s ready to use all these ideas to look at the Course of the World’s History, though still at a theoretical and anonymous level. He said that though growth and development in Nature proceed uneventfully, in the Spiritual realm they’re filled with conflict because there’s both the lure of the currently obvious goal and the inevitability of the Ultimate Goal. Sometimes the current goal seems thwarted, but that’s an error of perspective—everything that happens leads closer to that Ultimate Goal. Upheavals throughout history have been the transitions between a settled and achieved Spirit of One Age to the onset of the Spirit of the Next Age. The upheaval is good, because States need a new goal to work toward in order to avoid becoming listless and flaccid, or being overrun by the private goals of individuals.

Throughout this section, I watched him peel away huge areas of history that must be disregarded for one reason or another—India focusing on distinctions instead of unity, China focusing on individual happiness instead of State good. But even this didn’t quite prepare me for the outrageous prejudice in the Geographic section. In order to qualify as part of his Universal History, you need the proper climate, suitable natural resources, the correct religion, sufficient group identity, an interactive geographic position, and so on. Basically, you need to be Protestant Europe. His thesis works great as long as you ignore everything that doesn’t fit.

Hegel’s thesis is indeed Idealistic, and more than slightly self-congratulatory, but it does sort of hang together as long as you wrap your mind around his very provincial worldview. I can see how people would have loved to see Progress in terms that excused or explained horrible events. But it seems an awful lot like children’s Christianity, rephrased with philosophical vocabulary: Don’t worry, God has it under control, everything happens for a reason, it’s His will, and so on. I don’t see, though, how it was supposed to help historians to organize and understand large bunches of apparently disparate data, other than by ignoring most of it.

Kant is obviously on the same page, but in a delightfully brief version. He also focused on large groups over individuals, assumed a goal that creation is moving toward, put human actions in service to this Universal Goal, and said that the State—or society—is the only arena for progress because social restraints provide freedom.

He does focus on individuals more than Hegel did, though, especially in thesis four. There, he said that humans are drawn into social groups, but within those groups we still seek our individual will, so conflict is inevitable. On a smaller scale than Hegel, he reiterates that conflict and striving are better for progress than is ease and concord.

His other point of difference is that he identifies this Ultimate Goal as a single coordinated league of all Nations. When everyone is constrained by the same set of expectations, all our competitive nature will go toward human development, instead of toward competition and destruction. All of the wars and chaos now are necessary to guide us toward this universal State that will be the Goal of history’s efforts.

Again, Kant is very idealistic. He specifically pointed out at the end that philosophers offer this perspective to augment the empiricism of historians, not to replace it, which I found to be more realistic than saying it’s a good way to actually write history. There are a lot of people who do see life this way, though they use different terms to discuss it. Understanding that this worldview may be involved makes it easier to infer motivations for behaviors we run across in research.

I read von Ranke first, so I saw him distancing himself before I knew what he was distancing himself from. Now when I look at his insistence on facts and proof and accuracy, I see why he was so adamant. He focuses on archives because he wants to know what happened, not how events can be interpreted into a shape that fits this theory of Universal Progress. And he believes people drive history in a much more intentional way than Hegel and Kant describe it.

He stressed over and over that different times and places must be evaluated for themselves, based on their own events and character. Eventually, on page 250, he summed up the value of considering a universal scope of history, but he still insisted that we use particular events, and let them dictate the shape of this meta-story, not the other way around.

Despite being clearly oriented differently from the others, he does use phrases like “peoples have developed in unison and along similar lines” (57), “the development of the unity and the progress of the events” (58), “private collections…[are]…not to be compared with the riches of the state archives” (62-63), “a portion of the history of the world, and of the general progress of mankind” (66), “truth can be but one” (72) and so on. I see how people could think he was part of the Idealists. But in the section from page 101 on, he insists on particulars and eyewitnesses, and says that pieces of history fit into a Universal History on their own terms, not within the constraints of a preconceived theory of Progress. He did have a new and important contribution to make, and I’m glad he insisted on being heard.

entry.title: Hegel on the philosophy of history
entry.content:
Hegel’s types of history – original, reflective, philosophical – make sense when one looks at the emerging discipline of history in the European intellectual world.  It actually does what the people and governments wanted from history of the time; to know where they came from, to relate it to their time, and then to ponder the why of things, and where civilization was going.  In the first part Hegel does well explaining the basis for history with Herodotus and Thucydides, and what defines original history.  Breaking down reflective into universal, pragmatical, critical, and fragmentary allows for easier classification of many manuscripts during his day.  I especially liked that he noted the debate about how history ought to be written was frustrating; it appears this question has been around a while. (4)  And he makes a note that writers were not distinguishing their time from the time about which they wrote. (5) His whole Spirit/Reason/Providence section was confusing and daunting. I look forward to hearing comments on that both here and in class.
When I got to the ‘Geographical Basis of History’ part it was plain that Hegel was a man of his times, and very Eurocentric.  It was like he was channeling Buffon claiming the Americas were totally inferior, and as such their history was of no import.  Then, continent by continent he checks them off as having no bearing on “true” world history, which can only come from the Mediterranean area; and Germany of course with Julius Caesar’s crossing of the Alps.  For all his comments about blacks and slavery being a “natural condition,” I like that he comes back to say, “Slavery is in and for itself injustice, for the essence of humanity if Freedom.”  (99) This is just a few observations of mine.  The quick outline I did for this took a page and a half.  What struck the rest of you as odd?  Was anything eye-opening? I found a lot of his work still relevant for today, just not the we’re better than everyone else part.

entry.title: Kant's world view...
entry.content:
Here is my take on Kant’s “Universal History from a Cosmopolitan Point of View.” (1784). Immanuel Kant was a deep thinker, but still a man of his time.  This reading was from the period just before the French Revolution, and after the American War of Independence.  So, yes it would seem as if the world was in chaos, with different groups opposing each other looking to assert their collective will.  His introduction seems to be an attempt at soothing anxious Europeans in saying that the destructiveness will work out in the end for the betterment of man.  His first thesis seems to sum up the idea of the Enlightenment – in which humans are progressing to a natural end through their own ability to reason; with the understanding that this ‘natural’ end is far better than the current state of human affairs.  His second thesis would appear to answer why there are peasants and nobility, ignorant, slow, normal, smart, and gifted individuals by saying that the human race itself advances, but not all individuals move at the same pace. (Good statement of the obvious) Thesis three appears to set the stage for man taking credit for the bettering of life through his own abilities, as if to say it was done without divine intervention.  Thesis four comes off to me as a justification for taking Amerindian lands.  Thesis five, six, and even seven are the framework to create this ‘just constitution’ Kant wants.  Thesis eight and nine are the justification for the need of universal constitution between countries.
In all this Kant appears to head toward a humanist idea of the world.  A world in which we humans make it on our own, and without any help from above.  However, he circles back toward ‘Providence’ at least to link the deist idea to the Enlightenment where God, or Providence, watches with approval what the reasoning men have created.
What else can be learned from this excerpt from Kant’s work?

entry.title: Raction to Canizares-Esguerra's How to Write the History of the New World
entry.content:
For starters, I will be entirely honest and admit that there were portions of this book that were, to say the least, a struggle.  That does not mean, however, that I think that Canizares-Esguerra is a bad writer. In fact, he is a very good writer: clear, concise, direct.  I think that it is the nature of the source material and the subject that make it so dry at times.

Having said that, there are some very good parts to this book.  The story of Boturini.  shows the various origins of modern historiography: ideological battles, patriotism, egos, and– what else?–sources.  It seems interesting that people could recognize that there was a new movement going on in history… and yet still want an older, more moralizing purpose behind it. It seems laughable to us that people would take the writing of a history this personally, but also allows us to see that history HAD a purpose and was a tool which they could use to their advantage. But what is more important and impressive to me are the countless people who, what ever their motive, began to question the use of sources (especially, in this case, native) and the scholarship that was done on sources which was in a real way very new.

One particularly interesting facet of Canizares-Esguerra’s writing I particularly appreciate is the human element that manages to show through. The motives he ascribes to not only those trying to sort out this history (and, often implicitly, those of their detractors) are interesting in that the are, as we experience today, a combination of personal, professional, and often political.  Where he is most effective, though, is in his word choices. When attempting to define “nations”  he defines them not as “fraternities of citizens” but “fraternities of Virtuous citizens” (emphasis mine; pg. 204). The reason for this word choice, I think, it to show not only what the definition of a nation is (which many in his intended audience would be familiar with anyway) but how a patriotic observer might want their people shown. That he does this in one word where other might have taken more is a credit to the subtlety in his writing.

entry.title: Thoughts on "How to Write the History of the New World"
entry.content:
At the end of his introduction and thorough outline of his book, Jorge Canizares-Esguerra  managed to get my attention blatantly declaring war on what he calls North Atlantic-centric historiography.  He calls the understanding  of the what the West is as “amusingly Pompous.”    He openly challenges what is expected of him as a specialist of Latin American history by saying “I have learned that the public expects from historians of the region cautionary tales of revolutionary violence and, if socially conscious, stories of cunning peasants resisting treacherous oligarchs.  I am a storyteller of a different kind, who believes that there ought to be other tales for the public to consume.”  With this kind of fire in his writing I hoped for the rest of the book to channel rage constructed in such a way as to amuse me and keep me begging for more.  I was mistaken.  This book was a sincerely difficult read, but that is not to say I did not learn from it!

I like his concept of the philosophical traveler, a scholar who is “aware of the inadequacies of human perception and hence doubted the bare testimony of the senses,” and their “philosophical histories of the land and peoples of the America in which evidence from linguistics, natural history, ethnology, and geology took precedence.”

I also found very interesting the struggle that Spanish historians had in the 18th century attempting to patriotically defend their nation from historiographical attacks coming from Northern Europe.  If the Spanish historians stuck to what was “cutting edge” or I should really say “fashionable” readings of sources and writing of history then Spain would look like the “Bad guy” in history or the Ignorant in their 18th century present.

Overall, I enjoyed his attack on misconceptions and the anti-Spanish bias that seemed to plague a good deal of historiographical literature, while at the same time balancing the reading of Spanish sources with a critical eye.

entry.title: Reflections on 'How to Write the History of the New World'
entry.content:
Somebody (maybe or maybe not Winston Churchill) once said, “History is written by the victors.”


For some four centuries following Columbus’ 1492 voyage, Spain unquestionably was among the biggest winners in the realm of New World colonization.

And yet, as Jorge Canizares-Esguerra’s book seems to illustrate, even among Spaniards, there was in those years no clear consensus regarding the histories of the conquered regions, or the conduct of their “countrymen” as they did their conquering.

I say “seems” for two reasons.

First of all, this is a very dense work. Canizares-Esguerra not only elaborates at length on his main points, he also has a habit of repeating them, making his writing that much thicker.

But this book also has challenged me in a second, and more significant, way. It underscores the ways we often cast our own inherent biases as the “gold standard” by which other outlooks are to be judged. Unquestioningly attuned to our accepted views of history, we have a knee-jerk tendency to dismiss alternative views, even when, objectively viewed, they are no more and/or no less “fantastic” than our own.

So as I read Canizares-Esguerra’s words, I became conscious of the fact that my initial reactions thereto were to some extent shaped and colored by that which I’ve long thought I know to be true. Conversely, I get the sense that those words are in some ways a manifestation of what the author thinks or wishes to be true.

Does that make sense? No? Well, I’m not sure it does to me, either. This is heady stuff.

entry.title: 9/12 Canizares-Esguerra
entry.content:
Canizares-Esguerra, Jorge. How to Write the History of the New World.

In his heavily researched book, Canizares-Esguerra (CE) explores the ways in which Spanish and New World historiography of the New World changed in response to politics, the development of history, and the growing idea of nationalism. Throughout the course of the book, he discusses the debate concerning alphabetical vs. non-alphabetical texts and their mertis, the effects of patriotism on Spanish historiography in response to criticism from the rest of Europe about Spain and Spanish historians, effective elitism as historians chose to downplay common accounts of the conquest and the New World in favor of Amerindian aristocrats, and the distrust of foreign and “armchair philosopher” accounts of the New World.

Although my head was certainly spinning from the names of so many different 17th- and 18th-century historians, and I sometimes got irritated at CE for going on rather long tangents to explain one point, the book overall gave me some new perspectives on how we write history: the privileging of certain types of sources, the effects of politics on history, and the ways in which we decide the validity of accounts. Certainly, the practice of researching and writing history has changed since the time period covered in CE’s, but these considerations are still valid.

In particular, I found the preference for aristocratic Amerindian sources interesting. As a medievalist, the sources I have encountered, and am likely to see in the future, are the products of the elite; they’re all we have, no matter how much we might like to know about every non-aristocrat in Europe. Thus, although I understand the rationale of the time (members of the elite writing histories are perhaps rather likely to prefer accounts from other members of the ruling classes), I find it interesting, and disheartening from an informational standpoint, that the views, histories, and myths of so many common Amerindians were ignored because they were viewed as being untrustworthy—especially in a time/place when so many other sources, such as the non-alphabetical ones, were also viewed as inaccurate.

My biggest complaint with the book is that CE seems to have forgotten about Peru and the Inca civilization partway through. I’m not very familiar with the history of the Spanish colonies, or certainly of the historiography associated with them, so it’s possible that the histories of the Inca entered a standstill/lack-of-debate period. If so, however, I rather wish that CE had directly addressed that, rather than choosing to spend the remainder of the book exclusively in Central America.

entry.title: hist510
entry.content:
I found Jorge Canizares-Esguerra’s book to be an interesting tale of the debates that have taken place over Spanish American historiography. Historians today often operate under a shared set of assumptions of what constitutes proper historical evidence and how it should be used. This is not to say that every historian approaches their craft in the same manner; rather, there is an accepted methodology among  historians that has only recently emerged into academia. Recently in this context refers to the 1800s, when professional history first made its mark as a legitimate field of scholarly study. As Esguerra’s book reveals, however, prior to this development there existed no general consensus as to the “best” method of historical study, particularly in reference to what sources should be used.

The primary focus of Esguerra’s book falls on the discourses that arose surrounding the evidentiary aspect of writing a history of the Spanish American colonies from the sixteenth to eighteenth centuries. I was impressed at the amount of information Esguerra was able to incorporate into his book without losing his central focus. I found his decision to concentrate on the mutual influence of Europe and the New World to be particularly interesting. As one would expect, European developments inevitably impacted how scholars approached native sources to write a history of the colonies. More surprising, however, are the ways in which colonial intellectual trends exerted their own influence. Especially towards the late eighteenth century Spanish American scholars began to promote a more aggressively patriotic history of the New World that did not depend on European intellectual thought, and in fact directly countered European assumptions on the value of native sources. Much of the debate that raged over native sources centered around this very issue of reliability.

For Esguerra, the most important differences between indigenous source types was alphabetical or non-alphabetical. He does an excellent job of drawing out the positions held by those who advocated a general acceptance of non literary sources as opposed to those who believed that only written works could provide a reliable foundation for writing the New World’s history. The polemic between these two sides took a quite convoluted path as trends in historical thought shifted over the centuries. Esguerra relates not only who adhered to which opinion, but he also explains the rational behind each position and examines how individual contributions affected later discourse on the reliability of indigenous sources.

One of the most useful contributions of Esguerra’s book is its synthetic nature. As one can tell from the bibliography, there is certainly no dearth of material on the subject. There was, however, a lack of coherence and consolidation. Esguerra’s book does an excellent job of bringing together an intimidating amount of scattered research into a single manageable volume. His study does not end with a universal authoritarian conclusion purporting to have finally clarified the history of New World historiography. Instead, he is satisfied with the sporadically progressive nature of the New World’s history that emerged throughout his three hundred and fifty pages of research. I appreciated Esguerra’s decision to refrain from attempting to impose a more uniform and linear history than that which his research revealed. It made the book far more interesting and, in my opinion at least, lent his conclusions an added sense of credibility.

Overall, the book was an interesting read that illuminated a great deal on New World historiography as well as general intellectual trends in Europe from the sixteenth to eighteenth centuries. His work made me question source usage in history today, something I had not given much consideration to prior to reading this book. It certainly draws attention to the question of why historians choose to use the sources that they do and what underlying cultural values are determining which sources are ascribed value. The very nature of historical writing is dependent upon what evidence is used to construct a scholarly work, and I appreciate Esguerra’s book providing at least a little information on of the most important aspects of history.

entry.title: On How to Write the History of the New World
entry.content:
How to Write the History of the New World, by Jorge Canizares-Esguerra is a history of the European historiographic tradition of depicting the New World.  In particular, Canizares-Esguerra deals with sixteenth through nineteenth century eurocentricism and how it affected historical works about the Aztecs, Incas, Mexica and others.  I found this to be a very interesting book because it does an excellent job of illustrating the dangers involved with dealing with subjects that are far removed from the historian by both time and geography.  The author reflects on the major conjectural faux pas of notable historians of the aforementioned centuries and their sometimes comical depictions of the peoples of the Americas. 

Evidently, at least where the Americas were concerned, the academic hubris abounded through different historiographical eras and schools of thought from Renaissance humanism and the Enlightenment to romanticism.  This is evident in many historians’ refusal to believe eyewitness accounts of Spaniards because they were thought, as a people, to be deceitful by nature.  Also, historians’ depictions of the New World always seemed to have an alternate agenda serving some political purpose or to prove an alternate point, such as Locke’s Essay Concerning Human Understanding (1690).  Possibly the most intriguing thing about this book is that it makes me wonder if we ever got historiography right?  I mean, how do you write objectively when it’s impossible to be objective?  We say that good historians simply have to work around that dilemma, but the men in this book also thought they were employing the best means of getting at the truth, often missing the mark completely.  I don’t know about us, but as for them, I think Canizares-Esguerra sums it up nicely on page 103 when he stated that “…two impediments had to be overcome to create the science of history, namely, la boria delle nazioni  and la boria de’ dotti: the conceit of nations and the conceit of the learned.”

entry.title: Questions Unanswered
entry.content:
Jorge Canizares-Esguerra, How to Write the History of the New World

In his voluminously footnoted tome, Canizares-Esguerra sets out demonstrate that a critical, scientific, source-based practice of history developed in Spain and her American colonies prior to the emergence of Leopold von Ranke as the father of modern history. 

Very briefly, the author’s argument suggests that in Renaissance and Enlightenment Europe a “conjectural” or philosophical methodology developed which later morphed, via epistemological debates, into a system which placed validity on contextually understood primary sources and the inclusion of extra-literary sources.  Rather than discount Amerindian sources, early Spanish chroniclers went to great length to include them in their works and the suspicion of Amerindian sources was the result of an Enlightenment era backlash against Renaissance humanism.  The Spanish literati were actively engaged in a debate about the validity and use of sources pertaining to the New World, thus creating a prototype of Ranke’s modern methodology of history.  Ultimately, this method found its way to the New World and was used by patriotic bourgeois writers to critique European histories of the region as uninformed.

After finishing the book, one wonders about the author’s intent because the narrative ends rather abruptly without a satisfactory conclusion.  If Canizares-Esguerra intended to demonstrate, through his narrative, that colonial Spain developed a critical, scientific method of historical investigation then he succeeded—documentary evidence may suggest a protomorphic theory of critical history in colonial Spain.  If this was his goal, however, he could simply have written a lengthy article or two and accomplished just as much as he did with his book.  The book simply does not leave the reader with a sense of accomplishment or closure. 

After reading the book, I found myself wondering: if this was a concerted trans-Atlantic movement among the literati of imperial Spain, why did it fail to have any impact on the larger Western world?  The author suggests, in chapter 3, that this protomorphic scientific history gained great prominence in Spain, but that factionalism at court and within the academy over methodology ultimately derailed most attempts to publish prominent histories and relegated many manuscripts dusty archives.  Annoyingly, he only briefly addresses actual circumstances which likely prohibited the success of this movement in his discussion of Spanish unity. 

All of this leaves me wondering—if the movement was hampered by factionalism both within the academy and at court, and if it failed to produce any major literary works acknowledged by the larger Western world, was the movement really a coherent movement at all?  Furthermore, does it even matter if these developments were occurring in Spain if they failed to influence scholars in the rest of Europe?  Often times it is not the discoverer who gets credit but the man who popularizes the idea.  Lastly, one has to wonder, was the movement fully understood in the New World, or was its methodology simply co-opted in service to patriotic goals in the wake of imperial Spain’s collapse?

entry.title: How to Write the History of History-- A Microstudy that Says A Lot
entry.content:
I will freely admit that I picked this book at my first presentation on a lark—I’m not a huge fan of Marxist critique, and I don’t yet feel comfortable with material culture or feminist theory, so I thought, “Hey, a book on the historiography of the New World! That sounds different.” It’s always nice when your gambles pay off.

Jorge Canizares-Esguera’s text is a fantastic analysis of the historiographic debates that emerged during the eighteenth century in Spain and Spanish America, essentially on the reliability of Amerindian sources. This is an incredible simplification of the debate, which also involved northern European views on Spanish backwardness, the effects of patriotism, and the like, but I have the opportunity to discuss them at length tomorrow night when I lead the discussion, so I just want to touch on a couple of points I found most interesting/useful. The cyclical nature of the historiographic debate interested me greatly, and I find it applicable in my own research. Renaissance humanist historians took native accounts to be of the highest value; Enlightenment philosophical historians denigrated them; the reaction sought to give them mixed status; and in the end we now view them as worthwhile again. Of course, this isn’t to say there aren’t flaws with the sources, or that we don’t have to be careful in how we use them, but in the end the use of these sources is once again admired and encouraged. The way history is thought about, the “philosophy of history,” changes, and what we think of as the correct method right now may not be viewed that way in, say, a century. Anything we write as historians may someday be slammed for using antiquated ideas, or be taught in a class simply to show how ignorant scholars used to be. It’s a humbling thought.

I also found that the arguments used by both sides, the patriotic aspects of the text, were incredibly informative. I’ve thought about nationalist histories, and I’ve also considered how patriotism affects the way history is taught in US schools, but I had not thought about the grander implications when it came to the study of history in general. The idea of the Spanish American Enlightenment, the differences between the Spanish and northern European Enlightenments, the idea that Spain was backwards, antiquated and medieval… even the general idea of a Protestant vision of history versus a Catholic one, all of these are areas I had not ever pondered. The book does a great job of showing the grander scale of the problem, while focusing on the very specific internal debates.

Final thought on the book: this book, How to Write the History of the New World, looks at such a specific time, place and problem—how eighteenth century Spanish historians dealt with the history of the New World. At the same time, it uses this narrow lens to explore how we, as modern historians, think about Atlantic history, how the greater debates of Enlightenment vs. Renaissance history were shaped, how our views on native sources, reliability of primary source, etc., were developed, and how Spanish and Latin American history has been pushed out of the realm of the “Western” world and into the fringes.

If only I could do something so incredibly complex through a microstudy.

entry.title: Post
entry.content:
Kara Kempski
Post 2: How to Write the History of the New World

Jorge Cañizares-Esguerra clearly illustrates how complex and often bitter debates over credibility shaped the historical writings of the New World. Seemingly each effort at historiography was highly contested and very personal, as questions of intellectual capability and scholarly merit were not only leveled against individuals, but whole societies. Some believed that indigenous people and sources were not to be trusted. Multiple scholars proposed pseudo-scientific studies that the climate of the region disallowed Amerindian credibility since they were inherently inferior people, prone to lying. Others believed that their society was far less-developed, so reports of former grandeur and their own reports could not be trusted. This argument was furthered in many attacks on Amerindians’ system of record-keeping, which did not use alphabetic writing. As Cañizares-Esguerra explains on page 64, “Since God had transmitted his dispensation through the written word, societies that lacked “writing” were considered not only outside the pale of civilization, but humanity as well…Amerindian nonalphabetic scripts were, therefore, considered incapable of accumulating knowledge, which was the foundation of civilization.” Many reacted against such negative characterizations of the Amerindian societies, though for varying reasons. Clearly this was an affront to the learning and humanity of the societies in the New World and some scholars, particularly from the New World, took offense and strove to disprove such notions in their publications.

Others sought to defend Spanish conquistadors and colonials, since these dismissals of early Spanish observations also discredited the Spanish accounts as ignorance at best, deluded fantasy at worst. Questions of the capability of the “Spanish mind,” were rampant in Europe, albeit often through innuendo. Even within Spain, some scholars lamented the fact that those conquistadors and missionaries who first encountered the Amerindian cultures were woefully inept and their testimony could not be trusted. This led some to believe that all these testimonies should be thrown out and the history to be written anew. The debate over the “Spanish mind” also surfaced in other forms: some believed only non-Spanish scholars should write the history of Spanish-encounters with the New World, because only they could have the appropriate detachment(or, to some, necessary intellectual ability). Some believed Spain should adopt the styles of other European scholarly communities to be taken more seriously on the international stage; others argued that Spaniards should reassert their strong humanistic heritage and take precedence in scholarship relating to the Americas. Meanwhile, the scholarly community also quarreled over whether Spaniards should be openly critical of past misconduct or if such airing of dirty-laundry would be inappropriately unpatriotic.

What was actually discovered in the scripts, stones, and other documents seemed secondary to the debate behind who was doing the writing, and it was secondary in the book. There was some attention paid to it, particularly to the Amerindian development of highly complex calendric systems, but not much. This book posed some interesting questions and succeeds at demonstrating how multi-faceted the debate over the history of the New World was at this time. However, it is often repetitive, including reusing whole paragraphs from the introductions in other sections of the book, word for word. It is also often redundant in its arguments and conclusions, to the point that I feel that the book would be more successful with a general reordering of its chapters and sub-chapters.
