entry.title: How to Write the History of the New World
entry.content:
After spending more hours than I care to calculate wading through this book, and then reading through my notes to see if the distilled version is any clearer, I have to announce that I’m very disappointed by the entire endeavor. In the first paragraph of his introduction, Jorge Canizares-Esguerra announced that the thesis of his book is that the modern attitudes in historiography originated in 18th century Spain and Spanish America, not in 19th century Germany. But the subsequent 347 very dense pages suggest that his real goal was to show us just how very, very much research he had done. Unfortunately, when you include so much information, it tends to bury rather than support your point.

His first chapter discussed how these 18th century historians came to favor internal consistency in their resources over the credibility that comes from proximity. If the 16th century accounts made claims that didn’t support the 18th century expectations, then they were rejected. There were a lot of other topics stuffed into the chapter as well, but that seemed to be the overall gist that was trying to peek through the verbiage.

Chapter two revolved, loosely, around how attitudes toward forms of recording texts (alphabetically, pictorially, etc.) informed various eras’ attitudes toward the credibility of native American primary sources. Most Europeans believed they were unreliable because the authors were too primitive to know what they were doing, since they hadn’t yet developed enough to use alphabets. He did include other opinions, though.

Chapter three explored how patriotism in Spain inspired new histories and historical projects. But in pursuing these, they were caught between wanting to clear away images of 16th century Spanish slaughter, and not wanting to discount the accuracy of 16th century Spanish accounts of grand civilizations. Most of their efforts went unpublished, though, so Spain never got credit for the insights and advances they contributed to the art of writing history.

Chapter four provided many, many examples of these 18th century historians and what they were doing (and how, why, when, where, with whom, against, whom, and on and on). I think his point was to show that no matter what their topic or position relative to northern European techniques, they all agreed that credibility only resides in upper class natives.

Chapter five looked at American historians to show how they approached the investigation of some newly discovered stone calendars and the ruins of a jungle city. Again, there was a lot of variety of opinion and technique, but they agreed that American history couldn’t be accurately written by non-Americans. The side trip through Borunda’s linguistic fantasies added nothing to the discussion, and strongly reminded me of that poor mathematician in A Beautiful Mind.

And then, with no warning, the book finally ended. His conclusion just reiterated all of the topics and examples, without really synthesizing or concluding anything. It was done, but I didn’t feel any satisfaction from finishing something.

Hmmm, I guess the process of writing this entry has cleared some of the thicket. Each of these chapters was intended to illustrate how and why his historians were, in fact, engaging in the historiographical behaviors ascribed to von Ranke and his gang a hundred years later. I still think the book would have been better if his editor had taken a firmer position on slashing excess.

entry.title: Meanwhile... back in "The New World"
entry.content:
“How to Write the History of the New World” by Jorge Cañizares-Esguerra


It would appear that, while most Spaniards were searching for the little yellow rocks, others were busying themselves by collecting - and subsequently destroying - Amerindian writings on the grounds that they were demonic. And this simply because the images used to describe events looked like demons and snakes and such. Didn’t the European maps of the time also have serpents and sea creatures on them? Or, was this a decided effort by the conquering armies to break the unifying effect of a collective history? The attempts of the indigenous people to hide and protect their writings speak to the importance they gave to these manuscripts. The sad part is that these manuscripts were parceled out later to the highest bidders.

entry.title: Why can't these guys just get along?
entry.content:
“How to Write the History of the New World” by Jorge Cañizares-Esguerra:

The question of who had the “correct” interpretation of Mesoamerican history seems the overriding question during the 17th and 18th century in Spain. And while they were at each other’s throats they were united in saying that the rest of Europe didn’t have a clue about what was hidden in the non-Latin based indigenous sources because they weren’t even around while the Spaniards were sacking and pillaging cities and villages in their insatiable lust for gold.  This meant they were not in the country enough time to learn the local ways before the elders were gone. 
As to the in-fighting, I guess it would be hard to write a critical history with the knowledge that if you wrote against the government it could get you exiled, ostracized, censured, or worse. Speaking of the rest of Europe, did anyone on this side of the pond like what Buffon was writing?
Finally, was it me or did all of them eventually make Biblical references and links from and to Mesoamerican historical accounts?

more later….

James H

entry.title: Thoughts on The Footnote by Anthony Grafton
entry.content:
This book was comically written and truly a joy to read.  That was sincerely unexpected as the history of the Footnote has connotations of boredom implied in the title.  Now to comment on its contents, I was pleasantly surprised to learn that it was in the field of the Footnote that modern historical disputes are “punched out.”  Grafton enlightened me of the key insult technique of “CF” in American historical work, which he then used in the same page to take a stab at a contemporary of his in this field of historiographical work.  This intellectual battleground gave a third level to a history book, the first being the narrative, the second the footnote, and within the footnote the fight between historians.

He also does an excellent job of explaining that the purpose of the footnote today is extremely varied.  There are varying schools of thought, all methodical in respect to different pieces of information.  And so the footnote allows the historian to know “the intellectual styles of different national scientific communities, the pedagogical methods of the different graduate programs, and the literary preferences of different journal editors.”(pg 13)

The original purpose of the footnotes as they developed in historiography were to provide the reader with “proof.”  Through the course of Historiography however, the “proof” gradually found its way more and more in the main narrative of the text and the footnote took the role of supplying the sources that the historian used, so as to demonstrate where the information was gathered and show the reader that an “acceptable” amount of work was done to come to the conclusions that the author developed.

Overall, I enjoyed reading this book and learning of the evolution of the footnote, and more specifically from roles that Gibbon, Ranke and De Thou played.

entry.title: Reflections on Anthony Grafton's 'The Footnote'
entry.content:
I’ve never given much thought to the humble footnote. It probably would be fair to say I’ve viewed it simply as a device writers utilize “to show that they have put in hours of hard work in archive and library,” as Anthony Grafton puts it (referring specifically to students). Footnotes, Grafton continues, “confer authority on a writer.” ‘Nuff said.

But in his surprisingly engaging book “The Footnote: A Curious History,” Grafton deftly illuminates the ways in which the form’s evolution, like that of historiography as a whole, is in fact interwoven with the overlapping forces of social, political and religious history.

Quite interesting are the stories of Ranke, Gibbon, de Thou, Kircher, Bayle and others whose works and concomitant outlooks helped shape the approaches now widely practiced.

Meanwhile, particularly eye-opening to me was Grafton’s explanation of how footnotes can (and have) been used to perpetrate, rather than prevent, plagiarism. Less surprising was the disclosure that footnotes sometimes are compiled as a means of representing (or even misrepresenting) selected texts, so as to justify pre-established positions.

I would not go so far as to say that I’ll never again see as tedious the writing and reading of footnotes. But thanks to Grafton, I do now have an appreciation of their deeper significance.

entry.title: Week 2 HST 510 "The Footnote"
entry.content:
I must confess that Footnotes were a subject I knew very little about prior to this reading, even though I use them constantly.  In The Footnote, Anthony Grafton recreates the tumultuous history of the development of the use of footnotes and appendices.  The footnote developed as “proof” of scholarly integrity through the proper recording of ones sources of information within a given work. 

I found it interesting that the author whose footnotes I’ve always found most intriguing, namely Edward Gibbon, actually disliked them and felt they detracted in some way from his work.  I also enjoyed the way in which Grafton explains Leopold von Ranke’s role in solidifying the role of proper sourcing of information for our age, not only through his love of research, but through his adeptness at repelling criticism through the integrity of his work.

I was not surprised to see that footnoting, perhaps not in its present state, but in a fashion, existed prior to the Renaissance.  Also not surprising is that religious patronage played a part, however dubiously, in footnote development.  What I was surprised about was that there has been so much controversy about the use of footnotes, what form they should take, and even if they should be used at all.  How odd that they are such an integral part of expressing our research bona fides these days, when they were treated with such contempt by such giants as Voltaire! 

In closing, I’d like to say, tongue in cheek, that it was funny that Anthony Grafton’s The Footnote seemed to be comprised of about half text and half footnotes.  I think this was purposeful.  I was a little disappointed not to see some of Gibbon’s irreverance in them just for fun, but they were still a nice touch.

entry.title: I wish I could write the entirety of this entry in footnotes…
entry.content:
Anthony Grafton, The Footnote: A Curious History

When I began reading Grafton’s volume I found myself constantly wondering what is the point of all this, what can an overly philosophical and seemingly menial inquiry provide to my understanding of the practice of history?  To be sure, I gained a few insights into the history of the footnote, about its ancient antecedents, its relationship to commentaries and the appendix, but I ultimately failed to understand the worth of this book.  The footnote is a technical apparatus used by a variety of writers throughout history, and it may have an interesting history (to some), but does a modern historian really need any deep insight into the philosophy of the footnote?  Is a mere understanding of its function enough to guide the historian in its effective use?

Ah!  But therein lays the rub—its effective use.  Behind the multitude of examples and the discussion of methods used by ancient, medieval, renaissance, and early modern historians, Grafton addresses himself to issues which, while seemingly off topic, are useful to understanding good scholarship.  His analysis of the various forms of footnotes—such as those which provide commentary, educated debate, factual references, or the nature of sources—could spark lively debate over the appropriateness of each form and its usefulness to modern historians.  For our purposes in this course that may indeed be necessary.

Its benefits to debate notwithstanding, I am still not satisfied with the volume.   Throughout most of the book I found myself questioning what purpose the vignettes offered about Ranke, Gibbon, and other historians served.  I found the book less of a history on the footnote and more of an examination of the scholarship of history through the last four hundred years—which absolutely bored me at times, but could also come through with no small amount of humor.  At times it seemed to me as though Grafton actually got caught up in this examination of practice rather than his stated goal of examining the footnote.  It may be, however, that his examination of the practice of history over the course of these centuries is not without merit, and it may prove a lively source of debate about practices—a goal perhaps our instructor. 

Only in the final segment of the book, coyly titled “Some Concluding Footnotes,” could I find anything which would cause me to recommend this book.  Here, the author finally ties together the loose strings from his preceding vignettes.  Here, in the conclusion Grafton finally makes an argument worth reading, asserting that is the footnote and methodologies of history which make it possible to defend against the innate desire among men and nations to keep their skeletons well hidden, so that the Truth may be known and followed back to its sources.  It may be cartoonish, but it was one of the few moments if found in this book worth reading.

entry.title: 8/29 Grafton
entry.content:
Grafton, Anthony. The Footnote. Cambridge: Harvard University Press, 1997.

While reading Grafton’s book, I was intrigued by the long-lasting debate in the scholarly community of the seventeenth through nineteenth centuries about whether to even use footnotes at all. Did a footnote disrupt the flow of a learned, stylistically pleasing narrative or add to the scholar’s credibility and allow readers to check the work and subsequently perform their own scholarship? A seemingly endless drama appears to have raged, with adherents from the Pantheon of Great People firmly entrenched in their positions on either side.

And it never seemed to have ended. Even Ranke struggled with the question of whether or not to include citations, and from the way Grafton presents the information, printing your sources and criticism was perhaps more likely to get you heavily critiqued than not doing so, at least for a time. Of course, we have the modern footnote today, with some rather more carefully delineated usages for it, but the question remains: do you clutter the bottom of every page with notes, some of which must by spatial necessity flow onto the next (or the next) page, or do you shift your second narrative, as Grafton views it, to the back of the book and simply denote its presence with unobtrusive numbers? Certainly, I had noticed the difference between footnotes and endnotes before, but Grafton’s book prompted me to really consider their uses for varying audiences, the members of the historical profession or a lay audience, which would be perhaps more interested in the narrative and the conclusions rather than being able to trace the author’s time spent in archives.

Though I enjoyed Grafton’s book and his comments about footnotes and the way in which he uses the idea of source documentation as a sort of lens through which to view the construction of the modern historical field, I must admit that I was perplexed by the book’s organization. The word “vignettes” kept running through my mind while reading it, and I think I would have gotten more out of it had Grafton chosen to organize his study in a more chronological fashion, rather than choosing to leap around in time and pursue a sort of treasure hunt, on the path of the elusive footnote. I’m certainly a fan of in media res openings, so I don’t fault him for beginning with a short bit about Ranke, but overall, I felt as though I was not only reading an in media res opening, but also an imr middle and an imr conclusion.

entry.title: historian in training 2010-08-29 18:16:00
entry.content:
When I first discovered that this book was dedicated solely to the issue of footnotes, I must admit that I was not quite as excited as some of my colleagues seem to have been. Footnotes, while I have always conceded their necessity and usefulness, have never truly found a place in my historical heart. I am happy to say, however, that this book brought a new life and meaning to the footnote that has since convinced me to rethink my position.

The footnote was a sadly overlooked topic at my undergraduate college, and we were taught to use it only in the modernized form that Grafton laments. I never truly understood how simplified this one-sided use of the footnote was until Grafton’s text delved into the myriad ways in which the footnote has been and ought to be used. Rather than simply  being a tool to help insure historical veracity, footnotes in fact form a story of their own, one that tells as much about the author as is does the subject being discussed. Whether the footnote is in narrative form or providing supporting evidence, these brief side points allow a more personal glimpse of the author to come through than would be considered appropriate within the actual text itself.

Much like historical thought is constantly changing and developing, the footnote too is a surprisingly fluid concept. It reflects general intellectual trends of the time and provides a strong indication of the way a particular period approached the subject of history. For as long as histories have been around, the footnote has been a proud declaration of contemporary historical values. Even the absence of footnotes provides an indication of the importance placed on historical truth, or rather the failure to do so. There was no steady path culminating in the institutionalized version of today’s footnote, nor did it simply spring into existence fully formed and ready to go. The development of the footnote has taken a long time and often followed a somewhat bumpy path; progress has not always characterized its evolution and at some points it seems to have actually regressed.


I was impressed that this book actually had me missing the “good old” footnotes by its conclusion, where stories were told and jabs made. I too have noticed an increasing trend in current historiographical works to dedicate footnotes solely to providing documentation and information regarding further reading. While these are of course critical to providing a valid historical work, they lack the punch found in narrative footnotes. Ranke’s great problem with footnotes was that they interrupted the text, but I find that my reading only feels interrupted when the footnotes are nothing but lines of abbreviations and numbers that take minutes to decipher. I tend to get inexplicably excited when I come across a footnote that is simply three of four lines of text, always hoping that it will provide a little side entertainment before returning to the main work. While it is not practical, or even desirable, to constrain modern usage of the footnote to its narrative form, it would be appreciated to see a little more life fed back into the bottom of the page. I doubt this will happen any time soon, however, for as Grafton points out the footnote is essential to a historian and his/her work. Although footnotes are unable to definitively prove an author’s point, they provide the best reassurance we have to the veracity of a historical study and reflect the time and effort a historian put into their work. As such, the footnote is an essential tool for any professional historian and, like it or not, is around to stay.

entry.title: de Thou's peer review
entry.content:
Did I read this right?  Did Jacques-Auguste de Thou start the use of peer review?[1]  Today it is almost expected that one’s work is checked by reviewers in the various historical journals as both a demonstration of our professionalism and as a method of protecting the honor of our guild.  I’m sure that de Thou may have seen it fulfilling these, but it also may have been that he was taking the lower position to these erudite individuals.  It was a way of saying, “Hey, I’m new here and this is what I have found.  Would you be so kind as to double-check my findings to be sure the facts are correct?  If something is missing, please fill in the gaps as I want this to be as correct as possible.”  Instead of putting his work out there and saying, “Prove me wrong,” he took what Franklin later called “the humble inquirer,”[2]  By elevating other scholar’s positions in asking for help, de Thou could make use of more brainpower to try to get the history as close to correct as he could.

1.  Anthony Grafton, The Footnote [Cambridge: Harvard Univ. Press, 1997], 136.
2.  Benjamin Franklin, The Autobiography and Other Writings, ed. L. Jesse Lemisch [New York: Signet Classic, 2001], 30.

entry.title: Post #1
entry.content:
Post #1

August 29, 2010

Grafton, Anthony. The Footnote. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 1997.

Anthony Grafton takes an incisive look at the history of the footnote and its use in historical writing. He examines the multiple uses of the footnote; to aid the reader in their scholarship, to lend legitimacy to one’s work, to give credit to previous historians, and to discredit, discount, and humiliate one’s academic rivals, past and present. He devotes about as much time to the last use of the footnote as he does to the historical development of the footnote, the first use of which he dates to be around 1700, if not a few years before. Grafton explains the various uses of the footnote well, and how they have been part of historical debate for centuries. He extends his focus to the historians who are using them, and he does well examining the scholars and periods of academia with a fair eye. He acknowledges both the difficulties the scholars faced and their often bloated sense of accomplishment. These brief biographies of the historians are insightful and fairly even-handed, offering both praise and addressing failures and short-comings. The strongest point of the book, I felt, was the chapter placing the footnote, finally, at its inception in the Eighteenth Century. He demonstrates the difficulties historians at that time faced to reassert the importance of history and the other humanities at the time of so many other scientific Enlightenment breakthroughs. To confirm the validation of the subject while radically changing its practice is certainly a difficult task. Grafton cites some historians’ articulate defense of the subject, and supports the progression of the discipline, advocating the double-narrative that historians often use today.

The book moves along at a decent pace and is well-written. It must be admitted that the author seems to greatly enjoy his own writing, and employs various turns-of-phrase and literary analogies, which are at times interesting side-notes, but often seemed to me to be gratuitous assertions of his own learning. To pay tribute to his multiple literary references, I think it fitting to compare him to the character of E. K. Hornbeck in Inherit the Wind, a play by Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee. Hornbeck is a Baltimore newspaper man, who writes with a clever sophistication and “sneers politely at everything, including himself.” That being said, for what could have been a painfully dry subject, Grafton infuses a lot of life into the narrative, with his character sketches and related stories. Using the footnote as a lens, he is able not only to reveal the development of this historical apparatus, but also to offer a look into the world of historians, and the politics surrounding the study of history in each of the centuries he addresses.

entry.title: Response to Anthony Grafton's The Footnote (*a curious history)
entry.content: The most interesting section of Grafton’s book is a two-page section where he describes the duty of an historian “to tell the double story of the historical past and the historian’s research” before acknowledging that one of the primary champion’s of the footnote, Leopold von Ranke, “thought that the best historical narrative was a classical one, free of notes.” (pgs 67-68). I find it interesting because it tells the story of the great battle every historian fights: the battle between entertainment and authority. Authority, it seems, is purchased with the cost of at least some entertainment value; while the well-read historian can integrate the footnote into a narrative (or an argument) by second nature, many people get confused by or lost in the notes. Putting them at the end solves much of this; some histories have even done away with the footnote all together, dismissing them in works which they acknowledge are meant for the non-professional audience. The assumption is, of course, that the broad public wants a story while the professional cadre demands sources. While this seems at least minimally insulting to the broad public, it seems equally dismissive of the professional, as if they are some breed of automaton who can only process information if it comes with a superscript number behind it. I wonder, though, if this really distorts the message historians are presenting to the public–and I do not mean that the professional historian is imbibed with both certain etiquette and certain standards, which it should be– but that the historian desires a history that is not entertaining. The goal of every historical writing (I should hope) is that the joy of a subject, felt first by the historian, can be communicated through the mutual process of the narrative. Removing the footnote or the specific end note supplies another level of remove from that research which, while it may be less clumsy, takes away from the joy of learning something: that there is honest work in arriving at the truth.

entry.title: Sic transit gloria mundi
entry.content: For over a thousand years Roman conquerors returning from the wars enjoyed the honor of a triumph, a tumultuous parade. In the procession came trumpeters, musicians and strange animals from conquered territories, together with carts laden with treasure and captured armaments. The conquerors rode in a triumphal chariot, the dazed prisoners walking in chains before him. Sometimes his children robed in white stood with him in the chariot or rode the trace horses. A slave stood behind the conqueror holding a golden crown above his head and whispering in his ear a warning: that all glory is fleeting.

entry.title: The Footnote, A Curious Histoy
entry.content:
Anthony Grafton provided many definitions of footnotes throughout this book, beginning with, “[they] offer the empirical support for stories told and arguments supported” on page vii of the preface, and ending with “[they] enable[ ] historians to make their texts not monologues but conversations, in which modern scholars, their predecessors, and their subjects all take part” on page 234 of the epilogue.  In between, he even referred to them in sacramental terms, on page 24.  But this book did much more than simply define or dissect the small print at the bottom of the page, the reward—or not—for breaking your attention to the main text.  He used the development of, and changing attitudes toward, footnotes as a guiding theme for looking at the evolution of historiography itself, or at least one strand of it.  By following his trail, I was led to visit several eras of thought around how to write history, and I was introduced (or re-introduced) to an entertaining variety of thinkers.

Grafton opened his journey with a visit to Edward Gibbon, whose snarky footnotes put him in a class with Bierce, Twain, Fields, and others.  This was an appropriate beginning not only as an incentive to further explore what could have seemed an arid wasteland of parentheses and Latin abbreviations, but also because it foreshadowed Grafton’s own use of witty analogies and clever wordplay.  Besides comparing footnotes to a sacrament, he mentioned Ali Baba’s cave (x), swarming anthills (9), seas of lemonade (12) pigs and geese (35 and 37), thrift shops (39), armored vehicles (56), William Morris wallpaper (111), hitchhiking (135), and alchemy (199).  I very much appreciated seeing that academic writing doesn’t have to consist of convoluted, passively voiced, pretentiously worded sentences.  He was clear and interesting as well as informative.

He seems to have two main points that he’s making with his survey of footnotes throughout history.  One is that they tell a different, but equally important story than the one presented in the main text.  The text tells the history of the subject at hand, and the footnotes tell the history of creating that text above.  His other point is that our modern footnotes have a much more interesting genealogy than their current business-like practice would suggest, sort of like that Rockwell family tree, where little perfect Johnny has all sorts of interesting scalawags in his background. 

Today’s footnotes “convince the reader that the historian has done an acceptable amount of work…[and] indicate the chief sources that the historian has actually used.” (22) Occasionally they provide interesting additions to the main text, but often they’re bare citations.  I mentally cheered when I read Hume’s comment on page 103 that flipping pages only to find nothing entertaining is a frustration that needs to be remedied.  I was thinking along the lines of different typeface for the numbers that refer to citations or to commentary, but his idea of citations at the bottom and good stuff at the end would work as well.  Clearly distinguishing between the two roles of footnotes might encourage more creative use of the second role, too.

After beginning with Gibbon, the first chapter considered German arrogance and Positivism, then compared ancient helps to today’s footnotes.  Biblical and classical glosses, fifth-century legal writings, and Peter Lombard’s citations have elements in common with our current expectations, but fundamentally were included to help a limited reader approach and understand an authoritative text, not—as now—to show the ingredients of a text that has a particular and contingent perspective to add to the many valid voices on its topic.

The sections on Ranke were dear to my librarian’s heart.  Its always fun to meet someone who loves not only the treasures in an archive, but even the basic act of sifting through the detritus to find them.  And the chapter about Enlightenment excesses was wonderful.  I love the cheeky, droll, irreverent parodies he described.  They reminded me of Flanders & Swann, a musical duo with the same dry wit.  I’d never thought about footnotes for fiction, but I like the idea, sort of like parenthetical asides on an official scale (I’m a big fan of parenthetical asides).  Chapter five zipped through several people to show how respect for accuracy in the details developed over the years, even as admitting to the process of ensuring accuracy was kept hidden from the reader.  Chapter six, too, showed growth in careful scholarship still being kept behind the literary green baize door.

Finally, in chapter seven, Grafton shared the tale of Pierre Bayle’s dictionary, and how it made footnotes in scholarly works not only acceptable, but even desirable.  Bayle took pride in being a compiler, not a historian, of presenting facts and sources, not opinions and conclusions.  This was fitting to the time, as authority came under such fire in the seventeenth century.  Authors, along with science, the Bible, and politics, could no longer simply state their position and expect it to be accepted simply because of their position as authority figures.  Footnotes lent them credibility by showing why they should be trusted and believed, which is a big part of their role today.

In the epilogue, Grafton says, “Modern history is modern precisely because it tries to give a coherent literary form to both parts of the historical enterprise.” (232)   After showing the fits and starts, the shifting balance between eloquence and accuracy, and other lurching steps on the road to modern historiography, he sums up the story arc and leaves us with a few gentle warnings.  Footnotes can’t do everything we expect them to, they’re as prone to manipulation as are statistics, and they’re currently not as stylish as they could be.  However, they are our best guarantee of reliability, they show the investigative process of writing history, and they invite readers to become participants in the joys of exploring and sharing the story of human activity.

entry.title: The Footnote-- The Historian's Dagger
entry.content:
The pen is mightier than the sword, and the footnote is its stab to the kidneys.

I have a slight personal bias in favor of this book, because I love footnotes and the snarky things historians sometimes insert. I have been at conferences where I watched two scholars who have engaged in a war of footnote words act incredibly cordially to one another then mutter asides to their cohorts after they move on. The footnote as a tool for commentary is one of the things I most enjoyed about my undergraduate education, and when I purchased Anthony Grafton’s text, I was excited to learn more about it.

Grafton makes a couple of early points that have been my own understanding of footnotes, apparently antiquated: as he says, “A hundred years ago, most historians would have made a simple distinction: the text persuades, the notes prove.”[1] This is apparently horribly outdated, as the text is where the notes and studies are stuffed, with only the barest source material in the footnotes. I prefer the narrative nature of footnotes in someone like Gibbon, whom he rightfully lists as the master of the craft. I like footnotes to be rich, miniature essays in their own write, exhorting me to further research on a very specific point and giving me starting materials from which to expand.

The footnote changes history. It changes the way we think about history. The great medieval and classical histories are written by people who either experienced the events or interviewed people, or, in some cases, checked other books, but they don’t systematically cite or attempt to prove—it is assumed that you trust them, which leads to things like Geoffrey of Monmouth’s magnum opus. With footnotes, as Grafton points out, you have to look at the history being written through the lens of a historian; there are credentials being stated, and a modern worldview, and a detachment. A historian records history, he isn’t the one creating it.
The fallibility of footnotes, which Ranke dealt with in relation to Renaissance histories, is one of the things that scares me when it comes to academic texts. I know that a good editor and publishing company will at least check to make sure that all citations are factually correct, but sometimes when delving through history texts I wonder about the myriad sources and citations. Ranke managed to discover vast falsehoods, and I assume that the trend of scientific history has prevented the kind of widespread shenanigans exhibited in older texts, but it makes me a little paranoid at times.

Ranke’s issue with the footnote mirrors one of my own. Don’t get me wrong—when I read a history book as a scholar, I revel in footnotes. I like to write them down, and go look up the other sources and suggestions later to further my own education, and I enjoy the discussion of methodology, historiography, etc. that can accompany them. That being said, I sympathize with Ranke’s plight, and I sometimes wish for the unbroken narrative given by older, footnote-less texts. The use of appendices and endnotes can mitigate this to some degree, and I’ve read a number of popular-format history books that do this. In the end, I’m of split minds, because the scholar half of me hates to be without copious footnotes, but the reader prefers it greatly.
I love how Grafton takes the history of the footnote, and the history of history attached to it, and traces us back through a series of famous figures that I’ve actually heard of to explore how long historians have been obsessed with factuality, with delving into primary sources and supporting their work. While they may have been exceptions within their own time, I have been under the impression that carefully documented history was a modern obsession solely, a product of the need to prove the workload that went into an article or a monographs creation. Happily, this was a false assumption, and the footnote, or at least document-based history of the critical and well-supported nature, goes back through the early modern period.

This book does a number of important things. Firstly, it forces the reader to reevaluate the purpose, history, and meaning of footnotes. They are not just dry citations, but an entire discussion within themselves that speaks volumes about the authors training, methods, ideological approach, and in the best of them, his rivalries within his field. Secondly, it provides a good historiography of historical scholarship, in its many forms and stretching from the modern era back to the antiquarians of the 16th-17th century, and tracing back to antiquity to look at the ways in which the Greco-Roman world did history. As a book, it is a fine introduction to historiography all on its own. Thirdly, it shows how vital archival work and delving into primary sources really is. I’ve always been excited about the idea of finding new things to write about, but this book made it very clear how vital actually going to archives is, not just trusting republications of them. Connected to this is a paranoia about secondary sources, that you must carefully analyze every source you come into contact with.

Grafton laments the decline of the footnote into glorified citations, a sad fate for such an interesting means of communicating information. If nothing else, this interesting book has me promising not waste good footnotes on such a boring purpose—cite, yes, but comment as well.

[1] Anthony Grafton, The Footnote (Cambridge, MA: Harvard UP, 1997), 15.

entry.title: Why historians do what they do
entry.content:
While reading Grafton’s “The Footnote,” I came across this, “…historians perform two complementary tasks. They must examine all the sources relevant to the solution of a problem and construct a new narrative or argument from them.” (4, 5) He also went on to say that use of footnotes “identifies the work of history in question as the creation of a professional.” This spoke to me as it related to what we discussed in class last Monday. How are we as emerging historians to show that we truly belong to this guild? Mathematicians use proofs of mathematical formulas, or postulates. Doctors site case studies of diseases and cures to show they are correct in what they are saying. We have the written records and documents. Why a person did this or that can be ascertained by what was said to witnesses and what the person himself may have written. All the while we are never forgetting that those telling the story are infusing their own view as well, or are aware that posterity will use their words for its own interpretation. Still, Grafton returns to the idea that “footnotes serve to prove the author’s membership in a guild rather than to illuminate or support a particular point.” (108) It simply shows that we have done the legwork to find information on the topic upon which we are expounding.


More to follow…

entry.title: Getting Ready To Do History
entry.content:
First reading for my 510 class, William Cronon’s “Getting Ready to Do History.”

I have to admit, I was intrigued by the opening question of what a historian actually does, because I have in the past fallen into the category of those who would have just said “study history” and moved on. Really, I know that was a simplistic answer, but I wouldn’t have bothered to go any further into what I actually mean about that. His long bulleted list of what historians do, the things that link them, and the sketch of what I should, to a certain extent, begin thinking about as a new historian (new as in length of time doing it, rather than the historical school of thought). The last couple of points, especially the continuing emphasis on narrative storytelling, made me very happy, because history is fun and exciting, and should be written that way—a good history book is just as fun to read as any fiction.

I was also struck by the acknowledgement that history is written distinctly from our modern perspective, that we are constructing history based on our own views, and that this is ok and how we should and will operate. My teachers discussed history not in terms of objectivity but interpretation, but they did try to convince me that my own biases were bad and I should work to defeat them within my own text. I appreciate that it is understood that my bias is part of my text, and that honestly it is an important part. My history texts, my writings, are in the end valuable as a history of my lifetime and my particular context, because my biases and how they come out in my text are important markers of our culture.


When reading about the Ph.D. Octopus, I was reminded of a graphic distinction I just saw:


What Exactly Is A Doctorate?


I miss the era of the Renaissancce Man, where the mark of a good education was being deeply educated in a wide variety of areas. I would love to be able to get Ph.D.’s in several areas, or at least Master’s programs, or something of that nature. While I do have a passion for the area of history I am going into, I wish it were acceptable and practical to continue dabbling through higher education. At the same time, you do become theoretically the master of your chosen field, the absolute top scholar in a very narrow area. I know that the techniques I am learning/will learn will allow me to pick up any knowledge I care to study later, I agree that it stifles a bit of creativity within the bureaucratic undertaking of actually getting the doctorate.


I found this article on the whole heartening about the profession and the way it is being thought of. I come from a school with more narrow views on the future of history and the historians, and reading this article I felt that there is a very good sense of the vastness of possibility within somewhat fixed but generally free boundaries. While the guild structure of the historian is a real thing, I feel that the guild is shifting, that new types of history and old are both alive and well, and that the community I am entering is one that I will be able to adapt to well.
